review:
[h2][u][b]Frustrating...[/b][/u][/h2]
[h3]‚Ä¶and not relaxing, challenging, or enjoyable![/h3]
I usually like games with turn based strategic battles, but definitely not this one!

It seems that there is often only one way to win a battle, and you have to figure it out somehow. This means that you have to play some fights over and over again to perhaps find the only solution!? This is exactly what increases the further you progress in the game..., in my eyes absolutly frustrating and not fun (Example fights... ‚ÄúMarwans Attack‚Äù or ‚ÄúAdamant the Creator‚Äù)

I wasn't able to play Blackguards 1 because it's crashed every 5 minutes, but what i have seen looked very very similar to this part 2!

[u][b]Positives[/b][/u]
- Graphics and sound are fine for the time
- Combat system itself is ok
- Skill system, items, inventory are ok for this ‚Äûkind‚Äú of game 
- I'm surprised I didn't had any crashes here because of these in 1
- I only paid about a ‚Ç¨uro for it bundled with some other games...

[u][b]Negatives[/b][/u]
- The difficulty level is extrem poorly balanced
- Some really bad made / balanced fights
- Not really strategic, because there are often only a few / or maybe only one possible solution to win some of the battles
- There is often no time / a possibility to prepare your heros for fights 
- Good story but bad writen / made 
- Flat characters
- Feels overall definitely not finished / polished
‚Ä¶and so on...

[u][b]Final words[/b][/u]
This game could be sooooo much better, but it is what it is and that's not good! Maybe the developers were a bit frustrated too and also didn't want to look for a needle in a haystack...
Greetings & glhf anytime!

author: {'steamid': '76561198074085825', 'num_games_owned': 4493, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 2085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2085, 'last_played': 1594594940}
review:
Simply put, this game has a really odd story line. One minute I was murdering villagers to get more AP, the next I was letting prisoners go out of the kindness of my heart. Strangely it was all a lot of fun.

At first I didn't like the main character. She was a evil looking thing with boils covering half her face, but after her personality develops she is pretty interesting. I initially thought she was going to be evil the entire game, but not so. She turns out to be a pretty cool chick that just got in with some bad dudes.

One thing I wasn't so sure about is that you don't get to "make" your own character, but you can develop the main character anyway you want. Also she has a lot of speaking scenes and good voice acting which makes up for the inability to create your character from scratch. Also you only get 4 customizatable characters, which feels lacking to me for some reason. Also while they start off with alot to say, by mid game they just repeat the same old crap. One character, you can't even speak to after mid game. You see him sitting there, but that's it, you can't select to chat with him.

I didn't really like the way items and equipment were introduced to the characters. Some weapon types had a lot of really good weapons, while others didn't have much. Maybe it was on a loot table and I just got the good sword items and missed out on the good axe items. Too bad no one in my group used swords.

The story was odd, as I said earlier, but still interesting. I saw a lot of choices, which I always tried to pick the good one, except when AP was up for grabs. The interrogation process was interesting, but I failed most of them. :P Finally I figured out that I should save before I start the interrogation, and reload after I fail it. During the interrogation, you try to figure out what is the best way to handled the one you are interrogating. You can intimidate them, lie to them, or make them an offer. From what I could tell, they provide you with some information is you get everything right. Like I said, I did fail most of these.

The character customization was pretty good too. You have a lot of stuff to spend your AP on. Almost everything is at least a little useful. The only problem is all your characters except Cassia come predisposed to certain weapon types, so it doesn't make sense to change it. I ended up using Naurim's starter axe through the entire game. I would of loved to have switched him to something better, but I just never found anything better.

On the battle field is where this game shines though. Lots of stuff to do, and losts of stuff to watch out for. Only problem with them is a lot of the maps aren't as developed as I would like, but still most battles are really fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019450993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2725, 'last_played': 1704033690}
review:
This game is much easier than the first one. Didn't take a four + year break on this and knocked it back in two weeks. Just thought I'd start with that.

The voice acting is still stellar.
The locations are varied and many are pretty to look at.
The potion drinking sound is less annoying. THE POTION DRINKING SOUND IS LESS ANNOYING.

What kind of game is this, then? A turn based strategy game based on the Dark Eye setting where during battle you control a party of adventurers on a hex based grid. The strategy is important. This isn't a game where you shut your brain off but then again maybe you can on easy, I don't know.

Even though I enjoyed the first game I saw the negative reviews and thought the backwards slide in gameplay wouldn't be my thing but it was rather...fine. Not at all disruptive. I regret waiting so long to pick it up. The gameplay has been streamlined significantly and irritations such as percentage hit chance and encumbrance have been removed. Some things really do have to be removed at the alter of fun if you can't get the balance down right.

In the first game you control a party of four, but in Blackguards 2 you end up controlling a whole squad of various sizes due to the addition of mercenaries. For these extras you're essentially controlling nameless goons but at least there's background and a narrative reason as to why. There are many more enemies to fight at once now to make up for it and if you have absolutely zero patience, waiting for each enemy to perform their actions will drive you mad but it's not bad.

The story, as others have noted, isn't quite as good as Blackguards. Despite playing a named character with an easy to understand motivation for what they do, there's this closeness missing in 2 which the first game had between the whole cast. The returning characters aren't quite the same and their sudden inclusion was a bit head scratching. I mean I knew they were coming but it wasn't as organic as the first game.

There's a lot of choice for how you make the main character play and what they say during dialogue. Unfortunately the returning cast talk a bit less which furthers the odd feeling of them being out of place but when it works it's still extremely entertaining due to their chemistry with each other.

But just like the first game this experience is unpolished. For all the nice scenery there are plenty of uninspired locations. There's a pause before an action is performed which probably adds up to a significant amount of time. There are many spells but over half of them you can do without or have extremely niche uses.

If the devs had stuck to making what they know and not imploded due to *that* game (so common in the games industry these days!) I'd be hopeful that a Blackguards 3 could keep changing things up. Needs to run on a new engine though.

Games like this get me interested in the setting. Some people didn't get into Dungeons and Dragons though the tabletop and were first introduced to the expansive world thanks to games like Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights and Icewind Dale. I know that whoever owns the Dark Eye doesn't have that kind of money to throw around and studios have their own budgets but it would be nice for someone else to pick up the mantle of bringing more of this world to life.

I get it, there's better games out there and if you don't like the vibe and can't tolerate the smaller issues you'll bounce but it's a nice, serviceable, turn based strategy game to think about and kill some hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049452549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1707848456}
review:
Probably the best turn based battle game I have played, even though it is 8 years old now.  Includes RPG elements of character development and inventory management. It has a great dynamic of having 4 main heroes supported by a legion of expendable mercenaries that creates fast paced and very satisfying battles.

Every element of it is polished and fits together perfectly to produce a great game. Brilliant and extensive voice acting throughout supports a dark and interesting story with good characters (it really made me appreciate what a difference good voice acting makes). Excellent handcrafted battle scenarios. Graphics and animation are good. Music is good. Also has some really good unique mechanics and UI elements that I am surprised other games have not copied, because they are really good for turn based battles by creating a clutter free interface.

I just cannot understand how this got mixed reviews and not overwhelmingly positive. There is just no way you cannot recommend this if you like the genre. I have been playing games since 1982, and have become somewhat of a connoisseur of games, that is not easily pleased, and I particularly like turn based games and have played a lot. I can‚Äôt believe it took me 8 years to stumble across this.

A bargain at full asking price! I can‚Äôt believe the devs only want 8 pounds for this and knock it down by 90% during sales!

author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1706879565}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
Absolutely gorgeous game.
A must for fans of turn based tactical games and who also love the rpg elements of char development and inventory management.
The game delivers in fluff, content and story telling with strenght, the voice acting is very high level and the characters and the story itself are deep.
Once you got your initial squad and get a platoon of mercenaries (your cannon fodder) ready, the game turns into a campaign and then you get more of a macro strategy feel to it.
In sum , I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141765115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1697754490}
review:
Finally a dark tale with little good choices - I have never played BG1, but Cassia's story is told impressively and in beautiful sketches. Every now and then I would have liked more cutscenes and drawings, but that doesn't spoil the narrative. The main focus of the game is of course the battles, which were quite challenging for me.

Overall, I was very impressed by the story because towards the end it gets more complex than I expected. I liked playing a completely crazy and evil  person who even ends up taking the throne!

What bothers me: As a long-time player of The dark Eye, I noticed the all in all fairly good representation of the lore of Aventuria - with some exceptions:
Where are all the female soldiers? Looking at the (human) armies I noticed that all of the nameless NPCs are male. Of course there are some female fighters and heroes, but  definitely less than men. In the main game (a p&p tabletop rpg system) there is gender equality almost everywhere (almost!). 

Besides that I also would have loved to have more conversations with Mirai (and my companions) throughout the game which would have helped me to like them even more. 
Other than that I enjoyed the game very much.

review:
shallow revenge story with uninteresting characters and 0 player agency.

uninteresting tactical combat where gears have very little importance but character build is of the utmost importance (pick a wrong build and you cant finish the game even on easy). every fight is basically the same from the previous one, with the same obvious choices.

almost no strategy involved even though there's an illusion of choice on how you play the maps and how you handle interactibles. in the end it doesnt matter because you either deal with infinite AI reinforcement (which forces you to go straight to the objective and ignore the rest) or you have a set of turns to kill certain mobs before being overwhelmed.

presentation is top notch, though, with great art, very good voice over, very good ambience


i give this game 4/10, which makes a not recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561197992557240', 'num_games_owned': 679, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1690830626}
review:
Already knew what to expect after Blackguards 1. This is similar in all the bad ways: Unfair combat (don't know how else to describe it), endless reinforcements for enemies but not for you AND, the biggest killer of fun, nonexistent flexibility in battle. The last point makes character development, levelling up and buying new gear feel inconsequential.

Ending with PROS:
- Main character Cassia, only saved by good writing, as many people still would have preferred to make their own character as in the first game
- Good enough graphics, though admittedly not very impressive given how taxing the game is on hardware
- Price is okay, and is often on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198264221650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1690681163}
review:
Blackguards 2 is a direct sequel to the first game. However, the story is only remotely connected through the companions that join the new heroin on her quest for revenge. While the first game was your typical CRPG, the sequel tries to integrate conquest and troop management mechanic. Your main goal is to conquer cities and make decisions that will influence people around you. The game presents itself more like a Fallout Tactics, while giving you some freedom in your path of conquest. Expect 25'ish hours. 

However, the game mechanics have been extremely streamlined. Thusfar the main focus should be on experiencing the story. Don't check any walkthrough as it would spoil your enjoyment of the game. There is no "right way" to do it. You're dealing with fairly realistic human motivations. Every one has his goals/interests. It's up to you to make people rally your cause, by understanding what makes them tick.

A song of Ice and Fire/Game of Thrones fans might want to give it a try. Heck, for less than 5 bucks you can enjoy Blackguards 1 (+dlc) and Blackguards 2 when they're on sale. Worth every penny!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 1471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1471, 'last_played': 1664821703}
review:
Spielwertung: 7/10
Spieldauer: ca. 24.5 Stunden
Spieldurchl√§ufe: 1 (Ende)

Alles neu beim Nachfolger oder doch alles beim Alten? Warum Blackguards 2 ein fast v√∂llig neues Spiel ist, dass erstaunlich viel unver√§ndert l√§sst.

Die Story: Hier steht sie wirklich mal an der Spitze. Das Spiel ist deutlich linearer geschrieben als Teil 1. Die "Handlungsentscheidungen" sind Illusionen, ob gut oder b√∂se, beides f√ºhrt nach Mengbilla. Nebenquests wurden im Prinzip komplett abgeschafft! Wieso? Der 1. Teil h√§tte MEHR davon vertragen k√∂nnen, im 2. gibt es sie gar nicht mehr. Statt leerer 3 NPC-D√∂rfer gibt es jetzt nur noch 3, 4 St√§dte, in denen aber auch nix passiert. Immerhin d√ºrfen wir dort mit Bettler Riz ein paar Dialoge f√ºhren, ein paar nutzlose H√§ndler finden und uns pro oder contra Pl√ºndern entscheiden. Aber weshalb? Das Spiel gibt keinerlei R√ºckmeldungen, was das √ºberhaupt bedeutet. W√ºrden wir durch das Pl√ºndern +10, +100 Gold bekommen, h√§tte man etwas in der Hinterhand, so l√§sst sich nur erahnen, dass wir damit den "b√∂sen" Weg beschreiten (aber nur so wird die "nebenquest" erf√ºllt...)

Skillsystem: Weitestgehend √ºbernommen. Noch immer erhalten wir AP, die wir in viel zu viele Bereiche stopfen k√∂nnen. Man kann leider nie alles haben. Restlos gestrichen wurde das alte DSA-System von Weisheit, Geschicklichkeit, Kraft etc. Daf√ºr verteilt man jetzt feste Punkte in Ausdauer (neuer Wert), Lebens- oder Astralkraft usw. Immer feste Werte, egal ob schwacher Zauberer oder dicker K√§mpfer, alle kriegen f√ºr dieselben Kosten z.B. +10 Leben. Einerseits macht es die Sache einfacher, andererseits verliert das Skillsystem so seinen Reiz. Die Folgen: Zum Beispiel keinerlei Gewichtsgrenze + Malus mehr f√ºr Sachen. Wir k√∂nnen jetzt theoretisch 100 Waffen und R√ºstungen mit uns herumschleppen, es wird nie mehr was passieren...

Das Lager: Eine positive Neueinf√ºhrung. Dort finden sich Lehrer, die H√§ndlerin und alle wichtigen Charaktere ein. Die Dialogoptionen sind leider √§u√üerst bescheiden und schmal. 
Sehr schlecht wiederum: Es gibt kein Charisma mehr, aber trotzdem darf man in Dialogen zwischen "richtig" und "falsch" "raten". Ja, raten, denn meistens ergeben sich die "richtigen" Informationen nicht, auch nicht, haha, durch Ritz oder das Journal, indem man die "Personen" nachschlagen kann. Bei "richtigen" Antworten bekommt man dann z.B. Hinweise, bei falschen gar nichts. Eine 2. Chance? Die hei√üt Neuladen. Auch die 3 Spezis aus dem 1. Teil, Takate, Zubaran und Naurim k√∂nnen 3x "aufgewertet" werden, wenn man sie "richtig" anspricht. Auch das wird nirgends erkl√§rt oder angemessen verkauft. Es ist √§u√üerst schlecht gemacht. H√§ufiges Rumprobieren f√ºhrt automatisch zum Erfolg, zerst√∂rt aber jedwedes Rollenspielgef√ºhl. 

Die Reise: Im Prinzip sind wir noch immer auf derselben Karte, lassen dieses Mal aber weite Teile der K√ºste und des Nordens aus. Warum? Fragt die Entwickler, hier wurde viel Potential verschenkt. 

Die Spielzeit: Fast 10 Stunden weniger als Teil 1. Sicher, die Erfahrung/Routine spielt mit rein, wenn man Teil 2 direkt nach Teil 1 spielt und zu 90% sich sofort zurechtfindet, aber sehr viele Inhalte in Teil 2 sind pur optional und ich habe alles gemacht. Das Spiel h√§tte man viel schneller als in 24 Stunden durchspielen k√∂nnen. Ich habe allein stundenlang die ganzen Items studiert...

Items: Positiv: Es gibt mehr Vielfalt, mehr Sets, mehr einzigartige Sachen. Negativ: Die Sets sind fast immer zerstreut, so dass man meistens erst am Ende alle Teile zusammenhat. Beispiel: Ich bekomme nach einem Kampf 3 von 4 Setitems (???) 6 Stunden sp√§ter erhalte ich das fehlende 4. Ganz, ganz toll. Oder noch ein Beispiel: Ich finde 1 Item. 2 Items gibt es bei einem H√§ndler (2 Stunden sp√§ter) und die Teile 4 und 5 gibt es wieder nach einem Kampf (4 Stunden sp√§ter). Was soll dieser Mist? Dazu kommt, dass man nie mehr als 4 Charaktere hat, aber z.B. allein 4 gute Zauberer-Sets bekommen kann. Problem: Ihre Boni unterscheiden sich nur minimal. Schon das 1. Set ist somit im Grunde "Endgamecontent", der Rest ist nur "ich gebe dir einen Apfel und nehme dir eine Birne"-Stats. Dann entscheidet man konkret, ob man lieber 10% Crit oder Immunit√§t gegen Gifte (Stufe 3 ) haben will, w√§hrend alles andere quasi gleich ist. Cassia, unsere Heldin, hat zudem von Beginn an ein "Set", das so gut ist, dass man es im Grunde nie austauschen muss. Nat√ºrlich findet man gute Alternativen, aber die Boni des Helmes und des Sets lassen im Grunde lange keinerlei Austausch zu. 

In diesen Beschreibungen ist schwer zu vermitteln, wie frustrierend all das ist, wenn man es mit Games vergleicht, die einen konstanten Fortschritt erm√∂glichen (Baldurs Gate z.B.) 

Kleinigkeiten, die aber auffallen: Im 1. Teil, klassische Regel: Wenn ein Zauberer nah an einem Gegner steht, misslingen die Zauber h√§ufig. Im 2. Teil: Nope. Wenn ein Fernk√§mpfer nah an Gegnern steht, dasselbe. Im 2. Teil: Nope. Weder meine Sch√ºtzin l√§sst sich davon beirren, dass 4 Nahk√§mpfer-Feinde um sie herum stehen, noch k√ºmmern sich gegnerische Sch√ºtzen um meine Melees. Geil! (Sarkasmus).

Schwierigkeitsgrad: Bis auf den Endboss, bei dem man einfach den Heilstein und den Versteinerer beachten muss, war das Spiel auf "normal" nur die ersten Stationen "knackig". Ab der H√§lfte des Spiels machte es sich dann bezahlt, dass wir jede Festung befreit/erobert haben. Dank zahlreicher Boni f√ºr die Hilfstruppen und gleichzeitig genug AP, wurden s√§mtliche K√§mpfe ab da eher ein Spaziergang. Trotzdem hat es stets Spa√ü gemacht, auch wenn der Widerstand eher schmal war. 
Beim Endkampf frage ich mich, ob dieser vielleicht bugged war? Ich wollte Marwan nicht t√∂ten, habe ihn 20 Runden am Leben gelassen, er ist st√§ndig nur dumm rumgerannt, aber als ich endlich alle Gegner get√∂tet hatte, blieb nur noch er √ºbrig. Faramud (Gegner) und Naurim (Zwerg) waren versteinert/gel√§hmt und konnten trotz Magie bannen Stufe 4 (ALLE) nicht befreit werden. Also musste ich Marwan t√∂ten. 
Manchmal haben mich auch die Siegbedingungen genervt: Bei der Belagerung von Mengbilla gibt es die Mission, bei der man Steinschleudern gegen die Stadt richten soll. Bereits 2 von 6 Zielen erlauben den "Sieg", aber ich wollte 6/6. Als ich bei 5/6 stand und schon eine Idee hatte, wo Ziel 6 liegen w√ºrde, habe ich den letzten Gegner get√∂tet. Obwohl niemand meiner Leute in der "Fluchtzone" stand, war der Kampf danach automatisch vorbei. Wahrscheinlich h√§tte es nichts ge√§ndert, aber trotzdem.

Kamera: noch immer nicht drehbar. So schade. Das Ver√§ndern der H√∂he hilft, aber ein 360 Grad Schlachtfeld w√§re deutlich besser. Aber daran scheitert es nicht, ich sag es nur. 

Dialoge/Vertonung: Dieselben wie in Teil 1. Durch allgemeinen Mangel an Nebenquests aber eher wenige Stimmen. Ganz ehrlich, die Dialoge schwanken extrem. Manchmal fangen sie die Stimmung gut ein, dann wieder glaubt man, dass die Schreiber v√∂llig drauf waren. Da werden zusammenhanglose Oneliner gebracht, dass man irgendwann nur noch wegklicken will. Das alles soll dazu dienen die Hauptcharaktere zu "formen", wirkt aber eher wie "schreib schnell in 10 Minuten was auf √ºber nen Zwerg, nen Zauberer und nen Pseudo-Amazonas-Indigenen. Ach ja, und vergiss die Verr√ºckte und den S√∂ldner/Prophet/Irren nicht". Als ob ALLE aus der Klapse entkommen w√§ren und kein einziger Charakter "normal" reden k√∂nnte. 

Fazit: Das Spiel ist gef√§llig. Es macht Spa√ü. Es wei√ü zu unterhalten. Und doch war ich am Ende froh, dass es endlich vorbei war und hatte keine Lust mehr, den Endkampf noch mal neu zu versuchen, vielleicht ein anderes Ende zu sehen oder geschweige denn das gesamte Spiel noch mal neu aufzurollen. Ich werde Blackguards in den Giftschrank sperren und den Schl√ºssel wegwerfen. Das Spiel versucht etwas Gr√∂√üeres zu sein als es leisten kann. Es ist kein episches Universum, kein phantastisches Abenteuer, kein legend√§res Rollenspiel. Es ist St√ºckwerk, das im Ansatz toll mith√§lt, aber leider st√§ndig √ºber seine Fu√üspitzen stolpert. Bravo f√ºr den Versuch, schade f√ºr das Ergebnis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058459688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 1808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1808, 'last_played': 1661647377}
review:
[h1]Gameplay: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 6/10[/h1]

‚úîÔ∏è Rather deep character build customisation.
‚úîÔ∏è Simple but enjoyable interactive environments in combat.
‚úîÔ∏è The most obscure parts of character building and equipment from the first game got cleaned up and are easier to understand.
‚úîÔ∏è The game still benefits from a full voiceover.
‚úîÔ∏è Being able to alter your team composition through the use of mercenaries is a pretty fun addition to the first game.
‚úîÔ∏è The addition of endurance as a resource for special physical attacks is a nice way to prevent the physical fighters from just spamming their most powerful skills repeatedly.

üí≠ The graphics are still cheap and efficient, but not particularly pretty.

‚ùå The narration is a bit weird due to the game reusing quite a few characters and places from the first opus, which leads to them being introduced in a rather artificial manner. Needing to level up all of them again almost from zero feels weird, and their personalities got a bit altered between the first game and this one (though this part might be put on the account of the passage of time). Overall the game feels like it struggles to adhere to the same kind of tone and narrative direction as the first one did, and doesn't seem to find its own identity either because of how much it tries to build up on the first one.
‚ùå The defense missions feel a bit like fillers, artificially extending the game length - they don't bring you any rewards and take place on maps you've already played through.
‚ùå The core combat mechanics still make the game a bit slow and repetitive. Like in the first game, the environmental interactions help to counteract that, but it's definitely not a game I can do long sessions of because of how samey all the turns end up becoming.
‚ùå The game still has some clarity issues as to the combat controls and interactions. Typically, it might be a bit difficult to target an object in particular, especially since several objects can be on a single cell. In general, the UX of the game leaves a lot to be desired.

Overall I found the game interesting but not very thrilling to play through. I would recommend it to fans of turn-based tactical RPGs who would want to play another game because they've already played through their favorite games 5 or 6 times (I mean, it's very cheap, especially when on sale, you could as well give it a shot), but I wouldn't recommend it as a first journey into the genre. 

If you liked the first Blackguards, you probably will enjoy this one as well, even though you might find the narrative tone a bit off as compared to the first game. If you didn't play the first Blackguards and you care for an RPG's story, I'd recommend you to try the first game first, since the second down is weaker narratively in my opinion.

This is one of the many times when I blame Steam for not offering more flexibility in its rating system, because I can't decently recommend this game to most people, but I also kinda had fun playing it, so I guess it's a positive recommendation...

author: {'steamid': '76561198016886767', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1548814433}
review:
Great Story.
Enjoyable combat.
Now excuse my poor memory, I think I played this 4 or 5 years ago. 
Now, when I saw the main protag was a women, I initially had sirens going off. Because so far, more often than not, "powerful" women are basically just female dogs in behavior and charisma.
Thankfully I was wrong. Cassia (protag) was very interesting and even the highlight of the game. Probably my top 5 of favorite characters.  I dont remember exactly why, but the VA did a good job, she definitely has charisma without trying to appeal to horny 14 year olds. 

Now I said enjoyable combat. I mean it's decent enough that it does not hinder the main appeal, the story.

Keep in mind, I hate turn based combat if only for the fact that I have to watch each enemy do an animation to turn around, to move, to wait, and then to attack. I quite divinity original sin half way because I could not bear watching 16 spiders do the same shit over and over with no skip button. 

I never got to finish this story because I played the 1st game (also enjoyable) right before this one. So I probably overdosed on my own pet peeve. It will absolutely grate on your spirit watching the mass amount of enemies do very predicable things over and over and over again.

Now as I said, I havent played this game in years. I've read the other reviews complaining about bugs and such. I dont really remember any that outright angered me or hampered my experience. 
is it worth 10 dollars? Maybe, I got both games for real cheap though so.

review: It looks as bad as the first one. I didn't like the first one.  As I had the second one in my game library, I tried it after being disappointed with the first one. I see there is no improvement in this game. This game's general atmosphere and gameplay doesn't feel like it takes itself serious. This series tries to act as if it has dark atmosphere but despite all the efforts it is not. It feels like a bad TV movie that you find while changing channels. It feels so bland that you don't even want to watch longer and only thing comes to your mind, what were all these people thinking while they were making such a low quality product? As I said for the first one, no matter how cheap it gets, don't by this. As they have continued their low quality in the second one, it feels like it became a habit for this game, don't support it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198248408328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1031, 'last_played': 1633290438}
review:
First things first: Compared to its predecessor, 'Blackguards 2' is the much better game. It simplified many of the systems, reduced the number of skills and talents, so you can just decide on a general direction, you want to push the members of the party into. The main party members are also the important characters in the story, revolving around protagonist Cassia, who is already a much more compelling character over the one from the previous game by the sheer virtue of having a personality, motivation and clear goals. Her struggle to regain the life, that has been taken from her, the constant fight for her own sanity, the decision between bad and worse, all these are compelling. She might not be the most complex character in fantasy fiction by a longshot, but Cassia manages to have a consistent arc and provide a proper way to play her, The decisons are somewhat pre-selected by her rational, her own sense of right and wrong, her goals, and then presented to the player to interpret these elements of her character. Any decision makes sense for her in one way or another. Playing her role is easy, because she is a defined character (yes, I'm emphasizing that part). As a videogame, this is the most important part: The game allows agency in interpreting the main character, but ties her into the world and gives her a character with trait (and so on) to build off of. Much improved over the avatar-approach to the protagonist from the previous tale.
Besides that, the game flows pretty naturally with only a few hiccups along the way. Some fights are plainly unpleasant in design, mashing random criticals (which occur way too much) with time pressure, endless enemy spawns, these enemies all healing back to full at the end of a combat round and enemy mobility being crazy - just as one example. The skirmishes are better, due to having a few spare party members in the form of (replacable) mercenaries, and simplfied, to make them more readable and go by faster. They still take forever though getting boring, when you're going through the motions, knowing the battle is oer, but you need to manualy kill all the enemies on the field. 
As a whole, the game works itself out of these valleys pretty well and provides a simple to follow story, offering some moral complexity and a poetic ending, no matter which specific permutation one chooses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001383780', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1640087604}
review:
Sadly i have to give this game the thumbs down.
If you came here looking for a nice game following the system and playstile of Blackguards 1, this is not it. You WILL be disapointed. Let me give you a few + and - for this game.

+:
- Decisions Matter (killing certain people will prevent future events/encounters, letting people live may modify encounter and so on)
- Blackguard Lore and Universe (Storywise it "feels" like Blackguard 1, but thats about it)
- Story is good and every single Textline is voiced (very well done)

and thats sadly it..now for the negative

-:
- System got super simplified (no more weightlimit, no more roll if a spell succeeds..nothing, full heal after each battle, and so on)
- you get a ALL-Teacher right from the beginning...no scaling, nothing. you can learn everything right from the start. very boring
- no attributes, no stat-scaling (bc of missing attributes). its just talents, skills and passives
- no customizable avatar/MC
- Battling is super easy and is no challenge (in addition to your 4 Heros you get mercenary, which are disposable junk...literally...let them run in and die...0 consequences)
- the lenght...oh boy...the lenght of the game. its short...and i mean it...like super short. Maybe 10h if you clear EVERYTHING and make 1 playthrough. thats not even the lenghts of chapter 3 of the first Blackguardsgame
- you can see a gigantic map, but the whole game is just on the lower third of said map. maybe the publisher planed for some DLCs, but ultimatly stopped all development and release because the game flopped

All in all, if its heavly discounted you could grab it...but this game is a disgrace compared to the Blackguards 1

author: {'steamid': '76561198057814844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3032, 'last_played': 1639415374}
review:
The Good:  Character building and battles are fun. Has that old turn based RPG goodness. Characters start weak but can become pretty powerful as you invest in them.  This can take some pre-planning and dabbling.  Just hard enough to make you really think about positioning and builds.

The Not So Good:  Objectives in battle aren't given so you really have to guess as to what to do.  Having to look up objectives or key strategies is not fun.  Some skills are absolutely critical to win.

The Really Awful:  Game bugs prevent winning some fights.  It's really not fun spending hours completing a battle only for the game to hit a bug and not continue.  

Conclusion:  This is a fun game but I just can't recommend it.  The amount of time sunk into this game only to hit walls in game code is frustrating.  I would have rather just not started.

review: This is a great game! I absolutely love Blackguards, actually liked the first game better but I'll take as many Blackguards as they put out there.  I wish there were more of them. The story line is well done, the characters have very distinctive traits and personalities, the voicing is excellent. The strategy is challenging, trying to figure out what skills will benefit me in the long run is a bit difficult but certainly doable. There are many to choose from. Only problem I really had was trying to obtain sufficient gold to purchase all the items I wanted, haven't figured out how to do that yet. I highly recommend Blackguards 1,2 and the dlc. and you can grab the whole franchise for less than 3 bucks on sale. Can't beat this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972888061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2221, 'last_played': 1635221822}
review:
I felt like playing a turn based strategy, and despite the gripes in half the reviews figured I'd give this a shot.  I never played the first one.  I was pretty entertained.  The voice work is good.  I never ran into any game breaking bugs like some people complain about.  I never used a guide, and completed it fine.  

If I had any gripe it would be that there's so much going on and only 4 characters.  The characters are relatively predetermined as to their weapon set, but the game supplies you with a bunch of options.  I don't see why I would ever use swords, for example.  Or traps.  It's an option though, which I guess if nothing else adds to replay-ability. 

The story is compelling, and I didn't find it particularly difficult.  If you're looking for a turn based RPG that has a normal play time to complete (around 40 hours) then give this a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029587500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1629689215}
review:
although there was a time when this game would have been fine... that time is past.  The game suffers from several faults:

1. it is slow:  combat is real slow, and restarting several times in the beginning is necessary for you to get the feel of how it works.
2. combat is also cramped.  I think the developers were choke point happy with this one.  Every map I have played so has been a real challenge to allow me to actually use my fighters.  line-of-sight is really big in this game.  That means your archers and mages in the back, can't do anything because they cannot shoot over or though your front lines to hit the enemy.  All you can do is either rush your front line to make room, or hit skip turn on the back lines.  Lots of wasted fire power.
3. level up is super slow in the beginning (read first 10 hours or more of play).

These things prevent me from enjoying the game like I think I should.  So I cannot recommend, even if it is only a dollar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032309978', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1785, 'last_played': 1619723339}
review:
I was a bit on the fence about this but I guess it deserves a thumbs up.
I'd say it's a shaky 7/10.

The game has a pretty good, if mostly, straight forward story.
The combat is fun with a lot of different abilities to choose from, (although a couple of them are pretty powerful and you really need them) but half of the time I was a bit confused about the objectives in each battle.
They should really have put a lot more time in to explaining what you were supposed to do (and why) in each battle. This led to me having to restart a lot of fights (which luckily you can do quite easily) after a couple of rounds, because I suddenly had a light bulb moment or it turned out that what I thought I was supposed to do was completely wrong.
Also, you can only view the battlefield from up above or from a fixed angle (you can zoom, though), which was really annoying at first and a little bit less annoying later on.

In between the combat you find yourself in camp or in towns. 
There you can talk to your companions and you will be presented with a lot of choices about people that you really never got enough information about. A standard dilemma could go like this:
-Should I kill this one?
-He is pretty evil.
-But if i kill him, will I be evil?
All the while I was thinking to myself; well I don't even know the bugger. What has he done apart from throwing fireballs at me from a platform? Hmm ... he looks and sounds pretty much like a villain ... I guess it's thumbs down for you, whoever you are. 
So, pretty much like a real ruler, I guess.

There are a lot of weapons and armor in this game and a complete set will give you bonuses. I may very well be wrong here, but it seems it's impossible to complete a lot of the sets. Seeing as they are really expensive, thats just plain evil. In the end, I just saved my money and played with the ones I got, which was fine playing on normal, but kind of made that part of the game pointless. (it may very well be that the drops are random though, so another playthrough could have seen me getting different armors, in which case I guess it's OK)
 
In the end I would say a lot of the game is like this; you press one thing, expecting one of two outcomes and end up thinking; what? Why? Oh well ...

The voice acting is good, the music atmospheric and the art is top notch in my opinion.
 
All in all, I think it deserves a thumbs up and I would buy a sequel.
It just seems to me that it could have been a lot better with just a few minor, (and probably inexpensive) tweeks.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980371475', 'num_games_owned': 2410, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 869, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1617501732}
review:
Blackguards 2 is the follow up to the first The Dark Eye computer RPG in many years. Those who haven't played the first game will be able to enjoy this one, but a great deal of the backstory will be lost as almost all the main characters are returning from the first game. But this game is far less traditional RPG than the first. You won't be traveling the world completing quests and collecting loot. Instead you will be leading an army of mercenaries called The Silent Legion as you attempt to wrest control of the city of Mengbilla from its current ruler. 

As such, the concept of dungeons from the first game is gone. Every map point is a location to conquer. Doing so rewards you both with new gear and XP for your named characters, as well as improved abilities for your army. That army is represented in battle as nameless, faceless grunts. How many of these grunts are present in battle is decided by the game. Their loyalty is unquestioning (for story reasons), so you never have to worry about either losing too many mercenaries or losing their loyalty. 

But overall Blackguards 2 is a strategy game. The tactical battles remain nearly identical to the first game, the only notable addition being a crouch behind cover button. But your strategies will have changed as you now have numerous foot soldiers happy to die for the cause. They serve as effective meat shields, although the fact that wounds are now healed and mana replenished after every fight means even your named characters need behave less defensively. 

This might all sound like a downgrade from the first game, and in some ways this title is less punishing. It also does away with the traditional character attributes from the table top title, and a new skill for mages that allows them to wear metallic armor without reprecussion means that you can now create a battle mage that uses heavy plate armor, wields a 2-handed sword, fires flaming arrows with deadly precision, and still perform 3 or 4 spells masterfully. Main character Cassia receives enough XP by the end of the game to max out the entire talents and special talents tree, while mastering two or three weapons and three or four spells, depending on how many melee and ranged abilities you wish to give her. 

The entire character system here is more freeform, eventually leaving you with four godly heroes by the end of the game who can stand their own against some truly formidable foes. But, again, that fits with the story, as these four heroes are inspiring an entire army of rank and file soldiers. Meanwhile, you also have to contend with a new system that allows you to interrogate prisoners. I'll openly admit to failing every single one of these interrogations so I cannot actually tell you what you get for succeeding. You also occasionally have to defend the territory you have conquered from counter attacks, and in these battles you get to turn the tables a bit and place traps for your enemies, while you place troops throughout the map to defend a central point. These battles are some of the most fun of the game, and offer a good change of pace compared to most normal fights which see you on the offensive. 

So do all of these changes make for a better game? That's hard to say. It is certainly a more systemic one, with less linearity and far more freedom in both character development and story progress. There is also a lot more variability in the ending, with both good and bad options for your lead character as well as a variety of potential options for your three other heroes. That makes the game fairly replayable, a good thing considering it took me under 15 hours to beat it, compared to around 30 for the original. Is a shorter, more freeform approach better? Really it is a matter of preference. This really feels like a very different game from the first, despite featuring the same world, same characters, and same battle system. I personally really liked the new format, but if you are looking for the traditional RPG experience, you won't find it here.

The first Blackguards was really a shock; too much to take in, a jack-of-all-trades, lacking in every aspect it tried to master, something you'd love and hate all at once. The second Blackguards has stuck to the formula, tried to fix some things but fell flat in other aspects. The Drakensang hommage is still here; however, the game is NOT an improvement of the first game, I actually find this latter to be much better in some aspects. Blackguards 2 follows the story of Cassia, the Kyrios' wife who starts off by finding herself in the bottom of the Gladiators' Arena in Mengbilla. The reason why she is there is never fully explained (it is just alluded to the fact that she refused to follow some of Marwan's orders, her husband and the first Kyrios of Mengbilla). After getting bitten in the catacombs of the city by a Corapia spider, a growth starts forming in her face, making her ugly, ruthless and mad... She decides to overthrow Marwan and take control of Mengbilla and rule as its first Kyria. Now you can either choose to "contain" the Corapia Venom that's making her mad, OR you can give in to it and butcher every city you come across (and you bet there are endings involved with whatever choices you make). There are a number of things involved in her fate, however; one of the most important being her own sister, Mirai. Cassia Corapia proceeds to find allies in her quest when she escapes the dungeon, in the form of characters from the first game that I personally was never fond of: Zurbaran, the overconfident mage, Naurim, the treacherous dwarf, Takate, who was the only person I found interesting because, although he was strong and ruthless, had a soft spot for animals and a new face, Farmund, the vile mercenaries' leader out for blood. Now why would they bring back this awful cast for an encore is beyond me, but Cassia Corapia was a fascinating character overall! The same formula from the first game applies here, you can build your character any which way you like and instead of attributes and the huge character development tree, you get an encompassed version of that now that is easily accessible (even for noob casuals like myself). This tactical RPG also does a great job at portraying events and characters' story arcs as they progress; you can make Zurbaran evil, or get him to finally give up the overconfident a-hole act and settle down (you can also get him executed and it's quite fun to do that lol), you can do the same for Naurim... but Takate... he's got an interesting character development if you decide to follow through with it. I'll admit it was quite fun making that big gladiator man who kills for pleasure into a caring father-figure for a voiceless girl. Anyways, gameplay-wise, this is the ultimate Tactical RPG experience, with great difficulty spikes that will keep you on your toes. The creatures of this world are quite diverse, with the addition of "created chimeras", ugly, nightmarish creatures made by a bunch of crazed wizards; however, I really REALLY dislike how this second Blackguards omits all SIDE QUESTING and makes the map into a Conquest Mode. I will explain: you visit some cities, plunder them and then move unto the next in a Conquest Map with cutscenes occuring only when it's absolutly necessary (and they really don't do much to elaborate on the storyline). 

Although the devs have done a great job to code achievements to unlock at the right times; you can tell that the game was kind of bare. No SIDE QUESTING meant that you can finish your playthrough in a matter of hours and the lack of content hasn't helped this game one bit. The CONQUEST map makes the narrative worse and building your characters, although now easier, leaves so much to be desired. I loved the game though simply because it leaves room for some very special character developments and a choice-oriented narrative that is different with every little mundane choice you make. If they ever make a third game, I hope they go back to the way Blackguards 1 was and just try to better code the game for all Achievement Hunters out there to enjoy. It's a 6/10 tribute to Drakensang with an amazing voice acting, easily accessible skilltrees and an average storyline with a very bland character cast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198422199704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 431, 'playtime_forever': 981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 981, 'last_played': 1614589128}
review:
Blackguard 2 is the same Hexagon tiled SLG like the 1st series. Blackguard 1 is more like an experiment ground for the dev on combining a Pen & Paper rules on a SLG (Tactic) game, which ended up pretty messy and a lot are unfixed up to nowadays. Blackguard 2 improves a lot of the flaws in Blackguard 1 making this sequel more to the normal SLG games we get out there with actual conquering and such... but, they didn't go all out on the change, so it still felt unpolished and just like Blackguard 1, they sucks at doing branching causing a lot of mess and "weirdness" depending on the action and route you choose. By far, this is an enjoyable game if you like tactical battles. But like Blackguard 1, this is no where near a good game, at most only getting an average score. With the SLG hate/love thing, the mixed review is unavoidable.

The game has a decent story to tell... but the story teller sucks... all the nice narrations and voice over are wasted by the layout of the story telling (which is a mess).. if there's no voice, player might even just skip the story and get on with the battle. Yes, it's that bad.

My reason for giving this a thumb down is fairly simple... unnecessary cruelty to cat at the very beginning of the game just earned this game a thumbs down. There's no need for such act at all, and promoting such things is good enough reason to get a bad review. Think twice next time you guys plan a story. Both B1 and B2 are extremely under polished and unprofessionally done but still within tolerance level. But doing "extra" stupid stuff to anger your player base is just pushing the scale to tilt over to a bad review.

review:
The game is beautiful. The soundtrack fits the atmosphere and the battles. I found the combat to be very smooth. I like TBS because it gives me time to plan, and this game has wonderful set pieces in which the battles take place.
The ending is what you make it to be so you only have yourself to congratulate or blame. There is definite replay value since missions, side quests, interrogations can all be done in different ways. The final battle can be done in different ways. While I am happy with the ending that I got, I know I will be going back for a darker story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026525250', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1514, 'last_played': 1612029409}
review:
This game had the potential to be really good. There is a good game buried underneath it.

Mechanically, I really enjoy it. It's a simplified version of the first game, which I think is a good thing. The tactical combat feels good, character advancement feels good, the story is good, the consolidated tutors and whole camp mechanic feel good. The added mercenaries are good. There is so much good!

And then it all falls apart, as you get deeper into the game, because of level design. I appreciate their attempt to make more interesting encounters by having different objectives and such. But, at some point, you go from "interesting" to "frustrating". Some of the levels are nearly impossible to sight-read, because there are hidden mechanics and triggers you can't see. Playing a level twice just because the mechanic is hidden is NOT fun. Some levels have infinitely (or seemingly infinite, as I didn't wait around forever) spawning enemies, which isn't fun for anyone with defensive builds and strategy, either. If you want to win, you have to play fast and hard, not slow and steady.

And then there is the final fight, the worst of them all, in my opinion. The concept is very cool: there's a monster that you need to bait into attacking a certain NPC who runs around. Except there's no good way to do this, for some party setups. If the monster attacks one of your party members, you have to do a lot of damage in one hit to save them. And if your only source of that much damage at once is melee, then that character is now the new target. You need hard-hitting, sustainable, ranged DPS to do this. Also, you might not have your full party at that point, so if that character is now gone...you're still boned. It's an absolute brick wall for some setups. And since it's the very last fight of the game, it's not like you can quickly restart with a different comp and try again.

There is the core of a good game here, unfortunately it doesn't live up to its potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974493059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 6564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6564, 'last_played': 1610737963}
review:
A fun turn based CRPG that actually has an interesting back story. Battles can be won in many ways and terrain can be used as cover or can be moved or destroyed. Combat is fun and some battles can be quite challenging at higher difficultly levels. 

Graphics - 5/10 (not terrible, but not great either, but you don't play these games for great graphics)
Sound - 9/10 (good voice overs for a lot of the dialogue)
Story - 9/10 (good story with different endings for good or evil paths through the game)
Combat - 9/10 (well done overall with terrain interaction / destruction)
Character Progression System - 7/10 (good progression system, a few OP and a good number of worthless skills / spells are why it doesn't get a higher score)

Overall Score - 8/10, Recommended, especially for anyone who enjoys good turn based combat with a good back story. 

Check my guide on this game for information on weapons, armor, and items available in the game.

review: I played it and beat it. I love rpgs, but this game was not very good. The story was original and probably the only reason i bothered finishing it. However the story doesn't mean much if your game is so bugged that you can't win the final battle by in one of the two presented ways in order to save a story-important npc. Also, numerous times I had to reload an earlier save because this game would bug out and not end battles sometimes when all objectives have been met. It did this to me after the most frustrating battle in the game. Unlike other games, this game doesn't allow you to save during battle or at certain other times. I get that they want to cut down on save-scumming and keep it challenging, but it isn't "challenging" when I beat their most annoying fight and the game glitches, forcing me to reload the whole thing instead of going to an earlier point. Also I think it's crappy that you can only equip items at camp. sometimes there are 3 stage fights and you might get a cool weapon, but you have to wait two more fights to equip it. The worst gaming experience I have had since I got my gaming laptop and started actually using my steam account.

review:
I really enjoyed the first Blackguards.  I'm giving up on this one.

Too many secret triggers, like when you have to move to stop the infinite flow of enemies.  Some all-or-nothing moments where you need to have just the right build.  The first one had a few things like this, but this one is worse.  The battles tend to be bigger and take longer, which is great, except for the part where it's hard to tell which hexes are poison and which aren't... so you can totally screw yourself near the end of a really long battle when you step in something you didn't see.

It's not terrible.  If it were the only game in my Steam backlog I might keep beating my head against it, but I reached my frustration limit and am moving on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084642319', 'num_games_owned': 1456, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1604981955}
review: Blackguards 2 is a huge improvement over the 1st game I hated the first one so I figured I'd hate this one as well but turns out this one's actually ok and I would recommend on sale for cheap. The first game had a lot of problems such as spells having a chance to fail EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU USED THEM so you could simple lose a battle from that (because failing a aoe spell or a heal could very much mean life or death and you have a VERY HIGH chance to fail) however in this game they removed that which for me is a huge plus, they also brought in "mercs" you can control allowing you to bypass the first games problem of only having a few party member which made fights pretty hard considering you were fighting 4 vs usually at least double that. The game still has problems and is easy to mess up making you have to re-fight an entire battle because you weren't aware you had to block a lever the first time you went in but the game is significantly better than the first one I feel, and you don't need to play the first to know what's going on in the 2nd so I would recommend personally skipping 1 and just playing 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006493602', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1593713260}
review:
There is nothing left, but the skills of DSA (read: The Dark Eye) - all the good stuff...gone!

It's now a diablo-clone in terms of character-building, where you click them blindly and will get the best out of it; heck your party doesn't even matter anymore....thanks to cannonfodder.
Story-trigger progress nicely, thanks to certain areas, that need to be conquered and one false step and you might end up in a terrific battle, that is not meant to be triggered yet :>
Good ol' bugs are back in town - I have both games' boxed edition as well and thought, that at some day it will get patched.

BG1 was way more enjoyable....as is Drakensang and even Battle Isle:Phase IV Incubation (brutal game!)

...and then I saw a console gameplay and everything became obvious.

If you expect something near DSA roleplaying...you shall not!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119272484', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1592680057}
review:
[h1]Premessa[/h1]
Sequel del poco accattivante Blackguard, questo titolo sempre sviluppato da Daedalic Entertainment e basato sul gioco di ruolo da tavolo tedesco ‚ÄúThe Dark Eye‚Äù, riprende le basi dal predecessore migliorandole e snellendole ed aggiungendo meccaniche nuove ed un comparto narrativo meglio studiato ed integrato.
[h1]Storia[/h1]
Il gioco √® ambientato pochi anni dopo gli eventi del primo. Impersoneremo Cassia, principessa tradita ed imprigionata per 4 lunghi anni, la quale ora unico scopo √® vendicarsi e regnare su tutta Mengbilla. Per farlo deve muovere guerra e necessita di una sorta di generali, che andr√† cercando e si riveleranno i protagonisti del titolo precedente. La lunga durata della prigionia e isolamento hanno delineato un personaggio lontano dai soliti clich√©. La protagonista infatti √® in bilico tra la razionalit√† e la follia, cosa notabile dai dialoghi che a volte intraprende con se stessa, ci√≤ non solo per la lunga prigionia ma anche per il veleno di un ragno che l‚Äôha pure sfregiata in volto e la costringe a portare una maschera. Alcuni personaggi, essendo ripresi dal precedente titolo hanno possibilit√† di essere approfonditi e risultano adesso pi√π completi. I restanti npc invece seppur non altrettanto approfonditi sono ben caratterizzati. La trama √® lineare e semplice ma risulta pi√π interessante della precedente anche grazie ad una migliore scrittura dei dialoghi. L‚Äôintera ambientazione anche qui, riprende quelle tetre e dark-fantasy di ‚ÄúThe Dark eye‚Äù.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Come nel precedente, anche in questo capitolo vi sono griglie esagonali a delineare le mappe, che sono pi√π ampie, variegate e meglio strutturate rispetto al precedente, con ancora la possibilit√† di interagire con l‚Äôambiente. Tutte le finestre per abilit√†, capacit√† e magie sono state migliorate e rese pi√π semplici e comprensibili. Ampliato anche l‚Äôequipaggiamento e le armi disponibili e livellata a dovere questa volta la difficolt√†, che non risulta pi√π frustrante come nel precedente capitolo. Anche qui non ci si pu√≤ spostare liberamente ed in ogni luogo, in una schermata statica, potremo interagire con i personaggi per fare acquisti, riposare o intraprendere secondarie. anche qui vi sar√† la possibilit√† di scegliere le risposte ma a differenza del capitolo precedente qui le decisioni hanno un peso effettivo sulla trama e sui personaggi, rendendo pi√π dinamica la trama e le varie quest. In aggiunta alle migliorie apportate alle meccaniche gi√† presenti nel capitolo precedente, vi sar√† la gestione della world map, in una semplificata campagna di guerra che prevede l‚Äôespansione del regno di Cassia attraverso la conquista delle varie citt√† e dalla difesa delle citt√† gi√† in nostro possesso. In molte occasioni avremo la possibilit√† di scegliere chi e come schierare truppe e personaggi.
[h1]Comparto Tecnico[/h1]
Il comparto grafico seppur migliorato molto con modelli e particellari pi√π definiti e complessi, lo stesso non lo si puo dire delle texture, che seppur migliori non sono ottimali. Nel complesso per√≤ il colpo d‚Äôocchio non √® male permettendo di godere del gioco senza troppi fastidi visivi. La colonna sonora √® pi√π incisiva, complice una trama e dialoghi pi√π accattivanti.
[h1]Conclusione[/h1]
Un sequel rilasciato solo un anno dopo il primo capitolo. Un tempo non troppo lungo ma abbastanza per il piccolo team di Daedalic per portare non poche migliorie su tutti i fronti, da una narrazione notevolmente migliore ad un gameplay pi√π pulito, meno frustrante e con alcune innovazioni interessanti. Le scelte di dialogo finalmente hanno senso modificando gli avvenimenti della trama e la realizzazione tecnica ed il design sono anch'essi notevolmente migliorati. Uno strategico a turni solido che non fa gridare al miracolo ma che merita di essere giocato.
[h1]Voto[/h1]
[b]74/100[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198008091739', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1478, 'last_played': 1590939644}
review:
Blackguards 2 is a turn-based, party-based game. The main character (Cassia) is joined by the three remaining members from BG1. The skill system from BG1 is mostly still in place, though it has been simplified quite a bit. The major changes from BG1 include the existence of a larger army to command (beyond the four members in your primary party) and the existence of defensive battles.

Pros:
[list]
[*] I enjoyed most of the hand-crafted battles. They provided a nice diversity of objectives, beyond just killing everything. Boss fights were suitably challenging and diverse.
[*] As with BG1, I enjoyed the level-up system.
[*] Story was OK.
[*] Lots of reviewers complained about the difficulty, though perhaps these comments were made under an old patch or something. I played on normal and found the difficulty perfect. Challenging enough to warrant a retry on a few boards without becoming tedious. It is noted that I did do some light recon prior to my playthrough and trained Takate as an archer, which made a great many levels much easier than they would have been otherwise.
[*] You can easily get this on sale for $2.
[/list]

YMMV:
[list]
[*] The addition of troops beyond your primary party is a bit of mixed-bag. The unique troops were cool and diverse. The general troops (swordsman, archer, pikeman) were OK too. However, the presence of these meatbags and the abundance of ranged/spell options rendered melee/tank heroes somewhat useless. This was a major shift from BG1 and went a bit far IMO.
[*] Items were a bit underwhelming and didn't really drive any interesting decisions.
[*] I always love the ability to choose which I fight I need do next in many game genres. This game appears to have that in play, in choosing which city to conquer next. Each city also includes which bonus your army will receive upon victory. In practice however, it rarely makes sense to do anything but attack the next easiest battle.
[*] As compared to BG1, spells always hit now. Though it was kind of frustrating to miss a spell in BG1, I appreciated the ROI I got from leveling up spell. This change certainly makes spells stronger in this game.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] After a set number of offensive fights (I think every three), you must defend one of the cities you have captured. These battles were typically very easy, very lengthy, and resulted in no experience or items for your main party. These were kinda sorta neat idea in concept, but by the end I dreaded triggering these. Game would be better off w/o these I think.
[*] Freeze spell is OP. I intentionally restricted myself in only giving this spell to one of my mages, as many fights could otherwise be won in two turns by simply nuking everything on the board four times.
[*] The decisions required post-boss victory are weird and don't fit with the rest of the game. This is a minor con of course as the game is essentially already over at that point, but still.. weird.
[/list]

I was in the minority in liking BG1. My rating for BG2 is somewhat similar. Some things are changed this time around, some for the better, some for the worse; but it is a definitely a different game, which on the whole is a good thing. Some parts of this game drag a bit, and not everything is done perfectly, but if you liked BG1 or like party-based, turn-based games then you should give this a try (for $2 you have very little to lose).

Overall: 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198012182421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3238, 'last_played': 1588982428}
review:
It is a quite good game even though after Blackguards 1 it has gone easier.  Game is not quite complicated as Blackguards 1, but it has more features.
First of all, dice (chance of your attacks hit or etc) system improved. Developers saw the problem with the casting dice system and deleted the base values section completely. Character developing system has also been better than first game.
Spells are not too easy to max but also it does not go 6 times for upgrading only 1 tier. Each tier upgrade needs only 1 upping.
Also different from the first, second game has an endurance of char which limits your powerful attacks which they are not limited in first game.
The bad things about the game, it is not as hardcore rpg as first game. Game shows the way to you all the game and you need only to click mouse and think of your battle strategy.
Also as same as first game, performance of the game quite bad. You will get nearly same FPS even very low or very high setting which is quite low. RX570 4GB gives 30 fps most somelike it has a FPS cap. 
Together with your 'try agains' :) it will provide you around 30 hours of gameplay which is quite lower than first game. 
In total, I would give 7/10 to game.

ich versuche mich hier mal kurz zu halten, auch wenn ich es nur angespielt habe. Talente sind eigentlich egal, die Handhabung l√§sst ebenfalls zu w√ºnschen √ºbrig.
Das Spiel hat den Charme, die Logik der Charaktere und ihren Handlungswillen verloren. S√∂ldner ziehen die K√§mpfe heraus, die Idee ist nicht schlecht man befehligt verb√ºndete und die Helden, doch mit der dummen KI frustrieren die immer √§hnlichen K√§mpfe doch sehr. Man hat angebliche Entscheidungsfreiheit die aber kaum Einfluss auf das Spiel haben (kaum darum habe verschiedene Wege versucht bleibt aber gleich vielleicht am Ende etwas variabel oder so). Die Story f√ºhlt sich einfach k√ºnstlich an soweit sie vorhanden ist, erkl√§rt sich nicht und nur der Held ist wahnsinnig kann die Handlung erkl√§ren. So wirkt es wenn man Selbstgespr√§che f√ºhren kann, als w√ºrden die Entwickler sich selbst √ºber die schlechte Geschichte lustig machen.
Bilanz: Das erste Teil ist gut gelungen auch wenn viele hier kritisiert haben, das zweite ist einfach MIST geworden. Ich w√ºrde vermuten, dass man hier etwas auf den Markt werfen musste, die Entwickler m√∂glichst keine Zeit haben und die Konzepte von einem guten Pen & Paper einfach herausgenommen haben.

review:
PURTROPPO UN NO SECCO.

non si √® rivelato minimamente degno del suo predecessore, e infatti ne ha anche portato alla morte la saga purtroppo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1583574964}
review:
This is honestly one of the worst games I've played. I have not enjoyed a single mission, so far. And most of them were infuriating, which is why I am not playing this any more. Nothing good has come out of it in the first half, so I doubt any good will come now.

There are three main points I want to emphasize, the last of which is really what made me drop the game.
First, it suffers from the same problems as older D&D based RPGs like Baldur's Gate; second, it suffers from the same problem as Fallout 2 where you spend 80% of the battles waiting for the enemies' turns (because enemies far outnumber you and are extremely slow); third, every level is either brainless filler, or a contrived gimmick. 

Regarding the problem with D&D based games - martial classes suck, with an extremely limited ability set. Only mages have a wide array of spells that you can use creatively at all and which make the game interesting. Unfortunately, so far, there is only one mage companion, although you could have a second mage as your main character. I didn't know the companions would be this limited, so I made my main character an archer, since there was no archer in the companions - so I got one mage, one single character that is fun and tactical to play.
The spells aren't very creative, either, or useful - especially since you must almost focus exclusively on leveling up a single spell for it to be useful (for example, "cure poison" works in tiers, and the enemies will quickly use high tiers of poison, forcing you to spend too many experience points to make such a spell useful, thus limiting what other spells you can have to widen the toolbox).
Martial classes have 3-4 abilities at most, but they are little more than "do slightly more melee damage".

Ok, about the second problem. This is pretty self explanatory, but I'll elaborate on mission design. Not only do enemies outnumber you, but they often spawn indefinitely. Sometimes they spawn infinitely, and sometimes they just spawn for a very long time. You don't really know which, because the game doesn't tell you anything. There is no way to speed battles up, either. Some of these enemies are even unreachable. There was a mission which had 9 archers shooting you from "off the board". But they would work like normal units. Each archer would take maybe 4 seconds per turn. A battle has dozens of turns. So for these archers auto-attacking alone, you would spend 10, 20 minutes just waiting. And there are many levels like this. There is so much time spent doing nothing, it's amazing to me how the designers didn't try to alleviate it in any way. It was an obvious problem in Fallout 2, a 20 year old game, for crying out loud!

Ok, last problem. You know how RPGs let you build your party and learn the stat system and which skills to use against what, and so on? How you learn the skill system to overcome challenges? Yeah, this game using this as bait, but then every level relies on an entirely unique gimmick that nullifies most of your skills. 
One level has you run around pressing levers to open colored doors while a mage can mind control your party and is immune to mind control himself. Oh, and the levers are behind colored doors, only one of which can be open at any one time. And the doors are set up so that you must run from one side of the map to the other every time. And you can't kill the enemies before you go through the whole sequence because there are healing crystals next to the levers you need to destroy. Yeah, that's fun.
Some other level relies entirely on setting fire to oil pools. Except that those oil pools are bubbling green, which makes them seem like poison and something you avoid, not something you try to shoot with fire.
Several levels rely on closing doors to prevent monsters from infinitely spawning. 
The point is that most of the levels are really "puzzles" that have nothing to do with any kind of RPG skillset. In fact, they make most of the spells and attacks useless until you solve the gimmick.
The other missions are literally just push overs. They're mindless. You just kill cannon fodder. There is neither strategy nor role-playing involved. The missions are designed to fill time and to present a poor gimmick that often relies on poorly communicated mechanics.

So yeah. Honestly, I find this game a pure waste of time. There are other problems. The "morality" system is entirely black and white. You choose "good", or you choose "bad". For example, at one point I could free a dude or tie him up with ropes. He had information, so I wanted to tie him up, which could have been useful, right? Well, yeah, except that without any input from you, the game decided that "tying him up" actually meant "kill him". 

The equipment relies entirely on set bonuses, so single pieces of equipment are worthless. Either you use an entire set, or it doesn't matter. Not a very interesting system.
The overworld map also seems non-linear, until you realize that each mission has a difficulty rating and you should just play them in order anyway.
I could go on, but this is really nit-picking, now.

I almost enjoyed this, at the beginning. But I realized that I was just frustrated on every single mission. So yeah. This is incredibly bad, in my opinion, and you should stay away if any of the issues I mentioned sound reasonable to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085093968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 330, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1598388182}
review:
Story:
Blackguards 2 begins with a fallen princess driven insane from her imprisonment in the arena's monster storage warehouse, where the main stock is insanity-venom spiders. But her fate changed when she found a book from another world that somehow found its way to her. A book about post-Renaissance warfare. Now she has a plan: hire the arena's former champions as her lieutenants, free the ax-crazy Silent Sons from prison as her army, and conquer the southern half of the country one town at a time.

Gameplay:
Most of the time, you'll just hit the "I Win" button to skip fights. The real meat comes from figuring out which weapon combinations will ensure your survival against hordes.

I liked how they streamlined character customization. You can obtain nearly any spell or ability you want at will, and you get the stat boosts you want directly from the source. Characters are also near-blank slates from the start.

However, this isn't just any army you're facing. Roman-themed metal-masked soldiers fight alongside giant flying bug-men, angry ents with beehives, and living sand tornadoes. Each one has their own special abilities and strategies.

Unfortunately, the Boss fights are the same level of frustrating as the first game. Hordes of enemies will continually spawn in to compensate the boss' flimsy armor.
