author: {'steamid': '76561198058544253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1576795796}
review:
The first 3 hours of this game is a scripted walk through. Once you get past that, the map opens up offering alternate paths. The battle maps are isometric with little room to maneuver. Some scenarios require recon by replay. Weapon and armour stats are a little cryptic and require research.  I thought the game had 360 degree camera rotation. The video I watched looked like it did. But no, its isometric with some pitch control. My bad for not researching it more. I would have never got this game if I knew that. However, in fairness I give a thumbs up. The game does good things with party management, and story continuity. Voice acting is BBC quality.
It took me 36 hours to complete. Some people play it again just to configure their party differently with the equipment, and choose different options for the branching dialogues.
You are given four characters, a fighter, a dwarf, a Mage, and your protagonist who is chaotic. You get to direct her as good or evil. The battles are pretty much scripted but you can choose which location to attack. Its not an iron man game, you need to save. Replays, or possibly going back to an earlier save is par for the course. Its easy to paint yourself in a corner. But in reality I never had to go back past my last save, although the possibility was there. The battles are scripted well. Some require you to activate levers, and traps to open doors or drop bridges. Its very obvious what you have to do. Only one battle had a situation where I had to activate a rope pulley 3 times to expose an enemy inside of a cage, while battling flying insects etc. Tactics depend on positioning for ranged weapons and attributes of-course for all (melee) in turn based initiative on a hex field. 
I got this game cheap so I'm glad I stuck it out. Its a good deal if you get it for under 3 bucks like I did.

review:
Two steps forward, one step back. The game improves on many aspects of its predecessor, in particular by streamlining combat to run more fluently (and eliminating the need to artificially extend fights). Unfortunately (in my view) this streamlining also was applied to character development, removing depth for the sake of simplicity. This may helpful for casual gamers who don't like learning new rule systems, but fans of the Dark Eye PnP system will find that there is almost nothing left of the original game mechanics.
The story is is more combat-focused than its predecessors, but flows well and is entertaining.

review:
Despite it's apparent good aspects... it's just not fun. Monotonous tedium is all. Normal diff was too hard, too many battle replays.
Easy was mostly too easy until I met the Druid who gains 6 mana points/turn and casts powerful spells that cost...you guessed it, 6 mana points haha.

I started this on easy to learn where my mistakes were. Anyway, if you have a lot of patience maybe it's worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988534641', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1563574096}
review:
Alright, Beat Blackguards 1... well trudged through Blackguards 1.

Now onto Blackguards 2... They came out so close together I'm sure I'm about ready to Trudge through...

Oh whats this?

A Main Character? An Army of Extra Dudes? Returns of my (kinda) favorite 3 Criminals? A More Balanced Growth System with clear building!?

IS THIS EVEN THE SAME SERIES!? Well yeah obviously.  And that folks is literally enough reason to give this game a shot especially if you felt burned by the first part of the series.  Thought he game takes place after the first one so it's good to play the first one to move  onto here - but if you don't...well you probably won't be too lost.

That's really my only complaint about this game is that it relies so heavily for you to play through the first one but at the same time it makes the first one look and feel like rubbish comparatively.

But other than that, the battles are a million times more fun - there is an need of campaign tactics which includes defending territories... and yes the battle flow well.  Even to the point where I look forward to defensive battles.  Worth the buy.

review: Blackguards 2 has it advantages and disadvantages. Turn based fights are good and challenging. There's four characters you can develop (almost) any way you want (archer, mage, rogue, fighter, spearman, warlock etc.). Lots of skill to learn, lots of items to be equipped and lots of choices to be made! Story could be a little more engaging but it's not bad. The biggest disadvantage for me was not enough new ideas... I'd rather call this game Blackguards 1.5 than Blackguards 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198870090915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1559881483}
review:
Its a great game, but a couple of bugs make me not able to recommend it. The bug where youre suddenly unable to save has been around since 2013 (2015 on steam) with various fixes (all seemingly related to moving things into inventory from a purchase in one form or another), and having it still be an issue in 2019 is a bad sign. Sadly, I didnt know about this bug till it happened to me and I googled a fix (there is none, just outdated workarounds to stop if from happening... not much use after the fact).

Im 22 hours in, and struggled to win a series of really tough fights (after a few retries), and the first chance I have to save I equipped a new belt and was unable to save... ok, ok, I should have saved first, but come on, after five years, I would think this would be a more stable game. Maybe I'll circle back and play again, but it kind of stings right now to be hit with this setback. 

If there was a neutral rating, I'd probably have chosen that, since the mechanics of the game are enjoyable, but never knowing when this bug might strike is a deterrant to me, and I might not have bought it knowing that ahead of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093378763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1567151679}
review:
I can't believe that I let myself pick up this piece of crap. So, I've been on a bit of a "The Dark Eye" kick recently as I play all these computer games based on what is a german pen n paper gaming system that until now I had never heard of. It didn't hurt that the system seemed to share an element with another game I played (primarily the whole spell test to see if you successfully cast). 

So, the first Blackguards had issues IMO. Don't get me wrong, I got my moneys worth, but it had issues. Despite that, it had a better character creation method than Drakensang minus being able to choose which race you wanted your main character to be from. My biggest irritation with B1 is that there is a limited pool of XP to gain, so if you screw up too much that's it. Your character is screwed.

Why do I bring up the first Blackguards when this review is supposed to be about the second one? Why, the three primary returning NPCs (Takate, Naurim, and what's his face) all of whom were de-leveled back down to L1 and pitted against guys who can kill them within three hits if you don't do what you are told and run. What the fuck is up with these story-tellers that want to fuck over established power-houses? I was looking forward to maxing out their abilities or starting from a mid-range of power... but I'm back to the beginning with everyone. EVERYONE.

Anyways, modifications were made to the system to make it much more simple for the most part. Secondary skills lost their individual levels and you only pay the XP cost to reach the tiers where modifiers change (except weapon skills). Just about all the skills and special powers are purchasable within the first couple hours of the game, unlike B1 where you literally had to progress through the game to get the option to pick certain spells up or find specific skill trainers.

Anyways, if you absolutely have to play something that emphasizes a female lead character as THE amazing thing give this or Memoria a try, but don't say I didn't warn you.

I may spend some time playing this to see if it gets better, but I'm skeptical of that happening. Still pissed about the writers and designers kicking consistency in the proverbial nuts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059485126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1551817080}
review:
Every fight is a "Flip a switch and run to exit, while endless amount of enemies spawn from tunnels".

I understand that the 'Silver Corapia Army' is a band of outlaws using guerilla-tactics, so the combat in-games reflects that: However, if you're forced to make one type of a fight over and over again, you would expect the game designers to put in something to spice up the things once in a while. Instead, what you get is that half-way through the game you lose the main character (Cassia) to a story-related fever for few fights, and instantly after that you have to go against the hardest and most boring "infinitely spawning enemies while running to flip switches" type of a level so far.

The first Blackguard-game was solid enough to last for the 40 or so hours it takes to beat it: Also, seeing the Blackguard-world, its characters and the more mature, cynical humour made for a nice experience. Blackguards 2 doesn't provide anything new or clever into gameplay or to the story: Everything it does has been done better somewhere else. Despite that, its still passes as a somewhat fun RPG-experience - At least, until you go to the first Cassia's Fever/Lizard mission, where all of my interest towards the game dropped instantly.

What a wasted opportunity of a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044803765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1549834975}
review: I really enjoyed BG1, but, there were several really annoying things about it, that I had hoped they would fix in this game, which of course they didn't. First of all, you still can't rotate the screen to see around obstacles. You have to go top down, but, this still doesn't give you a full view of the area. Good luck finding the chests. Second, for some reason you have to open chests, during battle, which is really annoying, in order to get the treasure. Well, if I just killed everyone, why wouldn't I loot the chest before leaving. This is a dumb mechanic. The game gets incredible difficult, all at once. Basically, you will be wiping the floor with the enemies until you get to a stage and just miss every attack, get crit'd every other attack, receive 2-3 wounds every turn, and are outnumbered 2-to-1. It is then that you realize that you made a serious mistake leveling your team. But, now it is too late and you have to start from all over again. ( I am 19.5 hours into the game, and there is NO FREAKING WAY, that I am going to start all over again. There is no game balance. Then of course there is the weird rambling story, that doesn't make any sense. Why are the characters from the first game even in this new story? Oh, I almost forgot, they added mercenaries, which you can't control their development, they are basically lame cannon fodder that you have to take into battle. Well, not exactly cannon fodder since the NPC's will pretty much completely ignore them and focus all their fire on your main characters, which are the only ones worth a damn in a fight. The devs have really dropped the ball on this one. Two thumbs down, Daedalic. (maybe the devs should try playing their own games before they release them) Don't waste your money on Daedalic games, you will always be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132649389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1373, 'last_played': 1549225859}
review:
Its a great game, but a couple of bugs make me not able to recommend it. The bug where youre suddenly unable to save has been around since 2013 (2015 on steam) with various fixes (all seemingly related to moving things into inventory from a purchase in one form or another), and having it still be an issue in 2019 is a bad sign. Sadly, I didnt know about this bug till it happened to me and I googled a fix (there is none, just outdated workarounds to stop if from happening... not much use after the fact).

Im 22 hours in, and struggled to win a series of really tough fights  (after a few retries), and the first chance I have to save I equipped a new belt and was unable to save... ok, ok, I should have saved first, but come on, after five years, I would think this would be a more stable game. Maybe I'll circle back and play again, but it kind of stings right now to be hit with this setback. 

If there was a neutral rating, I'd probably have chosen that, since the mechanics of the game are enjoyable, but never knowing when this bug might strike is a deterrant to me, and I might not have bought it knowing that ahead of time.

review:
The thing about this game, that it is epic. From characters, battle, story, and ending with RPG elements & loot-it is all epic and great
well... except for the battle ground which has some issues that harden the battle in unfair way.
Spells & ranged weapons range is strange. Even after hrs and I still cant tell where can you hit from or where can cast a spell that enemies will be in its range. Many time, I would move a spell caster or ranger to position to discover that it was a waste, because I could not hit anybody.
Most of objects such as levers, ropes or other things are unhighlighted at all on the battle ground which I found boring and nonsense. I keep searching the battle ground for objects by hovering cursor everywhere but nothing, and then I watch a video to discover that I could v cut the gate rope and secure the escape route since start of battle!!

8/10
could v been a 10!! but the battle ground and some attacking mechanics got some issues..

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198038132122', 'num_games_owned': 1756, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 2165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2165, 'last_played': 1544009624}
review:
[h1]Rating: fair (6/10)[/h1]

[b] Introduction [/b]
Blackguards 2 is a turn based RPG where by leading a party of multiple members you try to suceed against the raining tyrant which has thrown you, his ex-wife, into the prison.

[b] Gameplay & Story: 6/10 [/b]
After being biten by Corapia (a certain spider type in Blackguards 2), you start to lose your mind, but while that attain a large amount of knowledge contained in the crypts below Mengbilla, the capital of the southern lands. You start to forge a plan against your ex-hubby which has cowardly betrayed you for unknown reasons. You create a party of the former Blackguard 1 champions of the Nine Hordes, which support you by will or not on your rise to the power. Blackguards 2 is not that much story driven as its first part and feels more like a turn-based strategy with some RPG elements. The story has some interesting parts and the outcome is changed a bit by your decisions through out the game, that also contain achievements, but for the greatest part it feels quite pre-set in terms of your next possible steps.

[b] Combat & Challenge : 7/10 [/b]
The combat is actually more fun than in the former part and offers great tactical possibilities, tons of character development alternatives, lots of weapons from the first part but also newly added sets that fit your style. The skills and magic are more balanced and the enemies AI did either get an update or the enemies are simply stronger. Overall the game does feel challenging on the harder difficulty and you will more likely have to replay some battles, at least to get to know the mechanics.

[b] Graphic & Interface : 6/10 [/b]
The graphic did not change much and the interface received only minor improvements, so I will keep the rating as with the first part. However it affects the overall rating, since Blackgaurds 2 is a follow up and should have received at least a minor update. The interface still feels fulfilling the purpose but could receive have received an overhaul while the game details are present only in some parts, while other are a bit lacking.

[b] Progress & Mini-Games : 6/10 [/b]
The main quest line is hard to finish without the side quests providing you more equipment and experience to spend on skills, so you can say that the side quests have been intergrated into the game quite well. However, the main story is lacking since you mostly are fighting with some minor dialogs inbetween. The progress is tracked by the areas you win and counter attack of the ruler of Mengbilla. The character progress does not feel like it matters that much anymore, since your mostly fight with a bigger part and the main campaign is tracked by the flags on the map and your team automatically receives benefits by captured areas.

[b] Audio & Immersion : 7/10 [/b]
The music is almost the same in Blackguards 2, but has been expanded by some minor tracks and sound effects. It creates a great immersion of the battles and other surroundings while the effects feeling impactful and vary between monster and humanoids.

[b] Side-Notes [/b]
[list]
[*]This game offers a single player long campaign with 30+h if you finish all the side quests as well.
[*]This game contains steam achievements that are sometimes quite hard to get and require either replaying of re-saving.
[*]This game offers minor replayability since its heavily story based, but can be replayed for achievements or finishing with another attunement.
[/list]

[b] Summary [/b]
Blackguards 2 is a decent single player RPG with an oldschool feeling, turn-based hex combat and strategic elements added to the story progression. The music as well the graphic style and interface fit the game really well and the amount of possibilities of character progression add a great amount of diversity. The characters are great and some dialogs between them are enjoyable. The combat is challenging on hard, so you might even have to replay it if you mess up your character on the first try. Overall, not as great as Blackguards 1 but still a decent RPG to spend time without, especially if you enjoyed Blackgaurds 1 characters, combat or character progression.


I hope this review helps you making the decision if its worth buying and installing this game. Rate and leave a comment if you enjoyed reading it.
~ForestWolf

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 33769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16339, 'last_played': 1539534120}
review:
Blackguards 2 isn't a large step down from the first game, which was actually already not that great, the main issue being that this second entry remains heavily bugged to this day, which can very much annihilate any and all enjoyment with ongoing campaigns.

The hex-battles themselves are solid, but the NPC cast isn't particularly likeable, the story is ... meh at best and there is pretty much zero exploration due to there not really being a gameworld except for the combat maps.

As a turn based battle game this is okay-ish, but as an RPG it fails miserably in my book. In this state, which is 100% unlikely to ever be adressed, won't recommend.

review: Am a bit lazy about posting reviews, but have to agree with many others who feel this is hugely underrated. Blackguards was fun and Blackguards 2 is an intense combat focus version of it. Yes, same combat mechanics and controls but without some of the other elements of the first game like attributes, weight management, arrow conservation - pretty much without anything that removes your focus from winning battles and defending territory. AP is still very scarce and you have to carefully plan how to spend those points for your band: Delaying some immediate useful skills in order to save for a more expensive critical one, not upgrading some skills, and sacrificing others altogether. This process is easier if you have finished the first game and you understand what you are looking for better, otherwise it will take some tries to get right. All in all, this is a fun and challenging experience and highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038538764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 6883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6013, 'last_played': 1535917830}
review:
Blackguards 2 - Rundentaktik mit Das schwarze Auge (DSA) Universum in abgespeckter Form.

Das Spiel handelt wie schon sein Vorg√§nger im DSA Universum. Auf diversen Karten k√§mpft man Taktik-Gefechte mit einer vorgegeben Heldengruppe, die man immer weiter ausbaut. Grafik, Stimmung und Spielmechanik wurden aus dem Vorg√§nger √ºbernommen. Neu ist allerdings eine Weltkarte, auf der man seinen Weg zum Endkampf selbst bestimmt.

Blackguards 2 ist allerdings die "abgespeckte" Version seines Vorg√§ngers. Die Spielzeit betr√§gt nur die H√§lfte und es wurden viele Sachen vereinfacht. Diese sind teilweise echt sinnvoll (Sichtlinien bei Bogensch√ºtzen werden angezeigt), f√ºr manche Spieler entweder gut oder schlecht (es gibt kein Gewicht bei Gegenst√§nden mehr) und teilweise nicht so toll (Abschaffung der Attribute). 

Das DSA Universum ist im Vergleich zu anderen eher komplex. Hier muss man sich erst bisl "einarbeiten". Das W√ºrfelgl√ºck spielte dadurch im Vorg√§nger eine grosse Rolle. Dies wurde aber von vielen kritisiert, manche fanden aber gerade dies gut, da man durch die Weiterentwicklung seiner Charaktere dieses W√ºrfelgl√ºck immer mehr und sp√ºrbar beeinflusste. In Blackguards 2 wurden die Regeln sehr (meiner Meinung nach zu sehr) vereinfacht und eher auf die negativen Kritiken zum Vorg√§nger geh√∂rt. Dadurch gibt es keine Attributpunkte mehr und normale Attacken und Zauber treffen fast immer. Durch zu viel Vereinfachungen f√ºr die Zug√§nglichkeit geht Spieltiefe verloren. 

Diese "Seichtigkeit" sieht man auch darin, dass immer Trainer bereitstehen, die alles lehren k√∂nnen. Im Vorg√§nger musste man bestimmte St√§dte mit bestimmten Trainern besuchen, die aber dann auch nicht alles gelehrt haben. Schade ist weiterhin, dass es fast keine Nebenauftr√§ge mehr gibt und man in den Gefechten fast nur gegen immer den selben Feindtyp (Soldat) antritt. Auch ist mir aufgefallen, dass man in den super gestalteten Karten des Vorg√§ngers mehr mit der Umwelt interagiert hat (Karten sind trotzdem noch gut designt). Positiv ist der gut ausbalancierte Schwierigkeitsgrad: auf "leicht" kommen Anf√§nger gut klar, auf "schwer" haben es selbst Profis manchmal schwer. Weiterhin positiv ist die Story, die den Wahnsinn oder die gut/b√∂se Entwicklung der Hauptfigur bis zum Ende gut nachzeichnet.

F√ºr mich insgesamt jedoch alles bisl zu sehr vereinfacht, obwohl es immer noch zu den guten Rundentaktik Spielen z√§hlt.

Fazit: Wer Anf√§nger im Genre der Rundentaktik ist, greift zu Blackguards 2. Wer fortgeschritten oder Profi ist, eher zu Blackguards 1. Bei Interesse kann man sich dann den anderen Teil auch zulegen, da diese in Sales teils zu billig angeboten werden (Teil 2 f√ºr 3 ‚Ç¨, Teil 1 f√ºr 2 ‚Ç¨).

author: {'steamid': '76561197981435013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1533503629}
review:
Blackguards 2 bien podr√≠a ser una expansi√≥n o DLC largo del primer juego. El motor, los gr√°ficos, la jugabilidad... apenas ha cambiado nada.

Sin embargo, simplifica enormemente las reglas de creaci√≥n y desarrollo de personajes (de hecho, por poder, no puedes ni crear un PJ y darle nombre). Esto puede ser alg√∫n inconveniente para alg√∫n fan ac√©rrimo de la primera parte, o alg√∫n jugador m√°s hardcore... A m√≠ sencillamente me ha convencido, ya que muchas mec√°nicas tediosas que tuve que soportar en el anterior se han visto limadas aqu√≠, d√°ndome m√°s ganas de jugar, y evitando aburrirme. Y es que, a pesar de todo, sigue siendo igual de repetitivo, por lo que... ¬øpor qu√© no aumentar un poquito la velocidad del juego y regalar m√°s acci√≥n?

Mejora mucho la historia, que se torna m√°s oscura y adulta. Aqu√≠ hay verdaderas decisiones inc√≥modas que te plantean si eres bueno o eres malo... y hay una moderada cantidad de decisiones que variar√°n ligeramente el final, los flecos sueltos, as√≠ como los logros a obtener. Se dejan en el tintero varias subtramas por desarrollar, y desde luego, la relaci√≥n entre algunos personajes y el desenlace de otros. Principalmente echo en falta una explicaci√≥n del origen de la protagonista y su inter√©s para con sus compa√±eros de aventuras. Parece un spinoff o precuela autoconclusiva, y no hace falta jugar el primero. Por √∫ltimo, si sois fans de los juegos de Daedalic y de los traumas de su equipo de guionistas, id preparando un vaso de agua con az√∫car.

En el aspecto jugable, arregla parcialmente el tema de la linealidad. Pasamos de una b√∫squeda de h√©roes a una campa√±a militar con conquistas y defensa de baluartes. El n√∫mero de enemigos y personajes jugables aumenta considerablemente. Esto es un arma de doble filo ya que, si bien las batallas resultan en parte m√°s √©picas, tambi√©n redundan en un peor rendimiento en m√°quinas m√°s modestas, y turnos interminables. Sobran defensas de territorios conquistados. Y por otra parte, olvidaos de la microgesti√≥n del ej√©rcito. Eso para otro juego.

La duraci√≥n es un aspecto que se ve afectado en esta segunda entrega. No llega ni de lejos a la de Blackguards + DLC. Es cierto que en esta ocasi√≥n he dejado de lado el masoquismo y he jugado en dificultad normal... pero la simplificaci√≥n de reglas y premios por combate hacen que todo pueda resultar un paseo si montas un buen grupo de personajes. El ataque a distancia con arcos sigue siendo cheto. A√∫n as√≠ no lo veo como un punto negativo, ya que el primero lleg√≥ un momento en que me estaba cansando, por su dificultad, y por el nulo inter√©s por las misiones secundarias.

En definitiva: lo jugu√© con expectativas bajitas. La gente le pon√≠a una nota mediocre y se quejaba. Est√° mucho mejor de lo que se cuenta y, sinceramente, lo he disfrutado m√°s que el primero.

7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197964133534', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2072, 'last_played': 1532558726}
review:
Got Blackguards 2 for 2 euros and it gave me much more in return. It was actually surprisingly good. 4/5 stars.

It's isometric combat focused story. Developing characters can be a bit tricky as there are set of spells, which have little to no use. Depending on skill/spell choices some battles may vary from easy to hard. Also, luck plays certain role in battles as hits are % based. As game goes on some AI problems become obvious and can be used in favor.

If you get Blackguards 2 from sale and in general like "old school" isometric fantasy games, then you prolly enjoy this game. But if you dislike learning new gamesystems, then you maybe won't enjoy Blackguards 2. System is not hard to learn but its not intuitive to start with. Its different and I found it refreshing.

review:
A worthy, yet a little faulty, follow up to the grim story of Blackguards. 

For me, being a big fan of turnbased strategy games since TBE: The Northlandtrilogy, this game had some good story telling. The characters were a little stiff and everyone was a little too short on his terms of speech, but all in all the characters, which we already knew from the first game, made the reason to stick with it.

The decisionmaking and your overall behaviour within a war is what counts in the end. There are multiple endings depending on your success in battle and decisions. Sadly only the last chapter is affected by it and you are not allowed to lose a battle. Yet it was well balanced in terms of abilities and useability. Not too many abilities, but still a big chunk of skilltable and the possibility to build characters with multiple classes (like my main character who was a master archer and supportive spellcaster).

This game has flaws nevertheless. First and foremost the fact, that there is not way to fasten up combat. If you are fighting against a horde of over ten men, which often happens, then you have to wait for every last one of them finish their animation. And since their walking of the entire map seems to be really important you are not allowed to do anything useful in the meantime, like checking inventories or exploring the map for treasures or levers. 
Then there is a certain balancing issue. Sure in the beginning the characters are weak (even the ones you leveled in Blackguards 1), but some fights are basically unfair and don't even tell you how to win it. The boss levels make this even clearer, where you are on some kind of a timelimit, since there always is the point where you will get overwhelmed. So more and more often it is a case of finding out what to do, then restart the fight and do it. 

And you are not able to save in the midst of battle or between two, so you either have to play through all battles of this stage in one session or rely on the autsave, which didn't always work for me.

All in all good for everyone who really loves this kind of games, I certainly did enjoy it, but probably not for people who just want to try it.

Finished in 25 hours with the good ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973112890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 4331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4252, 'last_played': 1649815015}
review:
This game is severely underrated, worth it at full price and it's frequently on sale for $3 which is a steal.

Blackguards 2 really strongly reminds me of Tyranny to such a degree that I almost wonder if Tyranny was inspired by this game and basically just a more polished version with spellcrafting. You lead a party of a few heroes+yourself and some mercenary soldiers to go conquering towns on a world map. It feels very gameboard-y and reminds me also of tabletop gaming and of Heroes of Might and Magic series.

The combat is decent, not great, but not bad either, unless you're ready for a board game still in which case it's good. It takes awhile if you're more impatient and you can't save in the middle of battles but that's okay by me so you can only savescum between villages. Graphics are decent, soundtrack is decent, great character customization and so on. Lots of items, which sadly don't get used enough because it ends your turn instead of combat, which on normal mode is ridiculously easy by the middle to end if you go full crazy spider mage although combat in the early part can be quite challenging.

If it's on sale definitely get it. I've had quite a lot of fun with this title so far and storyline wise it seems some sort of continuation from BG 1 so I'm a bit more lost who all these people are, but going in blind kind of makes the game more fun. Plus you are a supposedly insane person with a tinge of amnesia, so that helps to roleplay. I just wish I'd realized that saying "I'm not crazy" when prompted doesn't translate into "your character is crazy" which is a bummer if you were hoping to play a genuinely insane and not just dying character. I would suggest saying in dialogue options that you are crazy for a more Malkavian experience.

 The story itself wasn't even that long nor was the lore explanatory in any way, which oddly gave the story a feel of greater depth where you wanted to know more about it. A very interesting setting IMO and I liked the story.

In terms of gameplay you just have to adjust to the fact that it's hex based and you can't move past an occupied one, and with objects in the way you can easily get boxed in so plan your moves accordingly. It is more like Heroes of Might and Magic III than Fallout Tactics, however it basically is a tactical strategy game. Also, it would be nice to rotate the camera, not crippling just sometimes annoying. 

Overall a solid 8.5/10 and I hope to see Blackguards 1 on sell because now I plan to get it. Also has good replay value.

VOICE ACTING: S+ 
I forgot to mention this when I originally wrote the review but I adore the voice acting in the Blackguard series. This game blew me away in how well the actors managed to convey both feeling AND character with every line. I look forward to hearing them in any future games I might stumble upon.

A fun sequel to Blackguards albeit shorter and much easier. The story, gameplay, and music are very enjoyable aside from a camera that can't be rotated. Grab this game if you liked the first one and don't mind the sideways shift in gameplay. While I did several replays of Blackguards I don't think I'll be doing the same with Blackguards 2. Nonetheless, I definitely would say I had a very good time playing this especially since I got it on sale.

review:
Einige Jahre nach den Ereignissen des ersten "Blackguard"-Teils, gelingt es der, von ihrem Gatten Marwan jahrelang in den unteren Gew√∂lben der Stadt Mengbilla festgehaltenen, Ehefrau Cassia, aus ihrem dunklen und spinnenverseuchten Gef√§ngnis zu entfliehen. W√§hrend der Jahre in Isolation hat sie zwangsweise eine Affinit√§t f√ºr die Achtbeiner entwickelt, weshalb sie sich schlie√ülich auch unter dem Banner der Spinne aufmacht, den machtgierige Ex von seinem Thron zu schubsen. Zwischen ihm, Cassia und ihrer Rache steht lediglich die versammelte Armee Marwans, weshalb sie auf die, dem Gott des Kampfes Kor huldigende, S√∂ldnertruppe namens "Stumme Legion" zur√ºck greift, die ihre Reihen verst√§rken soll. Noch n√§her stehen ihr allerdings der Zwerg Naurim, der Zauberer Zurbaran und der Waldmensch Takate, die bereits f√ºr den Helden des Erstlings durchs Feuer gingen. Doch wird es Cassia verhindern k√∂nnen, zwischen all den Verlockungen nicht ebenfalls der Macht-, Blut oder Goldgier zu erliegen? Denn wie so oft lauert der gr√∂√üte Feind nicht unbedingt im Offensichtlichen, sondern ganz tief im Innern.

Die St√§rken des ersten Teiles bestanden in dem schnell erlernbaren Gameplay, der passablen Handlung und vor allen den teils arg stereotypen, aber interessanten, Figuren nebst ihren mehr oder weniger handlungsrelevanten Dialogen. Dazu gesellt sich mit der "Das Schwarze Auge"-Lizenz ein wahres Brett am Rollenspielhimmel, das immer wieder dazu verf√ºhrt, sich in jener Fantasiewelt zu verlieren. Mit Naurim, Takate, Zurbaran und auch Niobe kehren einige Figuren wieder zur√ºck, auf das Erstellen eines eigenen Helden muss man diesmal im Gegenzug aber verzichten. Daf√ºr erh√§lt man mit der von Spinnen deformierten Cassia eine alles andere als allt√§gliche Heldin, deren Motive aber erz√§hlerisch schlichtweg zu wenig nachvollziehbar aufgeschl√ºsselt werden. Klar, sie hat eine Rechnung mit ihrem "Alten" offen, aber muss man daf√ºr gleich ein ganzes Land erobern oder gar in Schutt und Asche legen? Hier anscheinend schon und, zugegeben, das ebenfalls nicht ganz unbekannte Reisesystem mit den verschiedenen Kartenstationen schafft es erneut, uns motiviert durch die Gegend zu schleifen. Die jeweiligen Angriffsziele bieten jeweils verschiedene Boni f√ºr unsere H√§ndler und S√∂ldner (Schwertk√§mpfer, Speertr√§ger oder Bogensch√ºtzen) und verleihen mitunter auch einige effektive Spezialtruppen (Kampfmagier, Assassinen und Schwarzoger). Weitere Neuerungen bestehen unter anderem in der M√∂glichkeit, die selbst gesteuerten Truppen mit Kontingenten aus den Reihen der Stummen Legion aufzuf√ºllen, um sich so bestens auf verschiedene Kampfsituationen einzustellen. Der Fokus liegt aber nat√ºrlich immer noch auf den bekannten Helden, die im rundenbasierten Hexagon-Kampfget√ºmmel noch immer die wichtigsten Figuren darstellen.

Technisch rei√üt "Blackguards 2" aber keine B√§ume aus und verl√§sst sich auf die gleiche Grafik-Engine, die bereits aus dem nur knapp 10 Monate √§lteren Vorg√§nger bekannt ist. F√ºr ein rundenbasiertes Strategie-RPG sind die visuellen Qualit√§ten aber nicht unbedingt unattraktiv, man darf halt nur keine Orgien vom Schlage prominenter reinrassiger Rollenspiele erwarten. Die Vertonung, insbesondere nat√ºrlich die Stimmen von Naurim, Zurbaran und Takate, ist ebenfalls wieder gelungen und man wartet regelrecht auf die bissigen Kommentare, die der kampfw√ºtige Zwer in den Zwischendialogen und K√§mpfen von sich gibt. √úbrigens darf man in Teil 2 ab und an in ein Feldlager einkehren, in welchem man das eine oder andere Gespr√§ch mit seinen Gefolgsleuten f√ºhren und auch einige Entscheidungen im Umgang mit diesen treffen darf. Bringen wir z.B. Naurim dazu, seinen Familiensinn wieder zu entdecken oder erwecken wir seine unnachgiebige Gier nach Gold? Bringen wir unsere Feinde, nach deren Niederlage, reihenweise um oder schenken wir ihnen gro√üz√ºgig die Freiheit, auch wenn dies bedeutet, dass sie uns einige Zeit sp√§ter wieder auf dem Schlachtfeld begegnen k√∂nnten?

"Blackguards 2" gibt sich reichlich M√ºhe, dem Vorg√§nger gerecht zu werden und kann, bis auf die etwas undurchsichtige Story, tats√§chlich auch auf Tuchf√ºhlung mit diesem gehen. Da die echten Innovationen aber ausbleiben und sich die Geschichte entweder sehr voraussehbar oder gar zu unnachvollziehbar entwickelt, reicht es im zweiten Durchgang nur noch zu drei guten, aber keineswegs mehr herausragenden, vier Sternen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035011027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1206, 'last_played': 1526911400}
review:
I actually bought promotion pack from the publisher primarily for this title, because I liked the first Blackguards game a lot.

I enjyoed this one as well, and pushed on until I had completed my first play-through.


I am not typiclly a turn-based fan, but I like the Dark Eye universe so the story / campaign setting kept me interested, and thankfully the difficulty scales pretty well for those that are a bit casual with the genre.

The big challenge is knowing what capabilities are essential when leveling up. I thankfully had read the recommendation to emphasize spell-casting, but admit that few of the creator fights required quite some trial and error. I personally would have liked a few more optional "filler" encounters to have the choice of leveling up a bit more in anticipation of the bosses. 

The game requires a certain engagement / investment from the player, but I personally found it very worthwhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068141034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1930, 'last_played': 1526191355}
review:
Whoa, mostly negative recent reviews? I don't get it, I thought Blackguards 1 was underrated, and now this massively so. 

Blackguards 2 is dark, all the rogue characters, black humor, and gritty militarism of the origina are here, now with the addition of an insane main character which is funny even though her insanity is played to the darkest levels - click to talk to yourself and you get insane ramblings of the disturbing variety. 

Prisoners can be interrogated, let go, or hung, one of them keeps a secret antidote recipe from you, while you're dying of the poison it cures. You get the option to use thumbscrews... you know, morality is a shifting concept and you very often turn brutal in the role play as well as the battle elements. You don't get to be Khaleesi, your mercs need pay, and pay is meted out in the form of letting them pillage your new towns. I play some cutesy games, and it sometimes feels like I should re-balance myself by playing one of those after a session on this. 

Blackguards 2 has some nice improvements over the original, some of them very subtle. The skills have been swathe simplified in some areas, and are pretty much the same in others. You can now give your mages a skill that lets them wear metal armor with no astral energy penalty. I've seen people complain that you can't compare equipment easily, but actually the character you last had in the inventory screen is the one that market items are compared to. And you can open the inventory screen, while the market screen is still open and 'behind' the inventory, and side swipe the characters to compare someone else. It's quite easy to assess the suitability of things. Also, stats have been added to the character page, and when you hover over potential equipment, you're shown the overall effect in plusses and minuses on a range of stats, and that includes the difference it'll make if you're breaking up a full set of armor, or making one.

You're out to conquor the entire landscape in this outing (the map from Blackguards 1) so you get to see the flags turning blue as you advance, taking each area and town. 

After every three battles, Marwan, the big bad in this, gets a chance to attack one of your towns and you must defend. These battles are great, it's gratifying to watch the other side now fall into swampy gloop, fall flat on their face over youuur tripwires, get bottlenecked into small pass areas and melted down by your mage or arrowed to sushi from a safe distance. The defence battles really put the boot on the other foot and its great to see the AI go all three stooges in the face of your awesome defences. Really cool, nice to have that defending experience amid all the driving forward. 

You now have mercenaries helping you, so as well as your heroes you can choose a few mercs to add to the party like battlemage, swordsmen, spearmen. Sometimes the mercs have pillaging they want to do, and you can run a battle or two with them alone. You might expect them to suck compared to your heroes but they level up nicely and gain skills. The battlemage had max level fireballs before my own mage did. 

There are two-stage battles sometimes. Say, you're going to attack a town, but the town has rock throwing catapults. You can choose a hero and some mercs to send up there and turn the tables with those catapults.... that prelim battle will be a battle map area of its own, and when finished with that, when you come to conduct the main battle you can't use the hero who you sent on the run before... because it's at the same time, if you see what I mean, he/she can't be in two places at once. I really like this as well because if you're like me you probably only have one healer. So you really have to choose carefully whether to send him on the advance party or into the main battle. Ofc main battle should win that, but you're forced then to get accustomed to battling without a healer, and actually that teaches you a lot. 

Like in BlackGuards 1, the beginning is tough, the toughest part of the game, especially I think the third battle? Around that time anyway, there's a 'runaway' type battlemap, which is tough as hell, your men can take about 3 hits from just one of the guys chasing you, while they can take about 20 of your hits... and there are 11 of them. They're a bit dumb in their pathseeking, all getting in each others way on the narrow ledges and stuff, but they can move very far and will start to go around the long way to box you in. That battle is one of the hardest in the game. When I see these negative reviews with only 1.5 hours played, I think it's due to rage quit over this particuar battle. But seriously, I did have reservations about the game while on my third attempt of that map.... but really take heart, the rest of the game is nothing like that one map. In fact, I haven't lowered the difficulty like I did during BlackGuards 1, i'm on the normal level and cruising nicely. As your characters level, skill, and gear up, the going gets a lot smoother. 

Other improvements on the original: there's much less missing of attacks in the early stages, and I've never seen a spell fail. Those were major irritations in the original, and I'm happy to see they've gone. There's also some new equipment, and the 'full set' bonuses on armor get really good. 

You now have a camp, a sort of roving base, which has its own tutors and maket, so you no longer have to go looking for teachers, and your market upgrades its content as you progress thru the story, these are much more convenient than running around the countryside looking for these things. Once you've taken over a town, you can use that town's facilities as well. 

You no longer need to sleep at inns to restore vitality, and you no longer have to heal wounds outisde of combat. Both of these affects are simply gone when the battle ends. 

You can lose a defence battle, and it's not game over, you simply lose that town. Which... means you can retake the town... and theoretically if you keep getting beaten back out of the same town, and raise AP every time you take it, there's a kind of... the tide is coming in! sensation about that... you'll only ever get stronger. Though, I know about this becuase I took the Capital City Mengbilla at the first opportunity... i'm pretty sure you're not supposed to do that while half the map still belongs to the enemy, but I got it! The counter attack tho'... omg lol! Definitely the most determined I've ever seen the AI... 

There are some battles along the way which are 'runaway to win' type things... well, smash crystals, steal something, pull a lever, that kind of thing, and then high tail it outta there. These ones are a bit weird, in that the enemy spawns and replaces constantly. You're unable to slaughter your way to victory, and actually have to run away even if you're strong enough to beat back entire waves of the monsters.

There are also some 'pull levers' dominated battlemaps, just one or two so far, which test your strategising in a different way. I find them frustrating, i'm more like, 'just lemme be brutal!' sobut, there aren't a huge amount of these lever pulley maps, only two stand out in my memory so far (28 hours in). 

The battles can take a long time, I think that puts some people off. But ofc they do, two sides, doing turn based. That's what happens. This isn't an MMO, this isn't a game where you spend six months in frantic combat to gain levels, you're taking over the whole map, as part of a greater story, and the battles take time! lol! Idk how else to put it, this is what you expect from BlackGuards 2 and all games of this type. In fact, the thought-through pace encourages you to chill out a bit and actually read the stuff between battles. This game is dark, it's involved, it's brutal, it makes you think, and it makes you rage, so the 'story' playing out between battles is a kind of natural tension breaker. I like it. 

This is great, this game is fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992222545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2254, 'last_played': 1524332124}
review:
Fairly solid game, though there are too many issues for me to recommend the game as I do for the first one. Perpetually spawning enemies make certain areas unpassable, so you have to restart the map and hope the AI doesnt get you stuck in a loop. The end battle is way too buggy for their climax fight. You would think with how important a final battle is, that all the mechanics that they implement in that fight would actually work.
I only paid $5 for the game, so all in all worth it. The main character is literally insane and its fun. I would not pay full price for this game, but if you enjoy turn based combat D&D esque games, try it for cheap.
85% sale is not unhead of for this game, maybe get it for $3

author: {'steamid': '76561198028993615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 994, 'last_played': 1523862919}
review:
The story has gotten much better, but all the faults of the first installment persist.
- camera can't be rotated - thus you end up fighting the camera more often than enemies
- there is no way to skip or speed up enemy turns - enjoy waiting for ages until a horde of zombies slowly walk to their destination one by one
- alt-tabbing pauses the game - so you can't skip enemy turns that way either
- inventory management is a pain - there are no option to sort equipment in any meaningful way, to compare an item across characters. At least the encumbrance system was removed.
- the skill wheel is tiresome to navigate once all the hotkey skill slots are used up.

All these issues make the game feel more like a chore than something fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978969288', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1213, 'last_played': 1522338552}
review:
Few things changed from the first, not all for the good i'm afraid : 

- the Combat is more or less the same, there's still a lot to it but this time with a lot more units on the screen most of the time, this fucks up the game performance somehow and slow the flow of the game, frustrating at times.
- Roleplaying elements are scarce but this time you've got some more liberty, which is good. 
- Not a whole lot of builds available, in fact they removed a few things here and there and made all the units pretty much the same.
- Map is smaller but there's not much more detail into it, infact, i think that the interaction with the world itself this time was kinda boring. 

All in all, once again i believe that even this game can entertain you for a few hours, but, i sadly also believe that its an inferior game compared to the first one, i'd recommend it to hardcore RPG fans who wouldnt shy away from action oriented RPGs.

Le cot√© RPG n'est pas en reste √©tant donn√© que les sp√©cialisations des personnages (√©quipements, comp√©tences, sorts) sont vastes et offrent des possibilit√©s diverses. 

Le cot√© strat√©gie lors des combats est quand √† lui am√©lior√© je trouve. 
Les plateaux sur lesquels nous combattons sont grands et les ennemis parfois retors. 
Les interactions avec le d√©cor sont pr√©sentes et peuvent √™tre d√©cisives.

On pourra aussi regretter le manque d'interet √† la rejouabilit√©  malgr√© le fait qu'il soit compens√© par un contenu assez important.

De mon point de vue les deux Blackguards sont des valeurs sures dans le domaine des RPG/Strat√©gie au tour par tour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976498153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 2232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2232, 'last_played': 1514864988}
review:
*pollice giallo*

Blackguards 2 √® un gioco di ruolo basato principalmente su combattimenti tattici a turni.
Come il primo capitolo della serie il gioco Deadelic ha un sacco di pregi... e di difetti. Diciamo subito che il fulcro del gioco, i combattimenti, sono divertenti. Partendo da come useremo i punti esperienza sui nostri personaggi gli elementi di diversificazione sono parecchi. Per capirci ho finito il gioco non usando mai almeno una decina di incantesimi, che potenzialmente avrei potuto portare al livello 4 (il massimo), cosa che avrebbe cambiato parecchio l'approccio al combat. La novit√† principale √® che questa volta avremmo a disposizione un piccolo esercito che ci porteremo dietro nelle missioni, arrivando ad avere anche una decina di pg da controllare. Lo scopo del gioco consiste nel conquistare citt√† dopo citt√† fino ad arrivare alla capitale. Qui salta fuori una grossa differenza rispetto a BG1: le citt√† con uno sfondo unico e dove potremo effettivamente fermarci sono solamente cinque. Dunque il gioco √® molto meno "gdr con una storia" e quest rispetto al passato, e di conseguenza molto pi√π corto (la met√† circa). Graficamente sembra addirittura peggio, visto che c'√® meno variet√† di locations. Stesso discorso per i nemici, che sono pi√π o meno gli stessi per tutto il gioco. Altre meccaniche nuove non servono granch√©, tipo gli organi o la gestione dei prigionieri. Per concludere se lo chiamavano Blackguards Tactics sarebbe stato pi√π corretto. Plauso per il doppiaggio e in particolare per la voce di Cassia.

P.S: l'ho giocato normal e si passa da situazioni facilissime a difficilissime in modo abbastanza random.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006689642', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2355, 'last_played': 1515175062}
review:
The game itself is not bad, but in comparison to its precessor ...

I liked Black Guards 1 very much - the way tactical fights were mixed with a few RPG elements.
All battles were nicely done and every one of them felt unique in its own way.

In black guards 2 the strategic battles are not bad themselves, 
it is just that because of the game design you play multi battle maps multiple times.

The can understand what the game designers thought of, in theory this was a nice idea
but in my opinioin in the end (or better in the middle of the game) it failed.

However I recommend this game anyway for all who played Blackguards 1. BG2 is still its successor and even though it won't fit into the foot prints of the first one it's the only thing we get. And as said, it was not bad by itself, it's an okay game but I liked BG1 more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007486006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1514666146}
review:
It is not a bad game, but to be honest I'm utterly unimpressed; I was pleasantly surprised by the first Blackguards, but I cannot recommend this sequel at all.

It looks, plays and feels exactly like the first Blackguards, but obviously it does not have the same air of novelty that the first one had. It is more of the same, with some extra limitations: no personalisation of the main character, a banale story of betrayal and revenge that does not drive the game forward convincingly, exactly the same characters in your team, but with less personality and no development at all since the last time you saw them, absolutely nothing new as far as gameplay is concerned, extremely repetitive scenaries and battles. The only novelty is the more punishing difficulty, probably introduced to cover up the emptiness of everything else.

If you have already played Blackguards and were left desperately wanting more, this might be a good choice, but if you did not love the first one to pieces, this one won't really hold your attention.

If you are new to the series, you should start with the first Blackguards, which is better and probably less expensive at the moment, and possibly stop there.

review:
Eins vorab: Blackguards 2 ist wesentlich besser gepolished als der erste Teil.

Ich habe das Spiel jetzt knapp sieben Stunden gespielt und so langsam zog mich das Spiel in sich hinein. Die ersten zwei bis drei Stunden muss man einfach durchhalten. Nach den Achievements zu urteilen, haben dies allerdings nur 31% der Spieler geschafft.

Eigentlich wollte ich das Spiel dann auch noch eine Weile spielen (eventuell sogar durchspielen), allerdings st√ºrzt das Spiel immer wieder ab. WARUM kann man NICHT in den K√§mpfen SPEICHERN? Ich habe die Platform PC bewusst gew√§hlt, weil ich unter anderem jederzeit speichern m√∂chte!!! Im Endeffekt musste ich dann zum vierten Mal eine Schlacht wiederholen, die so gut wie gewonnen war. Was ich besonders krass finde, laut Optionen ist die Taste F5 mit Schnellspeicher belegt. Dummerweise funktioniert diese Taste in den K√§mpfen nicht.

Aber WARUM SIND DIE ANIMATIONEN SO LANGSAM? Schon beim normalen Spielen macht das keinen Spa√ü. Wenn man dann aber eine Schlacht wiederholen muss, zieht mir das den Boden unter den F√º√üen weg.

So sympatisch ich Daedalic Entertainment theoretisch finde, mit ihren Spielen kann ich irgendwie nichts anfangen. Und das sage ich, obwohl ich durchaus ungeschliffene Diamanten mag (siehe Kings Bounty). Aus meiner Sicht hat sich der Entwickler hier einmal mehr √ºbernommen. Ich kann mir echt nicht erkl√§ren wie solch ein Bugdesaster in der Presse gut davonkam. Da von den Entwicklern keine Updates mehr kommen werden, kann ich von diesem Spiel nur abraten.

1/5

Great game, although I wouldn't pay full price for it. 
If you liked the first game, you'll like this one too.

review:
I spent half as much time with Blackguards 2 as the first one, but I don't feel like it was too short or that the first game was better, because it was longer. I got quantity and quality in large amounts with both games. If you liked the first one, you'll like this one. I recommend playing Blackguards 1 first or else it'll be a bit like starting at season 2 of a TV series, even if the plot and protagonist aren't the same. However, don't bother with the Untold Legends DLC as it doesn't add much, especially if you've already finished the game like I had.

I missed some things from the previous game, noticed many changes that were plain different rather than good or bad and was pleased that they had streamlined certain other things. The Blackguards games have their flaws, e.g. a few stupid "run around and pull switches" maps, but nothing too frequent or annoying. Also, combat strategies typically work well or not at all. Failure isn't as annoying as in other games, though, because of the wide selection of tactical elements. Reloading a fight feels more like an opportunity to improve your planning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256360437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1507888108}
review:
I really liked this game, it has cool assets and other weaknesses.

PROS
-Decent storyline and dialogues, wich make history interesting
-Build flexibility for your main character
-Simple, yet fun combat system and troop management
-Decisions kind of make a difference

CONS
-A shitload of buggs in original release, some of them are still there
-Mages are way stronger than other builds, kind of unbalanced
-Some missions about running are kind of "meh", since you cannot just stomp your enemies
-Actions could be faster, so the tempo of the game is better

Buy or Not? 
Defnitly buy on sale, if you like turned based strategy rpg with some cool storyline, the whole price is also worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079554112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1568636967}
review:
Somewhat confusing; there is usually little to no indication as to what you have to do in each level. Do I kill this monster, or is there some lever you can flip to kill it? Oh wait, I had to do some other thing on another level to do that. Oh well, I'd have to redo all 3 stages of this level to go back there. *proceeds to die five times* Ohhh, you can only kill this monster with fire spells. Too bad none of the characters have any. Better restart the entire game just to pick fire spells at the beginning. 
Yes, it's difficult, I understand that it's intentional, but when my only option is to restart all 10 hours of my progress through the game for a hope to finish a level, I'm not going to give this game a positive review.
On the upside, the level design is interesting, and there are a few objects that you can use (i.e. chandeliers which you can drop) to get the upper hand on enemies. Other than that, this game doesn't have much merit at all.

review:
I love turn-based games.  I finished the game on the hardest difficulty available.  Played the first Blackguards.

They really improved the game (vs the first one):
-  They removed the annoying spell casting failures.  
-  Fixed the 90%-100% chance to hit that misses. 
-  Fixed the annoying looking for teachers to level up

Maybe I appreciated the game because of the annoying experience I had with the first Blackguards.

TL/DR:  If you can get for cheap, try it.  If not, there are other better games out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052279426', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2757, 'last_played': 1501613749}
review:
Pretty fun game if you like figuring out fight mechanics in a challenging environment.

Most fights have an element of risk and reward with bonus objectives e.g. chests, trap placements, chokepoints and strategic locations to hold etc.

You will spend some time screwing up initially but once you got the flow and start steamrolling the enemies, it feels good :)

Combat may start to bore when the enemies start piling up on the screen and you have to wait for each of them to act their turns. This could go up to 12+ enemies and at some stage it could be hella annoying trying to wait out each turn, especially having to endure the annoying buzz, deathblow animations and sound of the fucking annoying insect troops. The Lv4 freeze spell helps you clear the board fast, but with the unfortunate side effect of slowing their animations to half resulting in longer wait time between turns.

Your dialogue choices will affect your companions' strengths and affinities. Certain dialogue cues will either turn them good or evil, and some choices have effects that will benefit their combat abilities (e.g. help your mage rediscover his ambition to rule, and his spell power/regeneration/resistance increases).

Certain enemies/prisoners will reveal their secrets via the right dialogue choices. Keep a lookout for hints that will help you make the correct dialogue choice, my only gripe is sometimes I know the correct answer to persuade a prisoner, but I do not know whether which dialogue path the answer is hidden in and there is no "Return" option (you get 3 options when integorrating prisoners - Intimidate, Lie, and Make An Offer - which can be pretty confusing).

Kinda like the choices we can make during the ending; would be nice if the developers throw in some vids to show us the effects of our end game actions and their impact on the citizens.

Overall, pretty decent game to pass time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105301586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1563, 'last_played': 1500842132}
review:
Ich kann dem Spiel keinen Daumen runter geben. Ich kann es f√ºr den vollen Preis nicht empfehlen aber im Sale, und wenn ihr den ersten Teil gemocht habt, kann es ein paar Stunden langeweile sehr gut vertreiben.

Warum k√∂nnt ihr nachfolgend lesen.


Kurze Zusammenfassung:

Pro:
- gute Vertonung
- Hauptcharakter
- mehrere M√∂glichkeiten f√ºr den Hauptcharakter Entscheidungen zu treffen
- taktische Freiheiten (nutzbare Umgebung)
- stellenweise richtig knackige Abschnitte
- umfangreiche M√∂glichkeiten Helden zu skillen
- viele verschiedene Waffen und R√ºstungssets (nur f√ºr meinen Geschmack zu viel f√ºr Magier?!)
- KI kann richtig schlau sein
- begrenzte Anzahl an S√∂ldnern k√∂nnen in K√§mpfe mitgenommen werden 


Contra:
- geringe Spielzeit
- unendlich spawnende Gegner
- (daraus resultierend) stellenweise Abschnitte, die nicht durch Taktik sondern nur durch Gl√ºck erfolgreich abgeschlossen werden k√∂nnen
- KI kann aber auch gar nicht funktionieren
- zu viele Gegner in einem Lv ziehen die K√§mpfe ungemein in die L√§nge bis jeder seinen Zug gemacht hat



Und nun ins Detail:


W√ºrde gerne einen direkten Vergleich zum Vorg√§nger ziehen. Aber der Zeitraum zwischen den Sessions ist einfach zu gro√ü gewesen.

Das Erste, was mir allerdings gleich aufgefallen ist, ist der Gr√∂√üenunterschied der beiden Teile. 

Habe jedes Spiel nur 1x durchgespielt. Bin bei Teil 1 auf gut 49 Std. gekommen und bei Teil 2 gerade mal auf knapp 24 Std (davon d√ºrfen sogar noch 3 Std. abgezogen werden, da ich diese Zeit wiederholen musste als mir zu sp√§t aufgefallen ist, dass das automatische Speichern nicht mehr funktioniert hatte (hab mich zu sehr drauf verlassen^^) - ging nach reload aber wieder).

Wenn man Ingame einen Blick auf die Karte wirft, sieht man den Grund f√ºr die geringe Spielzeit. Ca. 1/3 der Karte kann gar nicht erst bereist werden. Also entweder (spekulation) wurde das Geld knapp oder es waren DLCs geplant, die es nie gegeben hat.



Aber nun zur√ºck zum Spiel.

Der Hauptcharakter, Cassia, ist mMn echt super geworden. Ein Anti-Held mit einer bitteren Vorgeschichte, der sich (pers√∂nlich und je nach Entscheidungen) im Verlauf des Spiels zum guten oder schlechten entwickeln kann.

Gebiete k√∂nnen Erobert werden und St√§dte bieten dann neue S√∂ldner und H√§ndler. Der "Feind" versucht allerdings stellenweise, Gebiete wieder zur√ºck zu erobern. Diese m√ºssen dann verteidigt werden. Dabei k√∂nnen Fallen gelegt werden um den Gegner effektiv ein oder zwei Beine zu stellen.

Bei K√§mpfen kann die Umgebung aktiv genutzt werden. Sumpfgas kann z.B. mit Feuer zur Explosion gebracht oder Hornissennester mit einem geziehlten Pfeilschuss auf Gegner fallen gelassen werden.

Es gibt Abschnitte, die mMn einfach nur unfair sind. Selbst wenn man die Schwierigkeit auf leicht setzt. Dadurch, dass manche Gegner so viele Felder besetzen wie ein Durchgang breit ist, und diese Gegner immer wieder neu spawnen, ohne dass man eine Chance hat √ºberhaupt einen davon zu legen, kommt man mit Taktik nicht mehr weit.

Diese unendlich spawnenden Gegner sind vor allem dann extrem nervig, wenn man mit dem t√∂ten einfach nicht mehr hinterher kommt und das Gebiet erst dann abgeschlossen ist, wenn alle Gegner beseitigt wurden.

√úber die KI l√§sst sich streiten. Manchmal war sie echt fies (versteinern eines Charakters im unm√∂glichsten Moment), manchmal aber auch total dumm (Gegner l√§uft Planlos umher ohne anzugreifen oder sich Deckung zu suchen).

Sehr viele Gegner in einem Gebiet ziehen die K√§mpfe k√ºnstlich in die L√§nge. Klar muss jeder seinen Zug machen, aber bei 15+ Gegnern muss man doch sehr lange warten bis man wieder am Zug ist. Das kann auf dauer extrem nervig werden.


Sollte mir noch etwas einfallen werde ich es nachtragen. Das wars aber f√ºrs Erste.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011335956', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4156, 'last_played': 1498703103}
review:
An unworthy successor to BG1.  I liked the tweaks to the skill system, but this game was not as interesting as BG1, and it still has serious bugs over two years after its release.

I bought BG2 for just few dollars on sale because I had enjoyed the original.  The thing is, it's not about the money but the experience.  Having finished the game, I wish I'd spent the time playing something else -- something more fun and less frustrating.  Unexplained quirks and bugginess spoiled the experience. 

If you want to save a certain sympathetic NPC, you must sacrifice something important before the final battle, just to keep that option open.  I did that, but had to replay the final battle because the first time it simply would not not end.  One enemy unit had been permanently petrified and could not be killed.  I restarted and was careful not to let that happen.  The battle still would not end unless I killed the last surviving enemy, which I had to keep alive or that sympathetic NPC would die.  When the battle didn't end, I thought maybe I had to "subdue" that enemy by taking him to zero health.  No, that triggered the end but also cost the life of the person I was trying to save.  

The epilogue was buggy too.  Naurim was alive at the end of the final battle, but conspicuously absent from the epilogue, and I did not get the achievement for his survival.  Somehow I got both the achievements for Zurburan being evil AND good, even though I'd only chosen the good options (it's not like he flipped during the course of the game). 

Character development choices were also unclear.  Apparently unlocking an NPC's potential, such as fueling Naurim's rage to gain combat bonuses, counts as turning him evil.  I figured a little fire in the belly would be good for a warrior, but no that's "evil".

Some battles chain right into another battle without a chance to re-equip.  That's fine, but you never know when that will happen.  Should I use my poison in this fight or save it for a possible chained-into battle?  I ended up hardly using expendables because I kept saving them. 

Too much frustration, too little satisfaction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024965861', 'num_games_owned': 200, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1262, 'last_played': 1498592161}
review:
Unengaging.

COMBAT
Don't get me wrong: The tactical hexgrid turn based combat is excellent, scrathing that itch strategists/tacticians feel with new bland games. The varied type of maps is [b]good[/b], very gimmicky, with most of the time each map having some sort of environmental hazards that can be used for/against the player, making battles more than just strength but also a puzzle of sorts.
But [b]it lacks:[/b]
[list]
[*] Some sort of surrender option to enemies (very few times they try to leave combat, even if overpowered and outnumbered). It bores to hunt down the last one.
[*] Quicker battles. Combatants deal average damage per hit. With most of the time 8 in each side, combat can be dragging and unappealing.
[*] Better UI: Range of spells and line-of-sight are hit or miss. My Zurbaran became an archer so I could use the ranged weapon LOS/UI to help me with spells. Characters with negative HP stay in battle for 3 (?) rounds before leaving, but I know this because I played BG 1. If its wrong, worse: Game should offer better explanation.

STORY
I couldn't pay much importance to the revenge of Cassia over her husband. The character is a blank slate when presented to the player, so the player have a hard time attaching to her. The catacombs mission could help, but doesn't. Played because of the BG 1 trio, but they became just a shadow of what they were.
I tried to play a mad woman, and I think it could be awesome, but I went to the goodie one in the end. I can see where the differences would show, and is way better than the false dichotomy of recent games that only change the color of your picture but the end result is the same.

[b]The game is good for its tactical combat, but lacks story to keep the player interested in the events aside the battles themselves.[/b] If you like games for its challenges and see combat as a puzzle of sorts, this game is for you. If you want a rich story about the revenge of a woman against her husband, you'll find it severely lacking.

review:
= 2017/06/10 =
This is what you get for your hard earned $$, or your fathers/mothers/grandparents $$.

Pre-made heroes. But gives you a lot of Adventure Points (AP) during the tutorial so you can build her as you wish.
Spell caster or non-spell caster class. (main heroine starts as a spell caster)
6 melee weapons : Daggers, Sword/Saber, Axe/Mace, Spear, 2-handed sword, 2-handed bash (no more rapier/foil, staves)
3 ranged weapons : Bow, Crossbow, Throwing
Left/Right hand slot : One-hand weapon + shield, Dual wield, 2-Handed weapon
Armor slots : Head, Chest Legs, Hands, Feet, Waist (for belts to put items for combat)
There are no attributes, such as strength, dexterity, constitution, charisma, etc as in Blackguards 1.
Vitality (Hit Points), Endurance, Astral Power (Mana)
Skill have no pre-requisite, so you can learn whatever you want (part 1 needed certain attribute points for certain skills).
8 talents : Body control, Will power, Perception, Traps, Warcraft, Animal Lore, Human Lore, Arcane Lore
24 spells : Each spell has 4 tiers. Most 4th tier has a different effect (for example, Tier 1~3 Cold Shock would cold shock an enemy, tier 4 Cold Shock does it to the whole map)
14 Special Maneuvers : From Power Blow to Tripple Shot. (active skills)
12 Special Abilities : 38 including sub-abilities (for example Vitality 1->Vitality 2->Vitality 3) (passive skills)

[b] The below is a personal review of the game, you may feel totally opposite! [/b]

Blackguards 2 keeps on getting in my mind and I want to help those who wants to try this game.
I must get this out of my system.

After playing Blackguards 1, I decided to give Blackguards 2 a try.
Hint hint, this is giving Daedalic Entertainment another chance.
Because I really like the graphics, how equipment changes the looks, skill animations look nice.

The main problem in part 1 of this game is exactly in part 2!
The funny thing is, in part 1, I would see a high % hit chance which missed most of the time.
Here they "changed it" so that a 0% hit chance hit 100% of the time.
I thought at first, perhaps they made a mistake to indicate 100% as 0%, but nope. There is a 100% hit chance and a 0% hit chance, both hitting 100%.

As said in part 1 review, no one likes to be lied to. Whether it be in real life or in a game.
This happens in the beginning of the game (as it probably is a display/coding error).
And it got me wondering if the developers understand numbers as we players do????
It was a turn off from the start as it caused me many hours of frustration in part 1.

I will probably keep playing to see the ending, but definetly not for the enjoyment as I can foretell a great many hours of frustration heading my way...

PS: Make the right choice, we only live once

author: {'steamid': '76561198012023418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1332, 'last_played': 1503747637}
review:
I would love to recommend this game, but unfortunately there are just too many bugs and glitches. If you read the Steam community discussion page here : https://steamcommunity.com/app/249650/discussions/0/496879865902328863/ you will see that the game has conflicts with most major graphics cards. Eventually the system lockups make the game unplayable, which is a pity because...
The game itself: This is a fairly simple game where you recruit team membes, upgrade abilities and weaponry and eke your way across a map towards the final goal. Each step on the map requires you to decide on the best group of companions and mercenaries to use and (if successful) rewards you with item upgrades, mercenary upgrades, new companions or gold. It is a really enjoyable experience and the storyline is interesting, with some cool moral decisions thrown in.

TL;DR If your system will run this game properly, get it!

review:
There is plenty of things that go wrong in this game. So, let me tell you the good one :

BUT, if you ask me, it has been a long time since i've seen a so unbalanced game. OR a so narrow-minded design. There a few if not only one way to win some fights. I mean, if you do try an exotic build, you are fucked (except if you are extremely lucky)

For me, they didn't learn from their mistakes.

review: Whole game feels like Blackguards 1.5. A lot of assets and elements appear to be copied from first game, though most of changes between these two games are positive and clean the title from the redundant and annoying elements first game was full of. Story is much better, Cassia's madness and lust for revenge create deep and dark mood, something I could not find in the first Blackguards installment. With this said, one thing did not change - game is full of bugs and unfriendly shortcomings. From messed up hitboxes to soft freezes, game offers a lot of chances to get annoyed and loose the will to play. After 13 hours of enjoying the story and hating the gameplay bugs, game decided to freeze on me each time Tykates battle starts. After next 5 hours of digging through the internet and re-installing the game, the issue persists. Story blocker that does not allow you to continue gameplay without rolling back to much older saves is pretty much a killer for any game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996426001', 'num_games_owned': 621, 'num_reviews': 327, 'playtime_forever': 1902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1898, 'last_played': 1485809635}
review:
This sequel maintain most of the first game's strenght and flaws. You can find my my review of the firts game below (in case you didn't played it), most of the cons/pros stay untouched except: the campaign turned from a quest-based storyline to some sort of total war strategic map (massively simplified) where you have to choose what city to attack reducing the overall degree of freedom and removing any sign of sidequests. The combat system changed a bit, the mayor difference is that magic spells no longer have chances to succeed, simpliying planning and tactics; the character development system has been simplified but it didn't lost the freedom of choice. the character rooster has been reduced.

overall my opinion on this game is the same as the first one: buy it if you're a rpg tactics enthusiast but never at full price


BLACKGUARDS 1 REVIEW:
When I started to play the game I was surprised that it have so many negative reviews, it looked like a very good game at the beginning, but then its flaws bacame evident.

pros: 
-good storyline
-interesting side quests
-huge freedom on character development
-decent graphic
-interesting combat system
-interesting magic/abilities

cons:
-freedom on character development can turn against you later in the game. there's no clue on which way you should get skills and abilities and you can come across certains fights where you absolutely need a certain skill to win or it will take a lot of luck. this is quite frustrating. expecially if you don't have a savegame old enought to learn the ability you need.
-inventory items are uninteresting: you only get good stuff from a few side quest in the entire game, merchants around the world only sell cheap/bad stuff. also I think the weight of the stuff (especially supplies) is unbalanced.
-major and minor bugs could prevent you from completing some side-quests
-unnecessary loading times


in the end I can recomend this game only if you are a rpg tactics enthusiast but never at full price.
