author: {'steamid': '76561198006176581', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 3037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2885, 'last_played': 1484820257}
review:
When I played the first Blackguards, I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I would. I do not normally play strategy games, and I played Blackguards because it is in the same universe as the point and click adventures, The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav and Memoria. After I had beaten the previously noted titles, I decided it was finallly time to play Blackguards 2...and I absolutely loved it.
Bear in mind that I am not an experienced strategist. However, I loved this game. The only thing I can compare it to is the first Blackguards game and I find it a step up all around. Instead of leveling up, you gain AP points and you spend them on different skill trees. I find the skill trees much simpler to use in Blackguards 2. You also see the results very quickly when you learn new abilities. There are many ways to distribute points in weapon ability, spells, and unique ablilities and attributes that you can make any kind of character you want. For example, my Cassia is a dual wielder of swords and daggers but she can cripple enemies with her spells and be dangerous in close range battle. I guess that would make her a kind of battle mage....I found that my characters could be anything I wanted them to be, and that made the game really fun for me.
Now the story and the main character. In Blackguards 1, you create a hero from scratch. In Blackguards 2, you play Cassia - a compelling and determined young heroine.....who is being driven by revenge and madness...mostly madness due to betrayal and  she has been poisoned by spiders. She is a fascinating protagonist who you can turn into literally anything. Also, your actions throughout the story with her companions will shape what kind of campaign you will have and what kind of ruler you will become. Be careful, because your actions can cost you more than your sanity...it can cost you those that are closest to you. In the game, Cassia finds herself betrayed by her husband and thrown into a dungeon, where she is left to rot. Cassia's husband has siezed power over all the lands and believes that his wife is out of the way. What follows is a Kill Bill fantasy story, as you start at one point of the map and slowly widdle down at his defenses until you reach the palace. There are multiple ways to go about the map but in the end you are hoping to reach an end. 
The game is beautiful. The soundtrack fits the atmosphere and the battles. I found the combat to be very smooth. I like TBS because it gives me time to plan, and this game has wonderful set pieces in which the battles take place. 
The ending is what you make it to be so you only have yourself to congratulate or blame. There is definite replay value since missions, side quests, interrogations can all be done in different ways. The final battle can be done in different ways. While I am happy with the ending that I got, I know I will be going back for a darker story. 
Personally, I really enjoyed this game. If you are someone who doesn't normally jump into the strategy genre I definitely recommend this one. It has great strategy, a compelling story, and it is an accomplishment to finish. I don't plan on launching into more of this kind of fantasy strategy because I just love The Dark Eye universe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112810429', 'num_games_owned': 2594, 'num_reviews': 578, 'playtime_forever': 4063, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4063, 'last_played': 1484024685}
review:
The second volume of the strange turn-based combat RPG title, Blackguards, feels... quite different from the first game. The developers made a huge step from the classic role-playing game (which, honestly, wasn't the strongest point of the first Blackguards) to the tactical simulator of a lord with numerous mercenaries, conquering the country. You with your army of swordsmen, spearmen and archers, are traveling from one point to another, on the map of Southern Empire. Quite similar to the first game. But now you perform sieges to gain access to every point on the map (along with other bonuses, such as new items in shops and powerups for your men).

I liked the story of the first game, even with the fact it was badly performed in so many minor features, that all the impression to the end was just growing boredom... despite the good writing in the base of it. Well, the new story, written just as well as the first one, has an even lower role in the second game, and the game itself is quite short... So, the boredom of later acts of the first game now is very unlikely. And - I repeat that again - it's a good story if only a little distracting at the very start.

As of the main game element, turn-based battles, they are certainly evolved above the first game, in a good way. All the maps now are big, but none of them is so much frustrating, as a poisonous cave from the first Blackguards. There are a bigger variety of enemies now, thanks to chimerology, and its bosses (so-called Creators), which you need to bend over to make sure you'll win this war. And, as I've mentioned already, numerous nameless fighters on your side, aiding your basic team of adventurers, along with setting traps on the map, and different battle modes (like onslaught, infiltration raid or defense) - all that gives you a good variety of playtime.

Does it sound that the second Blackguards are better than the first game? Oh, well. It's all not worth the comparison, as the first game is a classic RPG with turn-based combat, and the second - is a game of turn-based battles with RPG elements. The Blackguards 2 is smoother in play than the Blackguards 1. It's not losing the gamer's curiosity after some time, it's more stable in terms of gaming interest. It's the game which you are really want to finish, to see the outcome.

Now, does the Blackguards 2 worth its price? Is it a good game you need to buy? No. Not quite. See, I'm always trying to protect not-AAA projects, and especially I'm fond of turn-based games. Just check my other reviews, and you'll see how tender I am when it comes to such games.

But, for a question, is it a good game, I'll have to say it's quite mediocre, like 6/10. The price of Blackguards is higher than its value. Even with the bundles, with discounts... All the good stuff you'll get there, you can get elsewhere. Either the price will be better, or the quality will be higher or both... So - no, for the current price of 35 golds, it's a no go. Yeah, the stability issues, the balance was fixed after early 2015 (you may see some disappointed people who tried to play it then). But the price is still too high for this product.

Blackguards 2 bietet ein Rollenspiel mit einer guten Mischung aus Taktik- und Rollenspiel, welches sich der Pen&Paper-Vorlage vom Vorg√§nger Das Schwarze Auge: Blackguards bedient.

Zun√§chst k√§mpfen wir uns mit der Protagonistin durch die Tutorial-Missionen. Dabei fallen schon einige Verbesserungen im Kampfsystem auf, welche eine bessere Kontrolle zulassen. Dazu z√§hlt auch der √ºberarbeitete Skilltree, welcher eine wesentlich freiere Entwicklung des Charakters zul√§sst, angefangen von einer Nahk√§mpferin, bis hin zur Hexe.

Mit der neuen √úbersichtskarte k√∂nnen wir erstmals selbst entscheiden, wo wir unseren Rivialen zuerst angreifen, die geradlinige Kampagne ist Vergangenheit. Mehrere Wege f√ºhren uns zur Hauptstadt, welche es zu erobern gilt und jeder Weg f√ºhrt uns an unterschiedlichen Schaupl√§tzen vorbei. Jedes eingenommene Gebiet bietet uns Vorteile und dr√§ngt Marwans Armee langsam zur√ºck. Au√üerdem vergr√∂√üern wir unsere Gruppe langsam, denn neben Cassia, k√∂nnen wir im Laufe der Geschichte die Kontrolle √ºber Naurim, Takate und Zurbaran, den 3 aus dem Vorg√§nger bekannten Charakteren, √ºbernehmen. Auch k√∂nnen wir bis zu 9 weitere S√∂ldner anheuern, welche sich in die Klassen Hexe, Assassine, Speertr√§ger, Bogensch√ºtze und Schwerttr√§ger aufteilen. Diese k√∂nnen wir auch noch upgraden, was sie zu perfekten Mitk√§mpfern macht.

Die Defensivphase gestaltet sich dabei wesentlich einfacher, als die Offensivphase. W√§hrend wir nur die Stellung halten m√ºssen, helfen uns vor allem aufgestellte Fallen dabei genau dies zu erreichen. Gehen wir hingegen in den Angriff, m√ºssen wir eine Vielzahl von Aufgaben erf√ºllen, wie beispielsweise Zug√§nge versprerren, oder √∂ffnen, oder Gefangene retten. Mit Tastendr√ºck werden benutzbare Gegenst√§nde farblich angezeigt, was die Interaktion mit der Umgebung erleichtert. So k√∂nnen wir durch das Umlegen eines Hebels beispielsweise Tore √∂ffnen, oder Seile zerschneiden, damit Kronleuchter auf die Gegner niederkrachen. Dabei kann man aber auch mal schnell die √úbersicht verlieren und wird bei der Vielzahl an Aufgaben einfach vom Gegner √ºberrannt.

Die K√§mpfe selbst laufen klassisch ab: Alle Einheiten haben bestimmte Aktionspunkte und k√∂nnen der Reihe nach diese verbrauchen, um sich zu bewegen und/oder eine Aktion auszuf√ºhren. Je nach Initiativewert der Einheit beginnt jene, mit dem h√∂chsten Wert. Generell ist hier eine wesentliche Verbesserung zu sp√ºren, was die K√§mpfe nochmals spannender macht und weniger Frustmomente, im Vergleich zum Ersten Teil, verursacht.

Erw√§hnenswert ist, dass wir kein Gewichtlimit mehr haben. Neben dem K√§mpfen, ruhen wir uns im Feldlager aus, verwalten Waffen und R√ºstungen, f√ºhren Gespr√§che und planen die n√§chsten Schritte. Die wichtigsten Charaktere und Anlaufpunkte sind hier zu Hause, wodurch wir nicht st√§ndig von Stadt zu Stadt laufen m√ºssen, um den gew√ºnschten Trainer, oder das ben√∂tigte Gesch√§ft wieder zu finden. Trotzdem lohnt sich ein Blick in die St√§dte, um zus√§tzliche Missionen zu erhalten, welche uns einen Bonus, oder Set-Gegenst√§nde geben k√∂nnen.

Eine nette Idee sind auch die Gefangenen, welche wir bei Eroberungen machen. Diese k√∂nnen wir in Multiple-Choice-Dialogen verh√∂ren und anschlie√üend √ºber ihr Schicksal befinden: Sie entweder laufen lassen oder aber hinrichten. Je nachdem wie wir richten, erhalten wir ein anderes Ende, entweder als g√ºtige Herrin, oder als blutr√ºnstige Eroberin. Doch zu viel Bosartigkeit kann unsere eigenen Einheiten √ºberlaufen lassen, genau wie zu viel Gutherzigkeit die begnadeten Gefangenen direkt zum Gegner wieder laufen k√∂nnen. W√§hlt also weise.

[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Gro√üe Kampagne
    [*]Viele Nebenmissionen

[b]Fazit:[/b]

Blackguards 2 ist ein gutes Rundenstrategiespiel, mit viel Umfang. Die Fehler vom ersten Teil werden gut verbessert und schaffen dadurch ein sehr guten Nachfolger. Zum perfekten Spiel fehlt dennoch ein letzter Schritt. Das rundenbasierte Spielen muss einem gefallen, aber in die Rolle des B√∂sen zu schl√ºpfen macht echt Spa√ü und bringt einen meist eher unbekannten Einblick in das Spiel. author: {'steamid': '76561198068133001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2426, 'last_played': 1484024783}
review:
I don't understand why this game has mixed reviews.  This is one of the great TBS (Turn-Based Strategy) games out there, and I play a lot of TBS games.  

- This game has some of the largest most complex battle maps and features.  It's not your standard square, strategy is required.  Split your forces or keep them consolidated?  The maps are different for every quest and battle, you can interact with the environment, and enemies are hidden beyond your vision and behind objects

- Character classes really matter in this game.  A ranged unit in this game can do a lot of damage, and often, can stay untouched.  Some characters can be good at ranged combat and melee.  You choose for the most part.  Magic has its place as well

- Rich RPG features.  There are main characters in the game that are part of the story...from the first game if you played it.  There are a few paths you can take your multiple characters down.  If you earn enough XP, you can have some really heavy hitters strong in various areas creating a well rounded group

- You don't manage cities on the campaign map, but you do speak with characters, trade, and travel between cities; the story is fun and the dialogue quirky.  There is an "Army" you can upgrade as the campaign progresses

- Weapons:  this game has some of the best weapons and RPG attack upgrades I've seen in a TBS game.  You can change every type of equipment your characters wear, the type of weapons they weild (more than one), and what types of special attacks you choose to give them when spending XP.  

If you like TBS, buy this game.  The mixed reviews are BS.  I also recommend Legens of Eisenwald (feels a little odd at the start, but a great game), and for some, Might & Magic (that game is more macro with minimal RPG elements and basic battle maps, the game focuses more on the campaign.  The latest Might & Magic is excellent), and of course, The Banner Saga is fun and beautiful.  

ENJOY!  ~ Steve

author: {'steamid': '76561198011965365', 'num_games_owned': 2442, 'num_reviews': 2080, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1483170245}
review: Seems that  Daedalic wanted to facilitate some elements of the game but added a management component. The simplification concerns mainly the whole system of skills, abilities and upgrades. The characters of the game do not level up but earn experience points that we can spend in five different categories after winning every fight. There are power-ups for weapons for general skills spells special moves to be exploited in battle and passive skills. The real heart of the game rather than the management of the characters is given by the turn-based combat characterized by classic hexagons for movement and many new features compared to the first chapter. Arenas and game environments appear more pleasant, large and full of interactive elements such as bridges, traps, objects to break and switches to activate. Although the success rate of a spell is now much more credible (in the first chapter even an attack on two failed). Ultimately Blackguards 2 is a sequel good and superior to the first chapter a bit 'from all points of view. Less confusing, more dynamic gameplay richer management elements less frustrating in the fighting. A blend of RPG and turn-based strategy, with a plot and a setting is not trivial but a calibration of difficulty not calibrated at best, clashes sometimes soporific and poor graphics.

Nach jeder gewonnenen Schlacht k√∂nnt ihr eure Charaktere in den wirklich riesigen Charakterb√§umen aufleveln, mit Ausr√ºstung ausstatten, Objekte kaufen oder Dialoge f√ºhren. Die Story an sich finde ich bisher wirklich sch√∂n und abwechslungsreich erz√§hlt. Die Charaktere sind HERVORRAGEND gesprochen und tragen viel zur Atmosph√§re bei (auch die deutschen Sprecher!).
Die K√§mpfe sind, wie gesagt, rundenbasiert und wirklich kniffelig, schon auf normalem Schwierigkeitsgrad (ich spiele eigentlich jedes Spiel immer auf schwer oder h√∂her, aber aus Erfahrung wei√ü ich schon, dass das hier keine so gute Idee ist). Mir pers√∂nlich gef√§llt sehr gut, dass man beim K√§mpfen wirklich vorrausdenken muss. Da gibt es zum Beispiel eine Runde, in der man durch K√§mpfen unm√∂glich gewinnen kann. Will man gleichzeitig noch die auf der Karte verteilten Sch√§tze einsammeln, wird das Ganze schon richtig kniffelig und ist nur durch geschickten Einsatz von Fallen, Kisten und Engstellen zu schaffen. author: {'steamid': '76561197992229015', 'num_games_owned': 1184, 'num_reviews': 778, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 789, 'last_played': 1478224060}
review:
Edit: I felt this was important: I did not encounter any bugs. And the game only crashed once during a mission load. I think that's pretty positive at least.

I have to admit I am extremely disappointed after Blackguards 1. The successor fails in almost every way I can think of:

- Length: The game is about half as long as the first one. Finished it in about 13 hours.

- Story: This is mostly subjective, but in my opinion, the first game's plot was much much much better. There were nuances, more interesting conversations, etc. This story on the other hand just gets more irritating by the minute.

- Quests: Side quests are completely gone. Instead you are tasked with capturing about 15 or so POIs. Every 3rd battle or so your enemy will counter attack and try to get one POI back from you. Also, at certain intervals you will have to complete other missions before you can continue your conquest.

- Combat: I would have called this an improvement at first. The combat system itself is a bit better, however, it is still lacking visibility. What makes this negative is the boring nature of combat in this game. For starters, you can't start as a ranged class, because you have to fight your way out of a dungeon on your own. Later in the game most battles have endlessly spawning enemies, which just makes the battles extremely annoying and boring, especially when you have to deal with 20 enemies at the same time and wait for each to make their bloody move. No matter that they can't even get to you anyway...I mean, this game takes 13 hours to complete...and of those 13 hours, 90% are battles...and of those battles 70% of the time is spent waiting for the enemy...
The boss battles, however, are actually quite ok for the most part.

- UI: Still horrible.

- RPG elements: Some decisions you can make sound interesting on paper, but in the end nothing really has an effect on the story or the game. You can upgrade your mercenary forces now, which means you can have up to 10 or so units fighting for you at the same time. These mercenary forces are standard boring troops, however. Only later do you get more "hero" units that actually feel compelling to use. You also get a fucking giant, which is utterly useless, because by the time you get him, there are barely any battles he can even take part anymore...yaaaay.

- Skills: Pretty much the same from BG 1, but trimmed down, which is actually not a bad thing. Why you need to level a weapon to 100, however, is beyond me. Apart from that spells now finally always have a 100% hit chance!

- Graphics: Exactly the same engine and effects as in BG 1...shame, because the engine is still badly optimized and the game slows down even on powerful machines. Also, still micro stutters from time to time, but not as bad as in BG 1.

- Sound: Voice acting is as good as in the first game. Too bad the actors don't get much to say once you're about 50% through the game *sigh*. Another wasted opportunity.

- Items: It seems a bit better than in BG 1. Item sets are quite meaningful. On the other hand, one has to wonder why you would get 3 parts of a set after 1 mission and the missing part for the set bonus (which makes the other 3 useless) several hours later from a completely different *side quest*...moronic.

- Misc: Gold, arrows, potions, healing, resting, wounds...everything is completely inconsequential, since your party is automatically rested and healed after every fight and all consumables are pretty much always in stock. Gold should also not be a problem. I didn't even have to replace my main's items, since they were so good to begin with for a ranged damage dealer, which is once again the most devastating "class", which can dish out from 40 to 60 damage with a triple shot easily, which means one shotting most enemies.

All in all I would suggest you play BG 1 and leave it at that. The sequel neither improves the game play nor does it continue the story in any meaningful way. After having beaten the Nameless One, your heroes have apparently wandered off and either gone mad, absolutely greedy or become a slave for whatever reason. You can't even choose your own character. You have to play a female, an insane female. Everyone is just bloody insane in this game, that seems to be the thing. You are, your companions are (Zurbaran is the most sane out of all of them), the mercenaries are, Marwan is, the Creators are...everyone is just bonkers and doesn't have any real motives. There are no great twists, no interesting characters. Just bad writing and boring combat.

Do yourself a favour and just ignore this one. I got it for "free" as part of a magazine (which I obviously paid for). Otherwise I might have never installed it anyway. And I was hyped after having played the first game. I loved the story and the combat was for the most part ok. You had to adapt to different situations. Here, it's 95% the same tactics. For example. you have to fight some skeletons 1 time...1 time only. And you can really just ignore them in this battle. Every other battle any weapon will do...meh. Not a terrible game for a discount, but a bad sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056541314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1762, 'last_played': 1475793387}
review:
Blackguards 2 contains almost nothing new, but represents an interesting mix of good features of other games: strategic map with mission selection reminding of Warlords Battlecry 3, inter-mission scenes and dialoges recall of Starcraft 2 and tactical battle system similar to Expeditions: Conquistador (I had not played Blackguards 1 prior to its sequel).
I liked the game but for new players I would suggest one trick I should have been sticking to from the beginning: set difficulty to easy (unless you adore this combat system)  and - optionally - try to play through without a single failed mission as a compensation for easiness. Easy difficulty will allow you to play missions faster which otherwise consume too much time due to unchangably slow animation. I would not say that battles are boring, however this game is about story, characters, dialogues and strategic choices in the first place - and they are really good; I often had a feeling that battles just distract me from this core part of the game. Moreover, there is no actual character generation and this may drastically decrease "battle immersion" and overall interest for some players.
As for people who enjoyed Blackguards 1, they may dislike the sequel due to the above-mentioned and overall simplification of tactical mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004692310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1226, 'last_played': 1475192374}
review:
I'll start this review by saying two things, 1) you really should play Blackguards 1 before playing this; it helps understand the characters and the mechanics of the game. 2) I've only been playing it recently and have experienced no bugs or crashes, which suggests that after a year in the wild they've fixed a lot of issues

That said, this is quite different to BG1 in a few ways, the simplest comparison is that BG1 was Dragon Age: Origins and BG2 is Dragon Age 2; not in terms of story quality as I think they are quite comparable but in terms of mechanics. BG2 has been streamlined considerably (to some people's annoyance) and so if you've played BG1 it is at first a bit of a shock, but it is essentially the same system just more Spartan / focussed.

I completed BG1 and went straight on to this game; the first game had a horrible learning curve and was restricted by the fact that in most fights you only had 3 - 5 characters against usually many more. In BG2 this is resolved in quite a clever way. In BG1 you jumped around points on the map trying to find out if a new side quest had popped up with someone you had previously talked to. Whilst in BG2 the map is laid out before you and you can see exactly what each place will offer. In BG1 you spoke with your characters only at specific moments, always initiated by the game. In BG2 you have a camp where you can interact with your party, but only after an encounter.

They are different games but there is one constant, all battles are resolved on a hex grid with turn based combat; in BG1 you had to juggle using potions and resting in between fights; in BG2 you start every fight at full life (and mana) meaning that every fight is more of a challenge between you and the AI. Both games can punish you if you have selected the 'wrong' skills or, more often than not, failed to improve a skill to the right level (I'm looking at you cure poison).

If you enjoyed BG1 then I would pause and consider what parts did you really enjoy? If you liked bits that I say have changed maybe wait until an 80% sale, if it still sounds good then just go ahead.
At the end of the day if you like turn based combat games you'll probably be entertained, for a little while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975421288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1540, 'last_played': 1473626571}
review:
It is an incredible shame that this game isn't highly rated, as the first game gets great reviews, yet this game is actually better, albeit shorter. I would recommend playing the first game first because it eases you into the way the game works, and also the extremely challenging combat. The first game was one of the best games I've played in a little over 30 years of gaming, but it had some shortcomings which this game amazingly manages to fix head on.

These Blackguards games are basically typical RPG's on paper, but they play differently. There is a story which is actually better than most RPG's I've played (and I've played probably 100), and the characters are exceptional. They are all voice acted too, and well. Combat is the highlight and focus of these games, and it is slow paced, turn based, very strategic, very tactical, and very challenging. Every battle can be won if you play well, but even experienced RPG gamers will likely need to attempt some missions twice. If you like deep and tactical combat, this is the best game I have ever found, and if anyone knows anything better, please send me a message! The nearest equivalent I can think of was Final Fantasy Tactics, in that each battle is very finely tuned to be challenging, and movement and positioning of your team is just as important as the spells and abilities they use on each turn. FFT was very popular and really well respected and one of my favorite games, but this game is better in every way. 

The only thing these games don't have that the average RPG gamer might want to know about, is exploration. There is no 1st or 3rd person walking around through forests looking for enemies or anything like that, instead you get a battle map of a country with various regions and cities, and you travel to them and get battles either in the cities or whilst travelling to them. I suppose if games like this could get the kinds of budgets the Elder Scrolls games get, there would be some exploration too, but this is an indie game so it can't have everything. But it still manages to have a lot, and what it does have it does extremely well. The itemization is fantastic, not so much in the first game but definitely in this sequel. There is a large variety of armor and weapons and there are sets you can wear which give bonuses. There are also dozens of usable items, not just potions but various traps and tools you can use in combat. Also the way you build up your characters with stats and spells is as good as it gets for RPG's. It uses an old rulebook which is an alternative to D&D and it is really deep and really good, and the game allows you to get really involved with lots of abilities and spells. The first game had a bit more customization as this sequel simplified one layer of this, but I don't think anything was lost with that, because you still get to focus on the various moves, spells and abilities, just without having to waste time tweaking stats to allow whichever ones you want to pick. 

Story, characters, dialogue, itemisation, and especially combat, this game is as good as any other game out there. It would probably be horrifying to the average action RPG player that dont want to try something different, but if you are someone who likes tactical RPG's, this is a must have game. I've loved Baldurs Gate 2, TOEE, all the Icewind Dale games, Summoner, Wizardry, Might & Magic, etc. but this game is my new love and comparable or better than most of those games. 

The first game is too, but the battle maps were just ok, the enemy types were repetitive, the itemisation was too limited, and hunting down needle in a haystack skill trainers was an unnecessary chore. This game improves all of those things significantly, the battle maps are bigger and more interesting here, and the enemies are too with huge bosses with great graphical touches. There are loads of items to choose from, and the tedium with trainers and finding gear etc. is all gone. 

I am aware most of the negative reviews these games get are because of the terrible bugs they had at release, and when I played the first game, even a long time after release, I suffered through a lot of really bad bugs. I even regularly had corrupt savegames which meant my last few saves would die and I had to recover one from further back which meant I had to replay an hour or more of the game... Really bad bugs, worse than most games, yet I still loved the game. I don't know what state it is in now, I assume pretty perfect by now. This game however I only played very recently and I didn't find ANY  bugs at all. I am sure there are some somewhere but it is a slick experience for me, so don't be put off by the negative reviews, they were surely very valid early on, but if you play the game now it is a great experience.

review:
Blackguards the first was a brilliant game with great characters and many more redeeming qualities. This installment although still decent has its let downs.

PROS
characters make a return although in my opinion some of them dont see like the same kind of character (and yes i understand that they would change due to what happened to them, but i also dont see them doing what they did... well not from the ending of the first one at least).

Great combat and the lack of the really "fair" dice system that was in the first game that always seemed rigged yet also at the same time awesome.

Great story although it has a lot of holes, and some weird... very weird aspects.

CONS

Seems to me to be a shorter game than the first.

New characters werent all that compelling.

Lack of story rich towns and scenes made me wander for a bit into other games before coming back and completing it.




Overall i would give it a 7/10 but the first one imo is better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155045661', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2092, 'last_played': 1471521984}
review:
For the first hour this felt like a badly developed version of the first game, which itself was decent but not fantastic by any means.  But once the story got going it became surprisingly addictive.  The story feels unique, it really feels like decisions you make impact on both how the story develops and on the gameplay (I'm not certain it does, but think it's very likely and either way it really pulls you in).  

The 3D-ness is slightly more distracting than impressive and combined with frequently having too many characters on a map the game can feel sluggish.  But again, the massive size of the battles and potential for strategem, perhaps initially frustrating, turns out to be really addictive.

And where the first game did shine, this one does too:
* In the range of abilities and effects available, with multiple ways to develop characters and multiple abilities that often play out very differently.  It includes a huge range of spells (if you consider in that levelled up spells are often quite different from the initial versions, and levelling up gives you access to each version), a decent range of melee abilities, a decent range of archery abilities, plus traps and throwable items.  And because you can usually combine at least two types of build in one character (eg. a melee character could turn out to be melee + archery, or melee + thrown weapons, or melee + traps, or melee + magic; etc), there's plenty of scope for variety and for just playing it your own way.
* And, to a slightly lesser extent, in some of the unique differences between maps.  It's not all just a wide hex field - there are different kinds of interactive objects, barrels and traps, narrow corridors, switches, hidden entrances, and more.  Some of the switch based maps are a little annoying, but they're rare.

Where the first was terrible, this made leaps and bounds of improvement:
* Powerful voice acting, particularly the narrating, and cutscenes.
* Maps, battles, and in-town interactions that really feel like part of the story.

Overall, slightly less variety in maps, and considerably shorter in gameplay than the original... but fully made up for in the epicness of both the maps/battles and the story and for really engaging you in that story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018005737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1469123312}
review:
Just completed my first play through and thought I'd give my verdict.

A few people mentioned extreme difficulty with some levels and I do agree.
There is a level very early on in which you are cornered and chased by > 20 enemies. 
However after a few failed attepts I realised the game was forcing me to escape and 
not just fight them all ( which, for these games I would always do). Once I realsed this I planned my traps to stop enemeis advancing at choke points and strategically placed arcane walls to block other choke points. From the point the game was a lot easier. Until the final battle.... wow

You have some flexibility with characters. Cassia can be anything you wish as she has access to all skill sets, I personally chose her to be an archer. The dwarf lacks the ability to learn magic and so I opted for a tank class. The mage guy is good and could be switched to another class. And the tribal guy, I made into a high damage high evasion class.

I saw a lot of posts about glitches and bugs. I didn't have a single crash or see any bugs. Maybe the game pauses at the end of a full round of turns, but the calculations have to be done. I guess the developers decided to just prioritise that and not thread it seperately. Not a massive issue.

Price wise: would I pay ¬£25 for this? No. Would I pay ¬£15 for this? yes. If the game was longer and had more skills etc./. I would pay the full price.

Overall it is very fun. I spent 16 hours playing this for 1 playthrough of the game

Pros:
-Good story
-Beautiful graphics
-Great skill sets for building fighters, mages, rogues, tanks and archers.
-hexagonal movement tiles
-The ability to wait after or before movement, giving you the chance to allow characters blocking you to move (very helpfull)

Cons:
-Could do with more weapons
-If magic isn't available you will find at the end of the game those characters have practically the same upgrades
-Needs more dedicated trees with bigger bonuses and bigger penalties.

review:

This game is not the same as blackguards 1 as many reviewers have already stated. I stupidely dismissed many of these claims prior to my purchase but I now fully agree with their reviews. The game is simply not fun which is a shame because I think that the tactical combat/gameplay is quite good, RPGs have been made that are similar to blackguards and I would much recommend them instead of this game (Pillars of eternity, Divinity Original Sin, Banner Saga, etc)

Save your money and play those RPGs instead

author: {'steamid': '76561198052352337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5400, 'last_played': 1468703269}
review:
This is the first review I've ever written for any game on steam, and it's really more for catharsis then anything else.  Where to begin...   The storyline for this game is amazing.  You follow the main hero Cassia as she seeks revenge against her enemies while spiraling into the depths of madness.  The combatis also on point.  Lots of options and tactics to use in battles.  When the game is "on" it's really "on"  

What kills it?  Why the non-recomendation?  Simple:  Daedalic have no concept of what makes a game fun.  Even with all these positives, this game will make you rage harder than anything From Software has ever produced.  Game difficulty is erratic, at best, and homicide inducing at worst. Daedlic must be run by alcholics...

Deadlic, please if you read this.  Please.  Please.  Please.  Play test your games...  not just for bugs, but ask your playtesters if they are having fun.  The system is great, stop dropping the ball on poor level design.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105226073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1766, 'last_played': 1468621606}
review:
Great Game!

Would be a pleasure to see a next part!

Positiv:

- Good balancing over all
- Well implemented Characters
- Interesting Story
- many different tactics are possible
- Story changes while progressing
- many different types of enemys
- Hight rate of individualisation
- Your decisions have impact on story progress

Negativ or Optimatizations for the next part (hehe):
- Monsters as Charcters in your party (Minotaurs f.e.)
- More content than 50 hours on hard
- No pre skilled Characters! (It will take you to enhance the given skills to not have wasted points)
- an additional class to play with (Shapeshifting / Summoning Druid maybe)
- Rotating Camera
- More optional Chests (hard to get ones)
- slightly more challange on harder difficulty levels, maybe due to the point above
- Warfare and so on just needed on one charcter to get infos (havent Skilled it, just read that you will need it on everyone when you want to get Infos every time) too much waste of points for optional information otherwise
- More different Equipment to enhance individualisation more over
- Focus more on controlling battle, instead of movemt (Takate Spidermap f.e.)

Anyway Thumbs up Team Daedalic Entertainment!
Can¬¥t wait to see part 3.

review:
Super Rollenspiel mit Rundentaktik!

Ich war schon von Teil 1 begeistert, aber Teil 2 hat vieles noch einmal verbessert.
Hier eine kurze Auflistung der Dinge, was neu ist, besser ist, und mir allgemein gefallen hat:

- Es gibt einige gr√∂√üere und umfangreichere K√§mpfe zu schlagen.
- Die K√§mpfe sind nun besser ausbalanciert und nun auch auf Stufe "Normal" wirklich f√ºr jedermann machbar.
- Helden sind ohne Hintergrundwissen wesentlich einfacher zu leveln
- einige umgestaltete Zauber passen nun besser zu den Arenak√§mpfen
- man hat die freie Auswahl bei der Eroberung der einzelnen Ortschaften
- zus√§tzliche, ausw√§hlbare Rekruten unterschiedlicher Klassen f√ºr die K√§mpfe
- viele kleine Entscheidungen sind zu treffen, die alle Auswirkungen auf die Geschichte haben
- die ganzen unterschiedlichen Enden sind Motivation f√ºr einen weiteren komplette Durchlauf, oder regen zum Laden eines Spielstandes ein

Die Vertonung ist wieder einmal richtig gut gelungen, die Grafik und Levelgestaltung ist an sich auch wirklich nett, nur h√§tte man die Engine ein wenig mit knackigeren Texturen aufpeppen k√∂nnen. Die Grafikkarte wird so kaum gefordert.
Die Steuerung ist wie immer super, das Ringmen√º ist Klasse.

Was f√ºr ein Rollenspiel auch sch√∂n ist, ist die Tatsache, dass man erst gewisse Fertigkeiten und Wissen leveln muss, damit man z.B. Fallen unterschiedlicher Stufe nutzen oder sehen darf, oder aber Statuswerte der Monster und menschlichen Gegner anschauen kann.

Auch das Zusammenspiel zwischen allgemeinen Waffenfertigkeiten und den gesonderten Kampffertigkeiten ist super gelungen. Was n√ºtzen einem hohe Angriffswerte, wenn man nicht auch sch√∂ne Spezialattacken daf√ºr gelernt hat?
So etwas bietet glaube ich sonst kein anderes Spiel, zumindest nicht in diesem Ma√üe. Auch nicht Shadowrun.

Was man in einem dritten Teil noch neben knackigeren Texturen verbessern k√∂nnte, w√§re vielleicht die rollenspieltechnische Geschichte.
Es gibt zwar nun mehr davon und auch mehr Entscheidungen als noch in Teil 1, aber insgesamt betrachtet ist das immer alles relativ kurz und vergleichsweise streng linear abgehandelt und ist wohl der Mischung aus Rollenspiel und gro√üem Strategiepart geschuldet.

Alles in Allem bin ich aber wirklich schwer begeistert und ich kann jedem Rollenspieler und Strategieliebhaber dieses Spiel empfehlen!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989664109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1474, 'last_played': 1463013728}
review:
The only reason I had trepidation in playing Blackguards 2 was the horrible bugs that made the first Blackguards unplayable. To my delight I had not one issue with Blackguards 2 and boy did I get a treat!

The story-writing was amazing, with an iconic memorable fairytale that changes depending on choices you make in the game. Cassia's story is dark, and as a heroine or villian, she edges towards the brink of insanity. The SRPG elements are fulfilling, but not all maps are created equal. Sometimes obscure clues you pick up offer advantages during battle, but only if you can remember what was said.

Overall, the game deserves a sequel and definitely a playthrough if you haven't already.

review:
A great turn-based tactical game about the military campaign of Cassia Corapia, a woman driven to madness by betrayal. 
Less puzzles and more combat focused then the first one (and a bit easier, but not necessarily a flaw, as the first one was sometimes frustrating), the story of the game follow the battles of the Silver Spider Army. Big battles, heroes, mercenaries and mythical creatures will make your day. 
A must buy for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052404717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1656, 'last_played': 1485115138}
review: I enjoyed this game very much. I'm a huge hex based rpg fan and was a big fan of the original, and this game didn't disappoint me at all. I found the game to be just as enjoyable as the original, but it is a bit easier and more forgiving during the combat compared to part one. That isn't a bad thing since the first game just flat out cheated at certain points. I found the writing namely the conversations with the party members enjoyable as they have the same witty responses and opinions as in the first game. The story is average at best but it isn't terrible just a little basic but if you're a fan of the first game and a fan of hex based rpgs in general you should enjoy this game. I recommend this game and I paid full price for it for what that is worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063369860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2928, 'last_played': 1457320445}
review:
Due to all the negative reviews on Blackguards 1 I decided to skip straight to part 2, so I cannot comment on the differences between the two games.
Blackguards 2 is a decent turn-based strategy game. However, it has a lot of quirks. It's kind of like having a boy-/girlfriend with a "manual". You don't really know how to handle him/her, but you find out over time. Sadly, in a game this is not necessarily a good thing, and it isn't in Blackguards 2. Though, that doesn't mean that it's really broken or not worth playing. Once you get past the initial difficulties (I'll have to refer you to other reviews for details), you will be able to appreciate the challenge. Right up to the point that the game gets too easy. Yes, gameplay is unbalanced in more than one way, sadly. Still, I had a pretty good time with it overall.
Get it on sale or play XCOM instead. It's that simple.

On a technical side note, some of the larger maps (or not even that) tend to cause massive fps drops. I doubt it's the hardware.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001316637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1443837692}
review:
[h1]What happened here?[/h1]

The first Blackguards was a decent first attempt by Daedalic at the TRPG genre. It did however some issues in terms of the story and the documentation for stats and skills. I went into Blackguards 2 hoping that they would build upon the original Blackguards and address the issues in it. Man did they fuck up.

Daedalic seemed to want attract a broader audience to this game, and one of the ways they tried this was to simplify the chaarcter creation system by removing attributes (Str. Con.). How does this affect the game? Well now, spells cannot fail , so in their attempt to make the game easier, they made it more unbalanced. There are other isues with mages in this game like the fact that wearing heavy armor is barely a penalty fo them, but the balancing is not my main problem.

God damn, do I hate the encounters in this game. Somehow, they went from its biggest strength to its biggest flaw. Yeah fighting waves of enemies every fight is sooooo fun! And what the hell is up with the spawn points?! The characters start all over the place. Great job Daedalic!

There are many other flaws (the story again!), but the tale I'm trying to write here is that Blackguards is shit and I don't want to waste anymore time on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058380579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1452979564}
review:
I reviewed Blackguards 1 a couple months ago and gave it a positive review due to the story and concepts - although it was severely lacking in user friendliness and the combat was below average.

Therefore when it came to playing Blackguards 2, i was bitterly dissaointed (and fairly angry) that it was exactly the same game with a far worse story. The graphics, the UI, the combat, the skills, the text, the options - everything is exactly the same. It wouldnt be a problem if it was a kickass game like Borderlands where its amazing in each of the similar renditions - but when BG1 starts off as a flop and the development team seemingly does nothing to even attempt to improve the game for the sequel, then its a game to avoid. 

Im not even going to try to enlighten you on the game mechanics and concepts as you would be better off buying BG1 or saving your money for another game.

review:
If you played the first, you will be very familiar with the second game.  It seems to go by quicker, and I only clocked about 20+ hours on it.  

Overall it is numerous battles, and then some roleplaying in between, where your decisions reflect on how the story goes. 

Combat is tough but not overly so.  I found that the main character that you get to create, should be a spellcaster to even things out in combat.  Think of creating a classic healer type and you should be in good shape.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159570795', 'num_games_owned': 390, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 929, 'last_played': 1437695819}
review:
I LOVED the first Blackguards game, and was looking forward to this one for a long time.
It is NOT the same. 

First, there are some definite improvements to the way the game plays on a technical level.
It is far more clear what you will get for putting points into skills, and the equipment is a little easier to make use of as well.

And it starts off soooo promising -- the jilted protagonist, twisted by solitude and lead by fate into a monster-ridden nightmare. Should be amazing.
But the game doesn't draw you in the same way the original(BG1) did, and the flow of the story is too disjointed and meandering. 

Worse still is that the combat is VERY repetitive.
In BG1, you could make half your units mages, or refocus everyone to melee -- there was immense versatility, despite very limited choices and a very clunky character sheet.

In this game, you mostly fight using NON-MAGICAL generic units, and the battles don't really weave into the plot much. 
They just seem to be "fight the stuff to move forward" and it just gets boring quick.

Unless you REALLY like the big fights with generic units, just play the first one and hope the next brings together what is good about BG 1&2.

review:
Pros:
- Great story with excellent voice acting.
- The combat is fun and interesting too.  With the below exception.
- The graphics are good for a game of its type.  

Cons:
- You can't speed up the movement of the troops and thus battles feel so sloooow as the characters trudge across the battlefield.  Overall, the slowness was too much for me to take and had to stop playing.  On the other hand, if you prefer a slow game with a lot of atmosphere then this would be a pro not a con!
- Mouse selection of enemies is a bit off, once again slowing the game down because of several seconds spent each time you want to see the health of a particular enemy.

review: Blackguards 2, in an attempt to improve some aspects of the first chapter, it loses some of its charge into a series of mistakes that disrupt the game experience. For lovers of the saga certain defects may not seem so obvious, but do not help the game Daedalic to reach more varied and demanding.

review: Blackguards 2 is supposed to be a tactical RPG but it suffers from the fact that the game is often random to the point of impossible.  You will be able to win eventually but it's usually not your tactics or play that leads you to win but rather the RNG eventually falling in your favor.  The first game was ok but I definitely would not recommend this one.

Explico.

En el blackguards 1 no te dicen que si te haces un mago de da√±o vas a ser inutil desde que empiezas a jugar hasta que se termina el juego, tienes que hacerte un rango o melee para ser algo en ese juego ya que parece que esta creado para hacer la pu√±eta al jugador.

NO os equivocais cuando os comeis un flechazo que quita mas que tu hechizo mejorado al maximo piensas: Hostias! pues deberia crearme otra cosa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257696182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2179, 'last_played': 1448847323}
review:
Blackguards 2 plays quite differently from Blackguards 1.  While I preferred the first game's character customization with the stats, the battles in 2 were more intense and included many more combatants.  The random number generator was significantly less frustrating.  It's hard to pick a favorite.  Both are amazing TRPGs.  Some believe this game feels like DLC for #1, and while I understand how you can get that impression (most music tracks in #2 are from #1), the world map and battles play quite differently.  There's enough content here to justify the sequel status, in my opinion.

What I liked about Blackguards 2.
* Battles were very intense.  The player can't always win with brute force (in fact, a great deal of battles will result in defeat if the player opts for brute force).  I took ONE LOOK at the field during the fight against the druid, my group surrounded by the treant chimearas, and didn't think there was any hope of success.  I ended up succeeding on my first attempt with the help of 2 well-placed fireballs (they unexpectedly grouped together).  A lot of battles had me thinking "What the heck am I going to do to win this?!" and occasionally required a second attempt.
* The return of Takate, Zurburan and Naurim from 1 was appreciated.  
* Huge battles.  The number of combatants in #1 (the unit portraits) never exceeded my screen's capacity, but the majority of the battles in #2 wrapped around.
* Contains multiple endings.  I think if I had played differently, the main character survives.  (I'll be back, just you wait #2.)
* The ability to have a magic-user wearing armor without penalty potentially allows for some very interesting hybrid options for Zurburan and the main character.
* I felt there were more than enough character points to complete what I wanted for all of my characters.

What I didn't like.
* Stats were dropped completely, dumbing down character customization and nearly completely removing the table-top RPG feel that the first game had.  This loss of stats affected the spells a lot.  The creators decided to hold on to every spell from #1 and alter them to keep them relevant.  I don't think it worked.  Many spells became nearly useless.  
* I prefer an adventuring party with mercenary assistance over a conquering horde.  Having to defend territories already claimed was a nuisance.  I hope it wasn't added just to increase play time.
* The narrator's voice annoyed the snot out of me.  I found myself pressing multiple buttons trying to shut him up, as I had already read the words.
* The story was there, but it was narrated more than acted out with the characters.  

Overall, this provides more of what I'm looking for.  More tactical RPG awesomeness.  I'm glad I didn't pass this series up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009169294', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1447089414}
review:
There are much better games than Blackguards 2, and it will fail to be worth your time or money.  A better experience can be had playing the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/237990/]Banner Saga[/url], or even [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/249650/]Blackguards 1[/url].  This game isn't terrible, it is somewhat fun, but it is really lacking compared the endless list of games on steam.  

It's not exactly the same genre or style, but Blackguards could learn a lot from the combat in [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/237990/]Banner Saga[/url].

[b]Pros[/b]
[*]144hz support
[*]Decent graphics, art tends to look reasonably good, it will immerse you
[*]Even though I chose not to finish the game (but did let it run for steam cards) I am curious how the story played out.  After seeing Cassia's spider-bite-scared-face and mask I was rooting for her; sadly her life is just too boring for me to continue playing.  
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[*][spoiler]Why couldn‚Äôt I keep my pet spider I named after my sister?  What a let down.[/spoiler]
[*]So slow!  The pacing is terrible: from the long and boring first level, to the slow paced action/movement system.  Even though the game is turn based it needs to allow the user to speed things up a bit.  It takes far too long time to accomplish anything in the game
[*]I can't pause cutscenes?  What if I need to step away!
[*]No camera rotating?  Some objects are placed behind others with an obscured view.  It's not an isometric game so this is seemingly pointless limitation.
[*]Cassia, has such an annoying and pretentious voice.  
[*]Combat doesn't seem to have a lot of strategy to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085586374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1571, 'last_played': 1446832058}
review:
Very good game!

Pros:
+ Very interesting characters with tremendous personalities. Cassia, Faramud and Takate are amazing characters.
+ Very good storyline with choices.
+ Talking with different characters at your camp feels very personal and interesting. This game has outstanding voice acting.
+ Tactical battles with large number of units.
+ Amazing music. Absolutely loved it.

Cons:
- Character development is rather simple and straightforward. Not very deep or broad.

I highly recommend this game if you are a fan of squad based turn based tactical battles games or if you are a fan of an amazing story, tremendous characters and beautiful music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030899809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1446391039}
review:
Rather captivating 'little' RPG game that I've enjoyed playing... but was close to abandon after the first two hours because the beginning is a bit slow and dissapointing (not what I was expecting from a RPG). Hopefully, I hadn't any other game waiting to be played, so I kept playing with this one and once arrived on the world map, it started to become good. And I really don't regret to have bought it. So do not let you be discouraged by the beginning.

Also, this game has a good ration durability/price : I took me 26 hours to finish it in normal mode for a game bought only 10 euros, that's good ( < 0.5 euro per hour of gameplay).

author: {'steamid': '76561197987388969', 'num_games_owned': 1737, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1446086149}
review: Blackguards 2 is a Turn-based, Tactical RPG, where you have the freedom to customize your character to your own playstyle.  Instead of rolling your own character as you did in Blackguards, Blackguards 2 has you play from the perspective of the Lady Cassia of Tenos, who is imprisoned for years in a spider infested dungeon. Disfigured and Demented after years of spider's poison, the tutorial takes you through the Labyrinth she is imprisoned in and teaches you the basics of the game. Lady Cassia can be customized for play more as a warrior, mage, or hunter, or even a hybrid if you choose.  You will lead various companions along the way whom you save or recruit on your travels to help you. Visually speaking, Blackguards 2 looks beautiful, as with the original it is well designed, intricate and detailed. I personally like the story, it has a Count of Monte Christo feel to it, which is one of my favorite stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007513026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 433, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1443823224}
review:
After a few hours to fears are confirmed, this game is just as bad as the first one, probably worse.

I enjoyed the first game for quite a few hours despite its many flaws. I got fed up with this one after two or three hours. Absolutely nothing has improved. Like the first game the difficulty curve is all over the place. The first few tutorial missions are very easy, which is fine. Then they throw a frustratingly difficult mission at you. But its difficult only because you are greatly outnumbered, the enemy AI is laughably bad.

I enjoy a challenge, but the challenges in this game are never fun. I almost never understood why my characters were hitting so poorly or why my archer never hit his target. There are lots of options to choose, but none of them have any obvious effect.

Daedalilc ought to give up on strategy RPGs, they obviously have no talent for games in the genre. Fortunately people seem to have caught on to this as it appears that Blackguards 2 bombed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023344725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2412, 'last_played': 1510520565}
review:
Hello everyone!
Just finished this game! If I tell you that it was interesting, I'll tell nothing! Because it is really amazing game! I remember not so many games when second  part is not worse that the first, but here I cannot decide which one is better! 
Comparing with 1st part:
1) the bugs were fixed!!! in the first game when you walk between location the game bugged very often. It was really awful!  Now, "Blackguards 2" run much smoother than the first part;
2) the classes of mage, archer and warrior were reworked. If in the first part there was no sense to make an archer (the size of battle locations. You can effectively shoot one or two times), in the second part it really works! Warriors now have an endurance scale, which works like mana for casters. Now you can't use your special abilities every turn as it was in the first game;
3) the atmosphere of the game changed in dark side. It is much more gloomy.
I really recommend this game for those who like turn-based battles and adventures. It's really worth it.

review:
Als Fan des ersten Teils habe ich mir Blackguards 2 nat√ºrlich auch zugelegt. Mein Fazit:

- Deutlich k√ºrzer als der erste Teil. Der hatte ungef√§hr 100 Gefechte, das hier sind deutlich weniger, sofern man nicht sinnlos auf der Karte rumreist und dauernd mit den S√∂ldnern verteidigt. 
- Weniger Rollenspiel. Es gibt eigentlich nur noch den Kampftree und die Talente 
- K√§mpfe auch auf Schwer nicht besonders fordernd, da war Blackguards 1 schon schwieriger. Zwei K√§mpfe habe ich neu gestartet, da man teilweise dank der nicht drehbaren Kamera gr√∂√üere Fallen nicht erkennen kann (wie dieses Ding, das einen in einem der K√§mpfe von der Br√ºcke schubst). Eher was f√ºr Anf√§nger im Hexfeldgenre, ganz klar kein Panzer General Forever oder so. 

Warum ich es trotzdem empfehle: ich hatte knapp 20 Stunden Spa√ü damit, daf√ºr war der Preis angemessen. Die Story ist ganz nett und an dem kitschigen DSA-Feeling komme ich einfach nicht vorbei. Man kann's gut zwischendurch spielen, da die K√§mpfe nicht sehr lange dauern bzw. nicht sehr anspruchsvoll sind, daf√ºr kriegt man dann schneller die Story zu sehen. Hat auch was.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961450116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1649689027}
review:
I was skeptical to buy this game based on the reviews I read here on Steam. I am happy to say that I am so glad i ignored them! This was a great game. The mechanics are certainly scaled back from the first game, however any review should be based on how well a game stands on its own. So with that being said I greatly enjoyed the storyline. It was just engaging enough to carry you through the story, while not being too overbearing. I like the mercenary/troop upgrade system and also being able to supplement my battles with mercs to suit my combat needs. The only negative aspect, for me, was that even on easy some of the absolute randomness of the battles made some maps almost impossible, and others so easy you almost didnt even have to think about it. I found that the fast pace of the game had my team and mercenaries upgrading their skills formidably after every fight, which was different from the first game (or most RPGs). That made each new fight an excercise in "lets see what this new ability does" which kept it very fresh for me. I like the fact that there really are a few different paths to take to the end of the game. This and the random nature of the fights gives the game some level of replayability that is enjoyable.

The biggest downfalls are not dealbreakers, but for me they are:
-Lack of ranged party member. If you do not roll your main character with bows or crossbows, you will not have a follower with that skillset. in the later game you could use excess points for this, but not for the first 3/4. I would like to try out a mage or warrior type but those are already covered with your "premade" party.
-Cumbersome tooltip to tell if a new item is an upgrade. You have to physically click on the CURRENT item and then hover over the new item in question. It works, but its not explained.
-Annoying "break the crystals before you can damage enemies" fights. seriously, just add extra enemies if you want it to be harder or at least only do this to us ONCE :P
-Removal of base stats (strength/Dexterity/Etc). I understand why and it works, it is just a big departure.
-Addition of enurance as a combat ability "mana". I am kind of on the fence with this because in the first game you could spam hard hitting abilities and now you have to think on that until your regeneration is higher. I like it but again, its a big departure.
-little to no side quests. 

Positives:
-actual storyline which is just interesting enough to pull you through the campaign but not complicated enough to make you skip tons of lore materials or quest dialog.
-combat system is fun and rage inducing at the same time. The Guard ability on crossbows is rediculously fun when it executes well! Some of the spells are so fun to cast that you always look forward to doing it.
-easy to understand and navigate map system. The bonuses you get from each capture point are very well presented and you can intelligently plan your own route of attacks to gain the upgrades you prefer instead of being stuck on a preplanned route.
-nice system of character skill upgrades that upgrade very fast. You will always feel relatiuvely powerful, especially if you pay attention to the difficulty rating on each point of the map.
-More but I cant think of them all. 

Overall for the money this is a great turn based RPG. Dont let the nay sayers talk you out of it. Its one of the best uses of 5 bucks in a while.

review:
Schade, ich freute mich anfangs endlich mal wieder ein rundenbasiertes RPG zu haben. Man sollte meinen, dann recht gut taktisch vorgehen zu k√∂nnen. Aber nicht so bei Blackguards 2, denn in fast jedem Kampf sind die Gegner in irgendeiner Art und Weise besser dran, als man selbst. Sei es durch Heilkristalle, die sie jede Runde komplett hochheilen, oder durch endlosen Nachschub von ausserhalb der Map oder sei es ganz einfach nur, weil einige Gegner Pfeile durch Mauern hindurch schiessen k√∂nnen. Andere springen auch ganz einfach durch die Mauer hindurch. Man selbst kann all diese Dinge nat√ºrlich nicht.....
Sehr nervig das alles.
Aber am Schluss: Der letzte Kampf ist der gr√∂sste Krampf √ºberhaupt. Hier gibt es n√§mlich einen Bug, der verhindert dass man im Spiel auf der guten Seite bleibt, bzw. man seine Schwester rettet! Das Spiel h√∂rte nur auf, als ich mich b√∂se verhielt, erst dann wurde der Kampf beendet. Sowas entt√§uschendes! Selten so einen hirnrissigen Bug entdeckt! Das hat mir im Nachhinein das komplette Spiel versaut!

Zum Bug (vorsicht Spoiler): 
[spoiler]Im Endkampf gibt es einen Gegner, der beherrscht die Kunst  des Versteinerns. Wenn dieses Wesen sich nun einen anderen, lebenden Gegner schnappt und ihn versteinert hat man einen Bug. Das Spiel denkt n√§mlich, dass dieser versteinerter Gegner noch leben w√ºrde und beendet dadurch nicht den Kampf. Man selbst hat leider keine M√∂glichkeit versteinerte Gegner im Nachhinein noch zu t√∂ten.
Dadurch bleibt dann nur noch Marwan zu killen als letzte M√∂glichkeit offen. Dummerweise stirbt dann auch die Schwester, die man versucht zu befreien. Der Kampf wird beendet und man steht als "B√∂se" da......
[/spoiler]

Spiel ist nicht empfehlenswert.

review:
It is a good sequel. Overall I would recommend it.
The game is simpler in terms of character development compared to its predecessor (e.g. you don't develop attributes yourself) but it compensates with interesting story and new aspects of battle (e.g. monster enemies). Skills are slightly changed, but more or less tha same as in BG1.

What I did not like is that there is no wold state import, the first game does not impact the second game in any way. What I did like is that the story is made in such a way, that in spite of the fact that the character can be good or bad, it feels more natural to be bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011457032', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1341, 'last_played': 1441063850}
review:
I've finished Blackguards 2 in 22 hours and have played the predecessor, so I'll share my impressions with you.

Blackguards 2 is a story-driven RPG with turn-based combat in the medieval fantasy setting of The Dark Eye's Aventuria.

Stability and Bugs: 10/10
No crashes, bugs or graphic/sound issues during the entire playthrough. Perfect.

Balancing: 7/10
The battles are much less frustrating than they were in Blackguards 1. That is essentially because there are far less riddles to solve during battles. You can still take advantage of certain map items, like cutting a rope to drop a weight on enemies that stand on the affected tiles, but you don't need to do that to win the battle. I felt that most battles where somewhere between easy and only a little challenging. 

Character development: 8/10
Both in a sense of actual character development (roleplaying-wise) and the ability to level up the traits and equipment of your characters, the game offers a lot of pathes to pursue. Especially your roleplay actions have significant consequences.

Story: 8/10
The developers found a nice balance between providing information (no walls of text) and letting you immerge in the setting and the feelings of your characters.

Summary:
A very good game for a fair price.

review:
Da meine Gesamtauswertung des Spiels zu lang wurde, konzentriere ich mich lediglich auf die Ver√§nderungen zum Vorg√§nger:

Charakterentwicklung: 
* sehr eingeschr√§nkt, auf Kampf optimiert , √ºberm√§√üig AP intensiv, vor allem Waffentalente und (gro√üteilig √ºberfl√ºssige) Talente wie Selbstbeherrschung, Tierkunde usw.
* Keine Attribute mehr! RPG-Elemente r√ºcken damit stark in den Hintergrund
* Individualisierung wird Optimierung geopfert

S√∂ldner:
* sollen vermutlich das Gef√ºhl von gro√üen Schlachten vermitteln, ziehen die K√§mpfe jedoch unn√∂tig in die L√§nge, sind allerdings aufgrund von √ºberm√§√üig hohem Gegneraufkommen unabdingbar
* steigen automatisch in den Stufen (und erhalten bessere Ausr√ºstung) durch Eroberung bestimmter Orte, ein direkter Einfluss auf die Truppen (bspw. individuelles Ausr√ºsten) ist damit nicht m√∂glich
* Verteidigen St√§dte die von Marwan (Cassias Konterpart) zur√ºck erobert werden sollen. (Diese K√§mpfe werden weder mit AP noch mit Loot oder auf sonst eine Weise belohnt. Dabei sind sie noch nicht einmal besonders herausfordernd - ich habe in zwei Durchg√§ngen auf mittel und schwer nicht einen Standort verloren! Gef√ºhlt ziehen diese Schlachten das Spiel nur unn√∂tig in die L√§nge!)

K√§mpfe:
* willk√ºrliches Spawnen von Gegnern (im ersten Teil war klar ersichtlich, wo die Gegner herkommen und man konnte etwas dagegen unternehmen, bspw. L√∂cher von Gruftasseln schlie√üen oder verhindern, dass die Alarmglocke gel√§utet wird), was K√§mpfe zeitweise frustrierend macht und unn√∂tig in die L√§nge zieht
* erheblich l√§nger (gr√∂√üere Karten) dabei aber nicht unbedingt anspruchsvoller
* un√ºbersichtlich (Wo genau verursacht das interagierbare Objekt jetzt Schaden? Wo steht die Schatztruhe? Treffe ich das Baumwesen oder nur das Wespennest an seiner Seite) hier w√§re eine Ver√§nderung zum ersten Teil, n√§mlich die M√∂glichkeit einer drehbaren Kamera, absolut w√ºnschenswert gewesen!
* Gifte und Fallen k√∂nnen kaum eingesetzt werden, da ihr Nutzen nicht im Verh√§ltnis zur Zeit steht (Ich kann eine Falle auslegen, die dem Gegner - wenn er sie denn ausl√∂st - 6 Punkte Schaden zuf√ºgt. oder ich schlage einfach mit 12 Schaden zu... Dieses Problem hatte jedoch der Vorg√§nger auch schon.)

Story:
* stark ausged√ºnnt. Etwas sinnbefreit. Cassia will herrschen. Aber warum? "Gibt kein warum!" - ok, das ist auch mal eine Antwort
* b√∂se sein ist m√∂glich - und das ist, meiner Ansicht nach, eine der gro√üen St√§rken des Spiels, denn es erlaubt (ohne dabei zu bestrafen, im Gegenteil!) absolut b√∂se Handlungen 
*stark reduzierte Quests und Dialoge - Daedalic, wirklich? Warum spielt ihr eure gr√∂√üten St√§rken (wundervoll gezeichnete Hintergr√ºnde, gro√üartig dargebrachte Dialoge, unterhaltsame und spannende Geschichten) hier nicht voll aus? "Gibt kein warum!" - ja, das h√§tte ich mir denken k√∂nnen.
* Die "frei begehbare Welt" unterscheidet sich nicht vom Vorg√§nger, abgesehen davon, dass es weit weniger Orte und noch viel weniger zu entdecken gibt!

Fazit:
Kleine M√§ngel aus dem Vorg√§nger h√§tten √ºberarbeitet werden k√∂nnen. Doch statt dessen kamen neue hinzu. Die Story ist zu kurz, Dialoge zu sparsam ges√§t, die K√§mpfe unangenehm l√§nger doch dabei weniger innovativ und nicht wirklich taktisch fordernder. Die Welt ist alles andere als "offen" und die Charakterentwicklung so weit zusammen geschrumpft, dass von den Rollenspielelementen nicht mehr so viel √ºbrig bleibt. 
Warum bewerte ich das Spiel dennoch positiv? Weil ich auf hohem Niveau klage! Daedalic hat mit dem ersten Teil von Blackguards gezeigt, wozu sie in der Lage sind und dass die Entwickler auch auf diesem, f√ºr sie neuen, Gebiet ein durchaus gutes Spiel produzieren k√∂nnen. Gemessen am ersten Teil, √ºberzeugt ihre Arbeit im zweiten allerdings nicht, denn es erscheint eher wie ein Experiment denn wie eine Weiterentwicklung. 

Den ersten Teil jedoch nicht als Ma√üstab nehmend, ist Blackguards 2 ein durchaus funktionierendes und unterhaltsames Spiel. Es ist d√ºster und pr√§sentiert interessante Charaktere. Die K√§mpfe sind (meistens) fordernd und laden nicht selten zum Gr√ºbeln ein - ein einfaches "drauf und dr√ºber" sorgt in den aller meisten F√§llen f√ºr eine sichere Niederlage. Und tats√§chlich ist es einmal ein Spiel, in dem b√∂se Handlungen nicht bestraft werden, sondern, im Gegenteil, durchaus von Vorteil sein k√∂nnen! Das macht dieses d√ºstere und melancholische Setting noch glaubw√ºrdiger. 

Wer sich also an etwa 20 Stunden taktischer Pr√ºgelei mit allerlei Gesindel erfreuen kann, der ist bei Blackguards 2 gut aufgehoben! Trotz meiner Vorbehalte war ich immerhin so sehr gefesselt, dass ich gleich zwei Durchl√§ufe gespielt habe. 

Wenn Daedalic aus den beiden Titeln das Beste heraus zieht und noch kleine Ver√§nderungen vornimmt, so k√∂nnte ich mir vorstellen, dass wir zuk√ºnftig noch mit einigen, durchaus erfolgreichen, Titeln dieser Art rechnen k√∂nnen. Ich w√ºrde es mir w√ºnschen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012492040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 931, 'last_played': 1466928865}
review:
Ich habe auch schon den ersten Teil gespielt und jetzt im Sale musste ich zugreifen.
Der Fokus bei Blackguards liegt ganz klar in den rundenbasierten taktischen K√§mpfen. Die einzelnen Karten sind nicht zufallsgeneriert, sondern liebevoll und vor allem mit vielen kleinen n√ºtzlichen Fallen ausgestattet.

Man kann z.B. Kr√§ne bedienen und Kisten auf Gegner fallen lassen, Holz mit Feuerpfeilen beschie√üen welche dann brennen und Gegner Schaden zuf√ºgen uvm. --> sprich man bezieht die Umgebung mit ein.

Im Gegensatz zum ersten Teil bekommt man nun auch ein Heer welches man mehr oder wenige kommandieren kann. Besonders gut finde ich dieses mal die Story man darf so richtig fie√ü sein, aber auch gut.
Ich spiele gerade den fie√üen Part und der macht richtig Laune, die Gespr√§che sind alle in deutsch vertont und gefallen mir sehr gut.
Cassa der Hauptchar befindet sich in einem Kampf mit sich selbst, daraus ergeben sich oft sehr tolle Selbstgespr√§che. Im Laufe der Story nimmt man immer wieder mal Gefangene, man darf dann selbst entscheiden wie das Verh√∂r statt finden soll und was man nach dem Verh√∂r mit dem Gefangenen macht :D


Leider hatte ich ein paar ungute Bugs, K√§mpfe wurden mittem im Kampfgeschehen abgebrochen und ich ging als Gewinner hervor, die Statistiken der Waffen stimmen nicht immer. Unkomfortabel finde ich den Vergelich der Gegenst√§nde wenn man im Shop neue Sachen kaufen will, irgendwie funktioniert das nicht immer korrekt.
Die Grafik k√∂nnte einen Tick besser sein erf√ºllt aber seinen Zweck. Auf den einzelnen Kampkarten passiert es √∂fter da sich Gegner so bl√∂d am Rand der Karte platzieren, dass man sie nicht sieht und auch nicht anklicken kann, da die Kamera nur genau bis zum Rand geht und nicht wie √ºblich etwas dar√ºber hinaus.
Die Kamer l√§sst sich leider auch nicht drehen, zumindest eine je 90¬∞ Drehung w√§re sehr sch√∂n gewesen, da man einige Sachen einfach nicht sieht.


Fazit:
Sehr anspruchsvolles rundenbasiertes Rollenspiel, mit toller Story und man darf dabei richtig fie√ü sein :D
Ich habe bis jetzt rund 10 Stunden gespielt und wurde bis jetzt sehr gut unterhalten, die Weltkarte ist relativ gro√ü und ich bin so wie ich das sehe noch am Anfang. Daher sch√§tze ich eine Spielzeit von 50-80h. Da man das ganze auch noch als gut spielen kann erh√∂ht sich der Wiederpsielwert enorm, beim zweiten Anlauf k√∂nnte man auch den erh√∂hten Schwierigkeitsgrad probieren, ich spiele zur Zeit auf normal und das ist auch schon eine sch√∂ne Herausforderung.
