author: {'steamid': '76561197998391180', 'num_games_owned': 3439, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1423625857}
review:
Leading a small band of despots into a city and taking it over completely is no small task. Slaves, guards, and even mythical creatures will try to thwart your path of destruction, but with superior strategy you will overcome them all. Blackguards 2 is a game centered around Cassia of Tenos, who collects the Gladiators from the previous Blackguards title to assist her with domination of the realm. There are so many unique mechanics at play, such as being able to shoot over the heads of those shorter than you and extremely interactive environments. All this makes Blackguards 2 one hell of a strategic romp. It does fall short in a couple places, but overall the presentation is wonderful. Each level is exceedingly difficult on the first time around, but the fantastic story that unfolds before and after each fight keeps me constantly thirsting for more. Without further adieu, lets delve into Blackguards 2.

As with the original, the story of Blackguards 2 is quite dark. Your main character is painted as completely insane within the first 30 minutes of playing, but she has her reasons. When asked by anyone why she‚Äôs out for conquest, she answers ‚ÄúThere is no why. Does the wind need a reason to blow?‚Äù Hell truly hath no fury like a woman scorned. You are not the good guys in this game, but Cassia‚Äôs intentions aren‚Äôt entirely based on whimsy either. The odds are stacked against her, but her first order of business is to set free bands of murderers from all the local prisons. Daedelic Entertainment does a great job of exploring a moral gray area. There is a grim feeling to almost everything you see which makes for a fantastic aesthetic. The ominous look is kept up throughout the game, even in levels when the sun is shining bright. The music is good, but slightly understated. I‚Äôd like to see a bit more attention drawn to their good soundtrack.

The skill trees have been massively simplified from the original Blackguards, which is a great thing. Spells and skills are now all straightforward, with costs and prerequisites laid out plain as day. Combat is exactly what it needs to be as well, left-click to move and right click to open a wheel filled with options, from spells to taking cover to ending the turn. Strategy is not a term used lightly in this game, characters will move in a set order based on initiative and cannot pass through friendly units on adjacent tiles. My first few matches involved a lot of bungling with characters being blocked in by their cohorts and having to pass the turn. You need to utilize every part of the environment, and your squad if you hope to make it out alive. This game pulls no punches. There is no inventory screen, so health potions can only be used from your belt and this means each hero can only carry one per fight. So use extreme caution.

Overall, I enjoyed Blackguards 2 greatly. The story is bleak, but witty. The characters are well-written, and relatable. I will say that the UI feels a bit clunky with enemy targeting, due to having multiple ways to cast a spell. The tutorial is also unabashedly long, clocking in at about 2 hours with cutscenes included. Lastly, I lament the removal of character creation, which the original Blackguards  did feature. Despite its flaws, the game is extremely replayable due to being able to build your characters‚Äô abilities any way you please. Voice-acting, graphics, sound, and story all mesh together beautifully into something that I plan to play again. Big thanks to Daedalic Entertainment for allowing me to review Blackguards 2, and for always offering such fantastic stories. Hope to see Blackguards 3 some day soon.

Summary: Superior 4x strategic fantasy combat with an amazing story.
Final Score: 7/10 for aesthetic, replayability, and story-telling.

Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-blackguards-2/

Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3s4s9kK02Cg

author: {'steamid': '76561198024705923', 'num_games_owned': 604, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1422111388}
review:
This may only serve as an early first impression. I might edit this review later on.

Blackguards 2 is a turn-based RPG/tactic game set in the Dark Eye Universe.

The graphics:
Blackguards 2 is not a AAA game especially regarding presentation techniques like graphics. But the artstyle is consistent. Some animations may be very rough and some textures only have a low resolution but in general the graphics look nice and atmospheric. 7/10

Sound:
The soundtrack is plain awesome! The music is atmospheric and fits the settings. ALso it doesn't repeat too often. Most voice-actors do a good job and the voices are fitting. 9/10

The atmosphere:
The world of Blackguards 2 is dark and brutal. The dialogues and the design of the locations and characters totally fit into that world and some locations are nothing less than epic. Unfortunately sometimes stiff animations break the immersion. 8/10

Gameplay:
The game is hard. Even in the beginning. Make one wrong step and you die. It is totally essentiall to know the skills of your characters. Every skill seems to be important. Though the skillsystem is slightly overwhelming at the beginning it allows carefull planning for the future.
There are often over a dozen characters at the same time in the battle and the arenas offer a lot of interactive objects. The developers used these to turn some battles into riddles. Tactic is much more important than luck! 
The interface works well but is in some cases (especially trading and inventory) not very comfortable. 8/10

Writing:
The story is a bit confusing at the beginning and has several timejumps. The main protagonist Cassia is, to say it frankly, a maniac. To make it short: I personally don't like her. I must admit that I don't even care for her and her story. Hopefully that will change soon...
The other characters instead are super! There are cool dynamics between them, everyone has his habits and background. Most dialogues are very funny to hear. 7/10

So in general I would rate the game with a 8 out of 10 and I will definitely continue to play it.

review:
[h1]I wanted to play Blackguards 2, [/h1]

because I had a lot of fun with games like x-com:eu or Incubation when it came out. So a friend recommended Blackguards 2 and I thought I should give it a try, even though I did not have much experience with DSA (i.e. The Dark Eye) except Shadows over Riva back in the day. I also heard a lot about Blackguards 2 being buggy and whatnot but worth its while. But to be safe (and for uni reasons) I waited until the newest Patch, which came out about two days ago.

Now I played for roughly five hours so far and I think the peeps at Deadalic did a reasonable job because I didn‚Äôt encounter any of the errors that the reviewers kept on ranting about. For that matter I think I didn‚Äôt run into one at all. At one point Cassia might have said ‚Äúokay‚Äù with Takate‚Äôs voice in a dialog, but then again it was running late and I was really tired.

Now here is the thing: I didn‚Äôt want to stop! The game is fun, I like playing and thinking about the skills I am giving or will give every character to just make them a tad more efficient. On the other hand I always end up a bit frustrated because the red numbers on the enemies stay roughly the same, which still makes mowing down a bunch of goblins a little bit less fun than it could be.

Last but not least:
[list]
[*]I started on the difficulty normal for starters and wasn‚Äôt too hard or easy either, the key thing is to know when to back down and get the f*¬©% out! 
[*] I am running it on a six year old laptop with a Dual Core, which still makes it run smooth as silk at medium settings. 
[*]The scrolling around on the game field is a bit laggy but I heard this is an issue on even stronger systems, so guys fix this and I am happy as a lark.
[/list]

[b]Buy it and give it a try, it will be worth your while![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197974250986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2036, 'last_played': 1423244045}
review:
Original Review: Thumbs Down.
(The game was released in a broken state.)

Updated Review: Thumbs up
After a series of patches, the game-breaking defects appear to be repaired.  I can now recommend the game to anyone who enjoyed the first Blackguards, or otherwise is a fan of turn-based tactical RPGs.  There is a lot of great stuff here, including good voice acting, character development, and the grim world of the pen-and-paper Dark Eye game.  It is a shame the developer just didn't wait the extra two weeks it took to polish the game before releasing it, as many fans may have been turned away by the bugs, resulting in a permanently-lowered review score.  This game is now a solid, turn-based, mission based, combat-focused RPG (no world exploration, similar to other tactics games).

I have never played the first Blackguards so I cant comment on an differences there but I enjoyed this.

The story is interesting if a bit dark and wierd and sometimes it makes very little sense.

There are a few bugs, at one point I could talk to two of my companions but no topics came up and at another point I had just dragged a big spider statue thing to my camp and talking to it started up a conversation with another character for some reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065494435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2301, 'last_played': 1422373394}
review:
Simply put, this game has a really odd story line. One minute I was murdering villagers to get more AP, the next I was letting prisoners go out of the kindness of my heart. Strangely it was all a lot of fun. 

At first I didn't like the main character. She was a evil looking thing with boils covering half her face, but after her personality develops she is pretty interesting. I initially thought she was going to be evil the entire game, but not so. She turns out to be a pretty cool chick that just got in with some bad dudes. 

One thing I wasn't so sure about is that you don't get to "make" your own character, but you can develop the main character anyway you want. Also she has a lot of speaking scenes and good voice acting which makes up for the inability to create your character from scratch. Also you only get 4 customizatable characters, which feels lacking to me for some reason. Also while they start off with alot to say, by mid game they just repeat the same old crap. One character, you can't even speak to after mid game. You see him sitting there, but that's it, you can't select to chat with him.

I didn't really like the way items and equipment were introduced to the characters. Some weapon types had a lot of really good weapons, while others didn't have much. Maybe it was on a loot table and I just got the good sword items and missed out on the good axe items. Too bad no one in my group used swords. 

The story was odd, as I said earlier, but still interesting. I saw a lot of choices, which I always tried to pick the good one, except when AP was up for grabs. The interrogation process was interesting, but I failed most of them. :P Finally I figured out that I should save before I start the interrogation, and reload after I fail it. During the interrogation, you try to figure out what is the best way to handled the one you are interrogating. You can intimidate them, lie to them, or make them an offer. From what I could tell, they provide you with some information is you get everything right. Like I said, I did fail most of these.

The character customization was pretty good too. You have a lot of stuff to spend your AP on. Almost everything is at least a little useful. The only problem is all your characters except Cassia come predisposed to certain weapon types, so it doesn't make sense to change it. I ended up using Naurim's starter axe through the entire game. I would of loved to have switched him to something better, but I just never found anything better. 

On the battle field is where this game shines though. Lots of stuff to do, and losts of stuff to watch out for. Only problem with them is a lot of the maps aren't as developed as I would like, but still most battles are really fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113958172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1677836795}
review:
* I only care about the game balance and systems *

I was a great fun of Blackguard1. Yes, it was complicated and can be forced to restart the game if your builds are wrong. But I liked them including shortages that are mentioned here by others.  Blackguard1 was a game to learn, evaluate, test skills and magics, and finally come up with the best build you can think of. I loved that process and spent hours and hours and restart the game 4 times before I could end it. (yah, i could end the game earlier but I am a perfectionist). I could finish off the hard-mode easily with my build. Yes, I got the right answer after tries and errors.

Blackguard2 was much more simplified and didnt take long to come up with the best build I can think of.  Yes, I can see the minor changes in skills that were over powered in blackguard1. (like sh***w + a***w r**n + b**fs on sh***w dont work anymore) But my 1st trial went too successful in blackguard2. A game is done when mastered the builds not when I see the ending credits or clear all the multi-endings. So it was over for me. Sigh.

I think this developer tried to make BlackGuard2 to meet the need of more general light game players or trying to get better reviews. But I am sorry to say that you completely lost me. Yes, you lost a big fun of Blackguard1. I was counting days for blackguard2 to be released but not for 3 anymore. Sad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040275876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1418912871}
review:
In 'Blackguards 2' schl√ºpfen wir in die Rolle von Cassia von Tenos, deren Rolle es ist, in den Kerker gesteckt zu werden. Die Gr√ºnde daf√ºr werden uns in einer komplett gezeichneten und hervorragend deutsch vertonten Sequenz berichtet. Diese erste Szene gibt ebenfalls Einblick in das doch recht d√ºstere Setting, in dem wir uns diesmal befinden. Ich w√ºrde Blackguards 2 in das Subgenre der 'Dark Fantasy' einordnen. W√§hrend uns jetzt also erz√§hlt wird, warum wir im Kerker sitzen, wohnen wir der Ermordung eines unschuldigen und fluffigen K√§tzchens bei. F√ºr mich als Katzenbesitzer und Gutmenschen war die Sequenz schon recht hart, zeigte mir aber ungeschminkt die unbarmherzige Situation, in der sich Cassia befindet. Hier sind wir nun, allein und ver√§ngstigt, in einem schmutzigen Loch unter der Erde. Gesellschaft leistet uns nur ein menschlicher Wachhund und eine Horde Corapien. Corapien sind recht gro√üe, h√§ssliche und giftige Spinnen, die gerne an Cassia knabbern m√∂chten. Nach dem ersten, eher ern√ºchternden, Gespr√§ch mit unserem W√§rter schauen wir uns jetzt um und entdecken, dass wir ebenfalls einige Waffen dabei haben und wir das Kerker-Labyrinth erkunden k√∂nnen. Auf einem dieser Erkundungstrips kommen wir in den Besitz eines Buches, in dem Cassia ab sofort die Flucht vor der Realit√§t sucht. Es vergeht eine Menge Zeit, in der Cassia neben dem Lesen und ihren Selbstgespr√§chen immer mehr von den Corapien und deren Gift zugesetzt wird und dadurch langsam aber sicher dem Wahnsinn verf√§llt, oder vielleicht auch nicht? Nein, nein, nein! Das Spiel erm√∂glicht uns hier auch dar√ºber zu entscheiden, ob Cassia lieber lesen oder mit sich selbst √ºber Wahnsinn debattieren soll. Mehr Zeit vergeht. Die lange Gefangenschaft, die Einsamkeit und die garstigen Spinnen kommen Cassia nicht gut zustehen. Ihr Gesicht schwillt an, ihr Geist schwindet und selbst die Spinnen ignorieren sie mittlerweile. Irgendwann beschlie√üt unsere Heldin ein letztes Mal zu fliehen, was ihr auch durch Hilfe einer Corapie und eines im Kerker auf der Flucht befindlichen Schurken gelingt. Nach der Flucht beginnt Cassia damit, die Haupthelden aus dem ersten 'Blackguards' um sich zu scheren und baut langsam eine Armee aus S√∂ldnern auf, um sich ihren Platz in der Welt wiederzuholen. Ihr stellt sich nun nur noch Marvens gesammelte Macht, seine Armee und seine Chim√§renmonster entgegen. Ob Cassia ihren Verb√ºndeten trauen kann, steht auch in den Sternen.
Kommen wir nun zum Gameplay. Mit Cassia als Hauptfigur haben wir die erste Neuerung zum Vorg√§nger. Diesmal spielen wir keinen "Namenlosen" Helden ohne Stimme, sondern eine gut geschriebene, dem Wahnsinn verfallene Antiheldin, deren Motivation es ist, einfach nur einmal auf dem Thron zu sitzen. Cassia hat auch keine festgelegte Klasse, allgemein bietet Blackguards 2 keine Klassenauswahl. Der Spieler hat eher ein System wie in den 'Elder Scrolls'-Spielen in dem man aus dem gro√üen Pool der F√§higkeiten, Zauber und extra Skills w√§hlen kann und sich dann damit seinen eigenen ''Magiertankflammenwerfendenbogensch√ºtzenassasinenberserker'' zu bauen. Ebenfalls wurde das DSA Regelsetting vereinfacht und umge√§ndert, um besser in ein Taktik RPG zu passen. Wo man im ersten Teil noch Angst haben musste, dass bei all der Planung und Aufstellung der Charaktere der Feuerball durch einen schlechten W√ºrfelwurf des PCs daneben ging, oder der Schwerthieb keinen der 4 angrenzenden Gegner auch nur zum Schwitzen bringt, funktioniert dies alles viel besser im zweiten Teil. Um das Spiel aber nicht zu einfach zu gestalten, wurde eine Stamina Liste eingef√ºhrt, die es uns unterbindet (den Gegnern aber auch) unentwegt unsere st√§rksten Nahkampff√§higkeiten einzusetzen. Der Kampf selbst findet aber immer noch auf gut Designten, mit Fallen, Deckungen und taktisch anwendbaren H√∂hen- und Tiefenunterschieden gespickten Battle-Maps statt. Hier agieren wir Zug um Zug, Runde um Runde auf Hexfeldern um unsere Gegner auszuspielen, mit Kronleuchtern zu erschlagen oder in √ñllachen abzufackeln. Alles im Namen des guten Wahnsinns! Eine der gr√∂√üten Neuerungen ist aber die Art die Kampagne voranzutreiben. Anstatt sich vom Spiel automatisch von Mission zu Mission leiten zu lassen, k√∂nnen wir uns auf der Karte des Emirats Mengbilla angrenzende St√§dte oder andere Ortschaften wie zum Beispiel ein Gef√§ngnis oder ein kleines Weglager aussuchen und diese dann erobern. Jeder eingenommene Ort bringt uns dabei neue Vorteile wie bessere Ausr√ºstung, mehr Geld oder neue Einheitentypen f√ºr unsere S√∂ldnerarmee. Angef√ºhrt von Faramud ist die stumme Legion unsere eigene Klonarmee. Wir k√∂nnen in K√§mpfen bis zu 9 Mitstreiter der stummen Legion befehligen, hierbei handelt es sich dann auch um eigenst√§ndige Charaktere, die aber weder etwas zu sagen haben ,noch einen wirklich wichtigen Bestand in der Geschichte, au√üer dass sie als kostenloses Kanonenfutter herhalten d√ºrfen. Stirbt einer der Soldaten im Einsatz, dann ist das eben so. Alles f√ºr Cassia, wenn du Dreck frisst, bleib liegen. Der Verlust dieser Einheiten hat keinerlei negative Auswirkungen auf das weitere Spiel. Hierbei sieht man auch wieder, dass man nicht mit irgendwelchen Strahlem√§nnern, sondern eiskalten Fieslingen unterwegs ist. Dies wird auch mit den weiteren Entscheidungen im Spiel unterstrichen. Wer kein Geld f√ºr die Verpflegung von Kriegsgefangen ausgeben m√∂chte, darf diese zum Beispiel auch einfach hinrichten lassen. Allgemein ist Blackguards viel mit Entscheidungen gespickt, die gr√∂√üte Auswirkung haben diese dann auch auf den Ausgang der Geschichte. Ob Cassia eine g√ºtige (und verr√ºckte) Herrscherin, oder eine komplett durchgedrehte Despotin wird, liegt in unseren H√§nden. Auch das Miteinander der NPC's und anderen Blackguards kann so beeinflusst werden, dass aus alten Verb√ºndeten pl√∂tzlich Feinde werden. Ganz so nutzlos sind die S√∂ldner der stummen Legion dann aber doch nicht. W√§hrend sich Cassia, Naurim und Co. auf einer Quest befinden, kann es gut und gerne geschehen, dass Marwen versucht eine Stadt zur√ºckzuerobern. Hierbei bildet dann die Gruppe aus S√∂ldnern die meist einzige M√∂glichkeit die Stadt zu halten. Dazu kommt dann auch noch die M√∂glichkeit, seine S√∂ldner auflzueveln und verbessern zu k√∂nnen. Wer also auf das Leben seiner Mietlinge acht gibt, kann sich so eine zweite schlagkr√§ftige Gruppe aufbauen. Bei der Balance und den Schwierigkeitsanstiegen aus dem 'Angespielt' hat sich leider nichts ge√§ndert, hier und da gibt es immer noch unerbittliche 'Trial-' und 'Errormissionen', die es mit Kopf, Herz und vor allem Nerven zu bew√§ltigen gilt. Den Wunsch die Maus in den Bildschirm zu pr√ºgeln versp√ºrte ich aber nicht mehr. Ein gro√ües Lob geht auch an die epischen Bossk√§mpfe und die allgemeine Gegner- und Missionsvielfalt. Nicht nur m√ºssen wir alle Gegner vom Schlachtfeld fegen, wir haben auch Missionen, in denen es Schalterr√§tsel zu l√∂sen oder Gefangene zu eskortieren gilt. Die Ladezeiten sind mittlerweile auch ertragbar und die paar Bugs, die hier und da auftreten k√∂nnen, sollen laut Daedelic auch schnellstm√∂glich behoben werden. Blackguards 2 sieht gut aus. Wir haben viele Details auf den Schlachtfeldern, die Ausr√ºstung hat neben R√ºstungs- und Angriffswerten auch einen visuellen Effekt, Licht und Schatten wurden gut umgesetzt und die Stadtkarten strotzen vor Details. Die Vertonung ist f√ºr ein deutsches Spiel wieder sehr gut und die Dialoge oder Cassia's Monologe sind auch sehr gut geschrieben. Daedelic hatten mit Blackguards 2 nicht zu viel versprochen und ein in allen belangen besseren Nachfolger geliefert.

review:
Ich habe vorher noch nie ein rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel gespielt und war deswegen zu Anfang etwas √ºberfordert. Allerdings kommt man gut ins Spiel rein und nach kurzer Spielzeit findet man sich mit der Steuerung zurecht. 

Ich kenne den ersten Teil des Spiels nicht, aber weitesgehend ist BG2 unabh√§ngig von seinem Vorg√§nger, wie ich auch durch Gespr√§che mit Freunden erfahren haben, die beide Teile spielen.
Die Story ist zu Anfang etwas undurchschaubar aber dadurch bekommt das Spiel einen gewissen Reiz, da man die Charaktere erst nach und nach kennenlernt. 

Alles in Allem ist es ein rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel das viel Spa√ü macht und auch f√ºr Einsteiger in diesem Genre geeignet ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977326167', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1426195353}
review:
To begin with I must say that I am a big fan of The Dark Eye Pen‚Äôn‚ÄôPaper and really like  the world of Aventuria! I was really excited when the first Blackguards was released. It wasn‚Äôt the game I was expecting but still good with some interesting features and a thrilling combat system.
Therefore I knew what to expect from Blackguards 2 ‚Ä¶ and I was still surprised! In a positive way! The story is more interesting and the characters even more well-rounded than in the first one! As soon as you start you feel pity and a disgusted by Cassia!
The combat itself hasn‚Äôt changed a lot which is good in my eyes! I like the strategic approach and the possibility to use the environment for your advantage. It‚Äôs not always easy too keep track of the entire map but that doesn‚Äôt hurt. Spells always work and also you normally hit enemy when you attack. This is something I was skeptical about but as it turns out the battles feel more dynamic and faster which is big plus!
What has changed is the character development and again for the better! Even I, knowing and loving the complexity of the Dark Eye rule books was confused and overwhelmed! So the new approach is way more user friendly and even for beginners easy to get into as there are always information available what the e.g. talent improves. Also you can develop ‚Äúyour‚Äù Cassia more into the direction you want during the game and not thinking ‚Äúshame, should‚Äôve chosen blablabla right at the start..‚Äù
The game definitely has developed since the first part! Positively! For anyone with a hang towards strategic hex-field battles in fantasy settings this game is a must! Especially given the, just guessing now, 20+ hours of game for only 20-30‚Ç¨!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198138282847', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1422212271}
review: Ich spiele dieses Spiel auf der normalen Schwierigkeitsstufe. Inwiefern nun die beiden anderen Modi leichter oder schwerer sind, kann ich nicht beurteilen. Jedoch bieten die Entwicklungsm√∂glichkeiten des eigenen Charakters sehr viele M√∂glichkeiten der Spezialisierung (ok auch die Begleiter kann man nach und nach trainieren). Jedoch f√ºhrt zum Gl√ºck nicht jede Instanz mit derselben Taktik zum gew√ºnschten Erfolg. Da ich schon einige Male gescheitert bin, habe ich immer wieder neue √úberlegungen anstellen d√ºrfen, um dann doch den jeweiligen Bereich erfolgreich abschlie√üen zu k√∂nnen. Mal muss man den Kampf suchen, dann mal k√§mpfen - R√ºckzug - k√§mpfen - R√ºckzug, einfach nur mal fliehen usw. Von daher gibt es sch√∂n viel Abwechslung und es wird nicht langweilig. Von Vorteil finde ich, dass das Spiel rundenbasiert ist, damit man nicht hektisch in Realtime seine Entscheidungen treffen muss. Damit sind auch Unterbrechungen durch das Real Life ohne weiteres zu "verschmerzen". Einfach pausieren und nach der St√∂rung weitermachen ;-)! Schwierig finde ich die Entscheidungen, in welche Richtung ich mich spezialisieren soll. Die Story, die sich mit der Zeit entwickelt, ist mit sehr angenehmen Stimmen vertont und passen meiner Meinung nach bisher sehr gut zu den jeweiligen Personen. Ich bin mal gespannt vor welche R√§tsel ich noch so gestellt werden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971896423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1422425745}
review:
After being nearly done with the game I can give a better review of the game:

Positive aspects:
- One of the best experiences for Turn based tactical combat. I really like this aspect of Blackguards since only a few games get turn based combat right.

- Witty and funny dialogue, this is one of the main reasons this game is charming

- Art and Sound are great just like in the first Blackguards.

- The Character building was streamlined and it is now harder to spec your character into a dead end. Removing some of the choices did not really dimminish the DSA rulesets.

-Most major bugs have been squashed after the lastest patch.

Negative aspects:


- Performance Issues related mostly to bad optimisation, the Engine is the same as Blackguards 1 and it feels like there are still the same issues present like the first one and there was no optimisation done.

- Some mission designs are very frustrating, the missions usually are challenging which is nice, but some missions are simply a test of will not to jump from a roof after you have to reload the mission for the 50th time because it either bugs out or the mission itself makes it near impossible to be beaten if you are not lucky.

- The Story and dialogue options dry up after half the towns are taken over. I have not had any new "banter" conversations after being done halfway from the game. The first Blackguards was far superior in Story and Character Design.


Overall the game is fun to play if you like tactical round based combat. The story and dialogue is good to a certain point however not troughout the whole game which saddens me.

Currently there are too many issues with the game so I recomment waiting a little bit till the worst bugs are fixed and hopefully the game a little bit revised.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979893641', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1524, 'last_played': 1422209129}
review:
This game is a mixed bag.
If you liked the first BlackGuards 1, you will probably like the BlackGuards 2.
- The Story is okayish... but no real twist or big decisions to make here.
- Can¬¥t rotate the camera, so sometimes you have to play with a bad point of view.
- Nothing new on the Character evolotion side. I kinda made the same Chars wirth the same skills as in the first BG game.
   But this is more to the point that i felt forced to do this due to the difficulty of some levels and to lag of skills/classes/spells in this game.
- There are definatly Bugs in this game and you will run into some of them. 
   Some Voicea-acting stuff got skipped without pressing any key, so i missedf out on a bit story telling (happend 2      times). 
  Game got stuck in enemy turn during a fight, which forced me to redo the fight. (happend 2 times)
- In BG1 there been more sidequests than in BG2. Sure, you get to defend you Cities you conquered, but those battles dont bring you any benefit. And after a while they become anoying because of that. They drag the game unnecessary.

Most of my 25h playthrough I enjoyed playing BG2. 
In my opinion there are missing some cool sidequests.
Due to the lag of character individualisation the game should not be longer than that.
Otherwise you would end up not knowing where to invest your APs in.

Okay sequel... but could be better in some regards.

review:
Endlich wieder ein rundenbasiertes Spiel, davon gibt es in meinen Augen viel zu wenig. 
Blackguards 2 hat einiges ge√§ndert im Vergleich zum Vorg√§nger. Die Zauber treffen jetzt und sind weniger von Prozentchancen abh√§ngig, auch der Nahkampf ist nicht mehr so frustrierend. 
Insgesamt f√ºhlt sich alles etwas runder an. 

Dass man nun S√∂ldner mit verschiedenen Fertigkeiten anheuern kann, die ebenfalls besser werden und Erfahrung sammeln, macht das ganze Spiel reizvoll. 
So muss man vor den K√§mpfen ausw√§hlen, welche Truppengattung man mitnimmt. Die verschiedenen Eigenschaften beeinflussen dann die eigene Taktik. 
W√§hle ich eher den Nahkampf, eher den Fernkampf, mische ich, nehme ich Assassinen mit, oder Kampfmagier? 
F√ºr mich ein absolutes Plus in BG2 Das Fehlen der Attribute und das √Ñndern des DSA Regelwerks st√∂rt nur in den ersten Minuten und auch nur, wenn man entweder versiert in den DSA Regeln ist und darauf beharrt, oder den ersten Teil gespielt hat. 
Man kommt aber schnell rein und vermisst eigentlich sp√§ter nichts.

review:
Wenn ihr Spa√ü an Taktik-RPGs habt, k√∂nnt ihr hier bedenkenlos zugreifen.
Die Grafik hat sich im Vergleich zum ersten Teil nicht ge√§ndert, ist aber immer noch ganz ansehnlich (ich finde sie ganz in Ordnung f√ºr das Genre). Zudem sind die Schlachtfelder gr√∂√üer geworden, mit verschiedensten H√∂hen und Deckungsm√∂glichkeiten. Leider l√§sst sich die taktische Karte immer noch nicht drehen -> die √úbersicht leidet dadurch manchmal.
Man spielt durchgehend den Hauptcharakter Cassia, deren Ziel zwar festgelegt ist, aber mit einer Menge moralischer Entscheidungen, die den Spielverlauf teilweise sogar stark ver√§ndern. Sch√∂n ist, dass die Klasse von Cassia nicht vorgeben ist, ob Magierin, K√§mpferin, Heilerin, Bogensch√ºtzin oder einem Mix aus allem: das Spiel l√§sst sich durch einen gro√üen Talentbaum beliebig gestalten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006644191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 4355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4355, 'last_played': 1422804668}
review:
I understand that my point of view reflects almost a small minority; but I will state my opinion. I am a gamer since mid '80s, and almost explicitely play strategy and RPGs (not the action ones...).

This game is amazing fun. It's like fire emblem, but even better. It combiness strategy and RPG. It's neither dumbed down nor shallow on the contrary, it's deep and engaging. It throws you puzzles that you have to solve, so often you don't have to win by fighting, but by finding the right patterns. I played on hard and has been so far challenging and rewarding.

Speaking with nearly 40h playtime; I had encountered a few bugs during the first two days of release, but after the last patch all of them are fixed. I really don't get the complains about the broken and almost unplayable game (yup, I passed the druid and the adamant).

It runs very smoothly on my rig. I have no performance issues.

Frankly, why don't they make more games like this? It's one of the best turn based strategies, I have played - and believe me I have played a lot.

Overall, I loved this game and I would give it a 90/100. I recommend this to all players who are into strategy, puzzle solving and deep RPG rules.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065305792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1423095908}
review: Well super disapointed on this one. Why in a game that is based on a ruleset do you remove the key components of those rules? Why in an rpg where you had a lot of options for your character in the 1st game do you take that away? The very nature of the opening of this game gives me no hope for its plot to be anything but over the top contrivences. As for the streamlined inovations- what they did was gut the Dark Eye rules out of the game keeping a few things in name only and made it so it is no longer based off attributes at all. That is correct they decided that we are too stupid to understand attributes and they needed to go. Skills have been minimized to an extreme and weapon skills now range into ridiculously high numbers in comparison to non-weapon skills (teir one with a weapon is something like a value of 50). I love the Dark Eye rules and I loved the first game because it was a complicated tactical rpg. This is just a sad money grab at best. That being said if you didnt like the first game because you couldnt figure out the mechanics maybe this will be better for you... as long as playing a lunatic, tumor ridden woman is your idea of a good protagonist. After all if you dont take the dark fantasy anti-hero concept and beat us over the head with it until we cry  we wont get it. If it isnt clear I really want my 31 bucks back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005966101', 'num_games_owned': 742, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1422905765}
review:
Another great game for anyone who loves turn based combat.

Compared to Blackguards 1, the battles last a lot longer and require much more strategic decision making even before starting them (what kinds of mercenaries do I want to use this time? which heros will accompany them?) furthermore all maps seem to be virtually littered with interactive objects to either loot or utilize against your enemies.

The game mechanics introduced in Blackguards 1 have been simpified for this sequel, without removing any of their strategic complexity.

My personal favourite part of the game are the decisions and consequences, I am extremely glad that there is no karma meter in this game. Instead, your decisions on how you treat the people you conquer and those that travel with you have consequences within the boundaries of the game and it's story. 

All in all I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoys turn based combat and a rich story that truly allows to be a vile conquerer or a freedom fighter with a heart of gold.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038506457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1316, 'last_played': 1422334041}
review:
Blackguards 2 is a more combat-focus version of Blackguards 1.

While BG 1 was an RNG fest, BG2 removed so many of the annoying RNG and made strategical plays and puzzle stages a lot more common. Boss fights have you running around trying to abuse the stage hazard to the fullest to win. Certain stages will force you to complete objectives and leave or face infinite spawns unlike the old one where you can kill EVERYTHING except for one stage where you run away from the poison.

Outside of combat, you can now interact with characters more unlike the old one. You can capture prisoners, and interrogate them. Based on a choice, you can either make them spill the beans or spit at you. The informations required to make them answer can be obtained by paying for information from your beggar spies or by speaking around in your camp. After the interrogation, you can decide whether to hang them or let them go. Letting them go can be good but sometime, a certain person might come back to fight you again.

The customization has been greatly simplified. You no longer have the Strength, Charisma, etc from BG1. Instead, you just go with "+10 health" "+10 mana" "unlock tier 1 passive" in a straight line. Weapon level goes froml 1 - 100 and you unlock tier bonus at 50 80 100. While this means no weight limit from the removal of STR (Yes! No more weight issue!), it means much less customization. Even your mages will have as much hp as a fighter at the end making them unkillable.

And with that, let's move on to the balancing.

Endurance has been introduced. In BG1, all you had to do was buff someone and spam that 3x damage move like Hammer blow or Triple shot. You can't anymore. Endurance works like Astral point. When you use a combat skill, you use 10-20 points from you 40-80 endurance pool based on your stat. You regenerate a certain amount each turn based on passive (Endurance Regeneration) and gear bonus.

You can now have 100% hit rate. So much yes! If your offence (Hit rate) is high enough now to deal with their defense, you will always hit. Dodge and parry is one once per turn so sniping someone with a weak arrow first will move your hit rate on any further hit from 75% to 100% on the next one. Bow is a special case and its offense is reduced by range. You can easily check if you can hit people with bow now by simply holding X and moving around. It will show everything in range, the base hit rate and if the enemies are within the Line of Sight or not. Extremely useful and needed feature.

Damage is now consistent. Assuming no armor, if it says 6 damage, it will always deal 6 damage. Skills like "Hammer blow" was nerfed from *3 damage to +10 damage.

Most poison now lasts the entire fight and there are "Buff potions" around as well now.

And if you have nothing to do with your belt slot, they introduced the "Trinket" items that will boost your status while you are holding. Higher crit rate, damage or regeneration. All up to you!

You can place your characters starting location at the start of the battle now!

You can place traps in defensive stages when the enemies decide to attack your base (For every 3-4 conquers, they will attack once)

This should cover most of the new features. Now we will move on to the last part. The pro and con of this games.

Pro

-You now control an army. While everything was nerfed. this is because most combat now have you control 6-10 characters fighting against 6-15 characters as well. Before, you would just control one person with buff + Fast as lightning and tripleshot everything to death.

-Less RNG. More strategical plays and planning required to beat the game.

-Great dialogue just like BG1.

-Set bonus! Yes! no more "Just armor rating +1 and encumbrance reduction" now. You actually get stats from wearing a certain set!

-Your action now decide how good your characters will be and if they will be alive at the end or not. If you want, for the laugh of it, you can even order to execute your friends at the end before reloading a save after seeing their reactions.

Con

-Horribly unbalance. In BG1, all you do is abuse the same damaging weapon move like Triple shot or Hammer blow with buffs and fast as lightning to kill EVERYTHING. In BG2, with the damaging spell buffs and set items, mages are the most op beings ever in an army vs army fight. All you have to do is spam the same AoE spell to destroy everything in 3 - 4 turns assuming it's a "Kill everything" stage. 

-Defensive battle doesn't give AP. The fight is already having you fight with gimped characters.

-Certain stage is horribly tedious, even more tedious than the last one. Infinite spawn happens every 2-3 stages and you have to do the "Rush in, Rush out" kind of gameplay. It's not fun because after you move all your 8 characters to the end of the stage, you also have to wait for the other 10 characters on the enemies side to move. You end up spending 10-15 minutes on this stage just waiting for everything to move. If only they would tone these down and give us a way to stop the spawning.

-Very buggy. Still playable though.

-There's only stage with the Lizard-chan throughout the whole game. WTF?

Final Verdict : 7/10. 

Blackguards 2 feel like a DLC content with improved mechanic because that's exactly what it is, but we also have to remember it's being sold at a DLC price as well. Also, NEED MORE ACHAZ FFS.

Started barely passed the first few hours in a flash and I can tell so much, I look forward to the next hopefully many still tricky hours!
If you like exciting, challenging, turn-based games that almost addictive by a well thought out story, this is exactly the game that you can have long times find. author: {'steamid': '76561198075983278', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1673486072}
review:
BlackGuards 2 is the sequel to BlackGuards. When I first learned of another BlackGuards game I was a little worried because the first had just come out not even one year ago. Unfortunately I was correct to feel that way because BlackGuards 2 is filled with bugs and FPS drops.

I really like BlackGuards 2, but there always seems to be something that gets in the way of my enjoyment of the game. The first BlackGuards game was solid. I thought it could use some work, but it was a good game and I enjoyed playing through it with my created character.

BlackGuards 2 took more than one step backwards, but also took a step in the right direction too. I don‚Äôt know why Daedalic Entertainment decided to take away the character creator in BlackGuards. This is something that really bugged me throughout my entire playthrough of the game. Cassia is a nice character, but I would have preferred to create my own protagonist like I could back in BlackGuards 1.

You could have told the exact same story and had the exact same supporting characters. The game would literally be no different. Well‚Ä¶ the beginning of the game would be drastically different, but I‚Äôm not going to spoil it for those of you that haven‚Äôt played the game yet.

Another big problem that I have with BlackGuards 2 is the fixed camera. The camera angle is never in a good spot on any map. The only thing you can do is scroll all the way out for an overhead view of the area and even then there‚Äôs no guarantee that you‚Äôll see the whole battlefield.

The cast of characters range from mediocre to average at best. I never felt connected with anyone in this game. The only remotely interesting character in the entire game is Cassia. I love her insanity and will to rule despite having no real reason to want to rule the world. You can actually have full conversations with yourself and it‚Äôs up to you how they play out. Talking to myself was by far the most interesting dialogue in the game because you get to see just how far Cassia has fallen.

I mentioned that this game has it‚Äôs fair share of bugs. I can usually overlook some bugs and glitches, but I went through this entire game at 15-28 FPS. That is unacceptable; I can play Dragon Age Inquisition on Ultra at about 45-60 FPS. There is no reason why I shouldn‚Äôt be able to play this game at a solid 60 FPS. I even went as far as lowering the game to all the lowest settings and it didn‚Äôt make a difference and it really affected my playthrough.

I couldn‚Äôt go through a single map without some serious lag. You‚Äôre probably thinking that I really hate this game so far, but that couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth. I like BlackGuards 2 and I really wanted to come here and give a good review, but I can‚Äôt ignore the problems that it has right now. Hopefully there‚Äôs going to be a day one patch to straighten out some of these issues.

BlackGuards 2 isn‚Äôt all bad though. The one thing that BlackGuards always had going for it was gameplay and that‚Äôs no different here. BlackGuards 2 has really good gameplay. At the beginning of every battle you‚Äôll have a chance to set your team up around the map. From there you‚Äôre placed on a grid and every character has a chance to perform an action. Some battles are pretty tricky while others might feel a little cheap because of the huge disadvantage that you‚Äôll have.

Every fight is winnable with the right strategy, but there is a certain cheapness to it.  Another neat feature in BlackGuards 2 is the world map. The goal of the game is build a large enough army to take on the leader and rule the world.

There‚Äôs a problem with that though. I never actually felt like I was the leader of a massive army. Dragon Age Inquisition had this problem too, but it‚Äôs a much better game than BlackGuards 2. BlackGuards 2 is a solid sequel to a solid game, but it does have it‚Äôs fair share of problems right now. The truth is neither game would score very highly with me because of all the issues that they have and the developers have done nothing to really innovate the series.

If you‚Äôre considering BlackGuards 2 I would recommend you wait for it to go on sale because it‚Äôs not worth the asking price in it‚Äôs current state.

The Verdict: 6/10

If you disagree with my review that's fine, but don't think I won't block you if you start spamming me with insults. Keep it civil please. At the end of the day this is just one guy's opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975870581', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 296, 'last_played': 1427648836}
review:
Hi Folks, 

I just played about 4-5 hours of Blackguards 2 and I have to say it is a very good sequel for Blackguards 1. The pace was increased and the complexity seems to be more bearable. I had a few problems on Blackguards 1 with the dynamic of the gameplay. This issue seems to be resolved with Blackguards 2. The quality of this sequel is outstanding given the fact that it was published within 10 months after the first part was published. I really love the "Dark Eye" Universe and I like how it was implemented in this series. I love the idea that the battlemaps can now be explored for special loot. So you have to decide if there is "enough time" for exploring the battlemap or finishing off the bad guys in order to win the map. I also think that the first part relied too much on RNG. At least I had the feeling. The second part seems more rewarding when it comes to playing with the right strategy AND you finally has a percentage forecast that shows your chance of success. The Art and presentation is really really good. Deadalic has a bunch of very talented artists at hand! That is another plus on their side. Turn-based strategy never looked so good IMO. Another few changes that were made and that were really appreciated were the stamina stat, the mercenary army and the bigger scale of fights in general. I can recommend this game to every fan of turn based strategy games without a doubt!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013865593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1342, 'last_played': 1430201210}
review:
Where shall I start? 
The first time when I started Blackguards 2 I missed some things from the first part. I thought, hey where are my attributes, what have you done with the ‚ÄúDark Eye‚Äù rule set and so on and so on. But as longer as I played in the last days the more I do like the new Blackguards 2.

Well done, really well done. Game is faster now, less complicated and without the extremely luck factor you sometimes had in Blackguards 1 and you can go deeper in your strategy. 
Now it‚Äôs more reasonable what you have to do and when and why. I have a better feeling now before I fight because in my opinion BG 2 gives me more options and with that more challenging fights; fun included.

The changings allow you to have enough freedom in your character creation and it seems that some talents were redesigned for better gameplay. You need stamina now for your fighters and for the special attacks. This is neither good nor bad; just another change to give the game another feeling.

What I really, really like is the new strategic map for your campaigns. Every conquered location or city gives you a bonus for your mercenaries. My wish for a third sequel would be even more strategy on exactly this map. This makes the game really awesome and now it‚Äôs not ‚Äúonly‚Äù a fantasy battle with a few characters. 

One of the best tools in game is the new line of side tool which helps you a lot in range combat.

So, what does that mean? My conclusion on that is very simple, Blackguards 1 was good and solid, Blackguards 2 is better, the overall feeling is more compact now, BG is grown-up now.
Unfortunately it seems there are a few bugs inside which affected some players lucky me no bugs for me at the moment. *fingers crossed* 

For what I can see is, that the devs are very active in the forums and try helping people and fixing the bugs as fast as they can. For me this is a plus but to be honest in my opinion this should be the right way talking with your fans and customers. :)

So you think BG 1 was bad, than give BG2 a try because it differs and it‚Äôs better. 
So you think you have heard many obscure rumors, than give it a try because it‚Äôs worth your time and your money.

Just my 2cents :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198068379783', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1422371117}
review:
First things first: buy this game? Oh hell, you should! 

But before I jump to feed you with my opinion I would like to adress some of the most common concerns I stumbled upon while reading other reviews.

1. Le Bugs: 
Even though I could play my somewhat above 10 hours without running into any of them - yes, they exist. But the developers are obviously working their asses off to fix them (with the first fix being released only one day after launch). Also you shouldn't forget that it's not the developer who choses a release date, it's the publisher. Never before have I experienced such intense and quick user support on a launch. If you can't live with a few bugs on release, don't buy a game on release. Also, don't just walk away from this title, maybe just wait a little until the issues are fixed.

2. The game being dumbed down: 
First of all it's hilarious how people complain about how the game appears so easy yet they also complain about it being unbalanced. Here's what changed to Blackguards 1 and how:
- You have way less attributes, spells in tiers instead of slightly raising your skill until you hit a breakpoint, ect. As for the attributes, the system is still absolutely the same, it's just a different repesentation for you. So if you put a skill in "more Astral Energy", in the Background your intelligence gets higher. It's just easier to get what outcome your chosen skills have. For the Spells and their tiers...
- spells now have a 100% chance of hitting, makes the fights more predictable and fair. Not easier though, as this is countered with enemies resistances. You won't just run through missions fireballing everything and that's it
- new endurance-resource, that's to physical attacks what astral energy is to magical attacks. 

3. Difficulty and tactics:
yes, this game is difficult as shit. If you want a game without losing, without restarting because you made one too many mistakes, go play Hello Kitty Online, because this game is going to make you flip tables. But in a good way. At no point have I felt the game to be unfair. Insanely difficult, yes, but never unfair. There are a lot of mean surprises like a sudden new wave of enemies rushing in, and yes it can be frustrating to have to restart a battle because you became too sloppy with victory just before you, but as you replay a fight you improve your tactics and get rewarded herefore. If you play it safe instead of rushing through battles mindlessly, you get rewarded for it. That's exactly how it's supposed to be.
There are tons of strategial possibilities, with some of them being: 
- place your characters in a starting zone (least effect is that characters with high initiative won't get stuck in the behind - hehe)
- strategic world map where your choice of what stronghold you're going to attack next really has an impact (least of the impacts is which of your mercs improve in what way)
- various objectives and strategies for a lot (but not all) the battles
- next to unlimited possibilities to skill you characters, providing your very own winning strategy (the main character having astral points by default is just great, I completely messed that one up in Blackguards 1)

4 Graphics:
Yeah, so this is not Far Cry 4 or whatever game has the graphical high ground today, duh. If you care about the graphics, you will probably be disappointed. But if you care for atmosphere, impression and such, the graphics are just gold. It generally looks a lot like Blackguards 1, but far more polished, far more small details and impressive scenery. I just love it

5. My opinion:
Seing how big this review has become already, I'll try to make it short at this point:
Story is awesome, looks are awesome, gameplay is awesome, difficulty is hell but I love it. Can't say anything about bugs as I haven't encountered any, but if that's the reason you don't want to buy the game - do yourself a favour and come back in a few days, get it wenn the bugs are gone, is so worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985589039', 'num_games_owned': 543, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1422751262}
review:
Let me start by saying that a turn based combat game has never looked so good, the presentation, the art, the voice overs, the whole general design is really top stuff.

So why the down vote?


Firstly the same as the first one, these guys have learned nothing at all from the first game, the balance is horendous, really dire. You could start with say 5 on your side, but the enemy could start with say double that, and they keep respawning, calling reinforcments as well as the scripted stuff during the fight, it just becomes anoying that you may actually sit there swearing at your monitor, and this is on easy mode too, so much for easy mode huh.

You dont really have much freedom in the combat too, with only one right way to finish it really, as for now being able to choose who starts where, this is pathetic, you can only really place them where you would start anyways...like wtf?

Parts of the game is even in german still???

Finally, bugs, game breaking bugs, after playing for a good few hours the game will lock up during combat, probably as it spawns so many enemys it gets confused, or the game will go limbo on you waiting for someone to take there turn but they never do.

Word of warning, these lockups can not be sorted with ctrl alt delete, the only way to get rid of it is to hard reset your pc.

Such a shame i love the characters etc in this game, really want to love it, really wanted it to go on and on but with the same problems as the first, then you just got to avoid this game.

If they can make a balance sweep on it , if just for easy mode, and fix the damn game breaking bugs (there are more) then it would be my top TBC game, thats how close they are, but as i said, avoid it as balance is a issue, but you will end up with the game crashing etc at same point and not even being able to play further.

Edit:

I have just retried the game, i get so many bugs it is a joke.
No matter what save i load i will get one of the following:

1 The game will freeze up
2 The game waits for a character to move who doesnt
3 A new bug just now, it was waiting fo rme to move Takate, who was not even in the party!

For love of all things, avoid this pile of poop.

[h1]Blackguards 2: Storytelling um die weiche Birne[/h1]

Ich kann noch nicht allzu viel berichten, da ich das Spiel bisher nur angezockt habe.

Doch der erste Eindruck ist ein durchweg positiver. Auch, wenn mich die Grafik etwas f√ºr das Jahr 2015 irritiert hat:
Dieser Titel beweisst, dass es keine bombastische Grafik-Engine braucht, um den Spieler zu fesseln. Selten musste ich aufgrund des direkten, teils dunkelschwarzen Humors so oft lachen wie hier allein innerhalb der sehr kurzen Testzeit. Die Tatsache, dass man durch die Vielzahl an Auswahlm√∂glichkeiten zur Charakterskillung und deren Funktionsweise erst etwas √ºberfahren wird,  wird durch das gekonnte Storytelling - ja, hier liegt meiner Meinung nach die Kernkompetenz des Spiels - sowie die auf Taktik ausgerichteten, rundenbasierten K√§mpfe, sch√∂n ausgehebelt. Dass ein anderes Regelwerk als das DSA Regelwerk hinter den K√§mpfen steckt, ist sofort erkennbar. Weniger Zufall - mehr Skill und Mechanik waren hier die Hauptzutaten.

Ohne zu spoilern: Die Charakter- und Storypr√§sentation ist - f√ºr den Anfang - grandios! Wer Wert auf viel Content, Story und strategische K√§mpfe legt, ist hier gut aufgehoben! Zumal man den mehr als fairen Preis betrachtet...

author: {'steamid': '76561197970189587', 'num_games_owned': 1464, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1663, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1663, 'last_played': 1421965501}
review:
I finished Blackguards 2 after a bit more than 25 hours and I tried not to enter the final stage, before I had really done everything. I find the game very  entertaining, it has not-too-easy tactical combats, tells an interesting story of a once lovely lady, that is made into an insane and kind-of-evil conquerer. The Player can also decide, if he is more like a Robin Hood-Rogue or a true brutal and ruthless bandit, who seeks only his own fortune.

A big variety on weapons and spells, all based on the dark eye license (Das Schwarze Auge in german) and a lot of known places gives fans of DSA/The Dark Eye a great familiar feeling and everyone else a dense world, with its own logic, history and myths, that has grown for over 30 years. 

Compared to the first Blackguards, the Combats are bigger, offer more variety and a few very important changes have been made, that adjust the Dark-Eye-Ruleset to fit better into a PC Game. For example there are now exakt percentage-forcasts on your chances to hit, additional to Lifepoints and mana, there is now Stamina. 

You do not only control a group of heroes but also get a mercenary army under your command with differnt classes of fighters or special units. With those troops you try to conquer the part of the World where the game takes place and you must repell sudden counterattacks from your AI-Opponent. This feels a bit like the good old Jagged Alliance with its sectors. 

Overall, Blackguards 2 is one of the game to really dive in for several hours/days. 

Looking forward to part 3 ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000751969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1646, 'last_played': 1422309523}
review:
Kind of a mixed bag for me since I never played Blackguards 1, which is (probably) responsible for my biggest issue;
The game is completely un-immersive in terms of story, like; *spoiler* you jump from the prison to a jungle arena -> to a dwarf mansion -> to a desertlike sahara -> to the dwarf mansion again in a matter for 5 minutes without having to travel there yourself. */spoiler*
In the mean time I have no idea how the main character knows every character she's trying to find and how she got this information in the first place.

But anyway, if you can look past that (or maybe, if you had everything explained in Blackguards 1) and go for gameplay, this game is for you.
The character customization options are wonderful and though initially the controls (without shortcuts) are a little fidgetty, after a thorough getting used to it's managable and even enjoyable.

Overall 7/10, with the right amount of immersion this would make a great 'D&D-like' game. 
Would recommend it to my friends, but not for release price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990001715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1421916219}
review:
Lets start by saying that this is a solid game, because it is. Would i recommend it? No. 

Lets go over the whats and whys. 

The inifial concept of the story struck me as something at least somewhat new and unique. Starting as a semi insane person is novelty in a way, if we forget Malkavians and the like. But it quickly slided down in terms of quality. The story is not entirely compelling and no matter what you do. You, ONCE AGAIN will never not in a million yeas get a good ending. Doesnt matter how good you are, doesnt matter how amazing was your decisionmaking or fighting. It just doesnt matter. The ending is set in stone,  you will die after 1 day of ruling, No matter what. Im fucking sick of every recent game in my memory doing that. It started with atrocious ending of ME3 and then it went on and on and on, - PC and NIiam dead in original Blackguards, tons of other games its like the new trademark: make endings spit you in the face. Fuck your efforts we want it to be remembered. And yes its understtandable from the story perspective and all but sersiously im sick of it.

Character creation and advancement. 

Stats were removed. And the system refined a bit, now you see what you pay for immediately. Its more user friendly, but i found that to me game lost a bit of charm with that decision, but dont get me wrong, i think its for the better. A lot of rebalancing, like the Witches Bile being nerfed aswell as some others, like the poison removal. No more wound persisting. Overall its way more user friendly. 

Story Discontinuity. 

This is a small problem which will probably be adressed in the near future -> there are some minor bugs with how story progresses, namely in the beginning you are teleported from dwarf mansion into a conversation with a mage already without a mask. That is done on a few occasions buts its very minor. 

Characters.

Well if you liked Naurim, his best buddy mage and Takashi or whats his face then i got great news for you! Unfortunately you will not have a designated ranged weapon specialist unless you will specialise into it. Oh! But let me tell you, you will want to  have a few spells up your sleeve! Thats right, you can progress anything any time! No more restrictions! On the other hand you WILL be forced to take Heal on your main guy for some fights. Otherwise you cant win them or will have to lower difficulty. Literally no other way. (unless you are willing to burn through consumables like crazy) 

Fights. 

Fights were great in the original game, they are even better here. Extremely challenging just by sheer ammount of bullshit some of them entail. How would you like to have 2 of your characters berzerking hitting everything that moves including friendlies, one envelopped in sand and immobile and last one trying to fidget with levers watching in terror as his teammates are torn to bits. Over and over and over and over. Or the neverending 2-4 mobs spawning every turn. Some fights are stupidly hard, some are ridiculously easy with double mage setup. Regardless the combat is way better then it was in the 1st game. 

Better camera controlls aswell, - all issues of the old game were adressed. Somehow though im not happy with this one. By all rational thought process this IS a better game in every aspect. But i somehow just dont feel it. The best way to describe it would be imagine there is a great local singer and he is putting his heart and soul into his songs, they arent flawless, but he touches you, you love it its great. Then he is picked up by some big studio, he is given tons of recources,  concerts, videoclips, support, backstage dancers - everything. But in his eyes you do not see the fire of old. The soul of what made him great is gone. To those who see him 1st time he is just another 'good new singer' but for you he is nothing like what he was of old. Yes he looks better and sings better but its not him. Dissapointed you switch channel with a sigh. 

This is how i feel about Blackguards 2. Its a good game, honestly. I d give it 7/10. But i would not recommend people to play it. Im sorry it just lacks the soul.

Man merkt das die Erfahrungen die durch den ersten Teil gemacht wurden hier eingeflossen sind und das Daedalic auf dem besten Weg ist ihre Expertise im Adventure-Genereauch auf andere Generes auszuweiten.  Mit Cassia hat man einen interessanten Charakter erschaffen der mir bereits jetzt nach 4 Stunden Spielzeit ans Herz gewachsen ist. Cassia hebt sich wohltuend von den 08/15 Helden dieser Tag ab und bringt frischen Wind ins ansonsten staubige Helden-Klischee-Zimmer. Spielerisch hat sich auch einiges getan. Es gibt neue Modi und einige nervt√∂tende Dinge wie das m√ºhsame Heilen der Helden nach einem Kampf sind entfallen. Das mag den einen oder anderen Hardcore-Rollenspieler nicht gefallen, aber im Sinne der Spielbarkeit eine gute Entscheidung. Was geblieben ist, ist der hohe Schwierigkeitsgrad und der Hang bestimme Spiel-Situationen nur durch Trial and Error erfolgreich bew√§ltigt werden k√∂nnen. Trotz gelegentlich auftretender Bugs ist Blackguards 2 ein tolles Spiel geworden das zu dem sehr g√ºnstig ist und mir viel Spa√ü bereitet.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970893072', 'num_games_owned': 663, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1422764415}
review:
If you were a fan of the original Blackguards, you'll find much to love in the new release. There are beloved  characters (Naurim, Zurbaran, et al.)  making their returns, and an all-new story of politics and revenge.

Some of the awkward aspects of the first release have been addressed.

Lasting wounds no longer require in-town healers to fix. In the previous game, this was a well-intentioned incentive to play well, but typically turned into a money/time sync. It's gone. Good riddance.

While the story still follows a relatively linear arc, the overworld map has many more nodes than before, representing land held by you and your opponent. If you and your armies can overtake these nodes, they unlock valuable bonuses and paths to new dungeons. Be warned, they can also be re-taken by your opponent, forcing you to re-take those nodes.

This allows a bit more variety than before. Instead of strictly puzzle-based handcrafted levels, you can now "grind" a little bit for XP and fun. This was sorely missed in the original game. It's not a complete solution, but alleviates a lot the pain.

The game has been simplified to make it more appealing to the less hardcore tabletop gamers. Skill trees are streamlined and some of the more cryptic stats have been brought in to the light.

You will also find levels that can be treated more as a tactical match instead of a puzzle whose trick needs to be figured out. In other words, the previous game had only one or two "correct" ways to finish a fight. This restriction has been loosened somewhat - although not to the degree that it should have.

Vorab: Ich mag sp√§testens seit History Line 1914-18 rundenbasierte Strategiespiele und bin damit affin f√ºr das Genre von BG2. 
Teil 1 habe ich gespielt und auch ich hatte einige Verbesserungsw√ºnsche an den Nachfolger. Daher freue ich mich, dass Daedalic zugeh√∂rt und vieles umgesetzt hat. Besonders wichtig ist hierbei das generelle Gelingen von Zaubern. Als alter Rollenspieler ist dies nat√ºrlich gleichzeitig ein gro√üer Schritt weg vom Regelwerk von DSA. Mir gef√§llt es gut, da nun Gl√ºck weniger Einfluss auf den Kampf hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005059495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1421814910}
review:
Extremely linear boring slogfest of an adventure game.  Thats right this is not a strategy RPG.  Sure it has some basic elements of the genre but it is nothing more than a boring story that forces you to play as one of the most annoying characters I have ever seen.

After an insufferable tutorial you are forced into clunky boring battles.  No choice no nothing.

The game is absolute abomination at its current price point.  It is not worth more than five dollars and that is a high price point.


Do not be deceived as I was by the games "features" in it's discription.  This is not a strategy RPG that allows you to recruit a team and upgrade them how you see fit as you lay waste to your enemies.  No this is an adventure game with a very linear plot and choose your ending story.   Did I mention it has an insufferable forced tutorial that will put you to sleep while you struggle trying to figure out why in the world you can access your inventory in battle but not equip anything.

Overall absolute trash of a game, do not buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041367767', 'num_games_owned': 1241, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1424442031}
review:
Blackguards 2 Gameplay Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E_QqFF42Kw0&list=UUUx4FfVE0Xfh4-AAtpxKikg

+ In depth tutorial for players new to the series
+ Really nice visuals and graphics
+ Runs well even on highest settings
+ Tactics are not simple or straightforward, they have depth and vary in approach
+ Hours and hours of gameplay to be had
+ Ability system is great once you get to grips with it
+ Moral choices that directly affect the game
+ Varied and well designed maps

- Maps sometimes need a trial run as objectives and tactics are not immediately obvious and early mistakes can be a death sentence on harder difficulties
- Getting to grips with the ability system can be trial and error as it is never properly explained
- Spec options and statistics are not explained in enough depth
- Aside from Cassia, other characters can take a while to warm to as they slowly reveal their backstory

[b]Talente und Magie[/b]
Die Skills und Talente wurden ordentlich aufger√§umt. W√§hrend wir in Teil 1 noch unz√§hlig Punkte verteilten um Zauber etc. auf Stufe 1 bis 4 zu bekommen ist diese rumz√§hlerei nun verschwunden. [b]Sprecher[/b]
